                                              Department : Surgical Gastroenterology
                                                          Discharge Summary

CR No.: 239212503329939                Name: Subhash Kumar Vishwakarma                             Age/Gender: 35 Yr/M

Admission No.: 239212025077479         Department Unit: Surgical Gastroenterology (Surgical        Consultant/Faculty: Dr Pravesh
                                       Gastroenterology)                                           Mathur

Ward: Gastro Surgery Ward              Room/Bed: Gastro Srg Ward Room/ Bed 7                       Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat

 Discharge Type: Normal Discharge      Father/Spouse Name: Rambahor Vishwakarma/-                  Occupation:

Contact No.: 8460413474                Address: ..,,..,Bhopal                                      State/Country Madhya
                                                                                                   Pradesh/India

D.O.A. : 22-Dec-2025 09:56             D.O.D. : 28-Dec-2025                                        D.O. Print Report: 28-Dec-2025 15:09

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
Admitted for evaluation of anemia
No fresh complaints
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Pt is K/C/O acute necrotizing pancreatitis with WOPN with DPDS, admitted in SGE ward previously &
underwent PCD on Nov 25. Currently no output from PCD for 10 days. Pt presented in OPD for PCD management. During evaluiation
pt was found to have severe anemia (Hb5.3, TLC 16200), hence admitted for evaluation & further management. Currently no
abdominal pain/distension/vomiting/fever/GI bleed. No co morbidities.
CASE SUMMARY: Patient conscious, oriented to time, place and person, and fairly nourished, afebrile. No
oedema/LN/clubbing/pallor/icterus are present. Weight-53 kg,height-161 cm, BMI- 20.5 kg/m2,PR-86/min, BP- 104/64 mmHg, RR- 20,
Spo2- 98%. P/A- soft, non tender, no Distension/organomegaly/no ascites/no scars. PCD in situ- Clamped.
CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Pt is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing stools, P/A soft, non tender,
PCD insitu with stoma bag applied over it. Pt is being discharged in stable condition.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
F/U/C/O acute necrotizing pancreatitis


Walled off necrosis


DPDS


Anemia


Left pleural effusion


HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient was admitted in SGE ward for evaluation of anemia & sepsis. Necessary blood investigations were done
(Hb-5.2 TLC-16280, Plt-4.2 L, urea/creat-15/0.7,Na/K-135/4.1, TB/DB-0.9/0.7, AST/ALT- 12/6, ALP/GGT-167/49-, TP/Alb-7.4/2.9 & viral
markers negative. Urgent CECT abdomen + thorax was planned to look for cause of anemia. 1 PRBC was transfused on 22/12
followed by another on 23/12/25. Post BT CBC- Hb/TLC/Plt.- 8.6/5700/2.12 CECT abdomen + thorax angiography was done on
22/12/25 which was provisionally s/o 2x4cm peripancreatic collection with pigtail tip insitu, splenic infarct over lower pole & no e/o
pseudoaneurysm (final report awaited). i/v/o residual collection, PCD is retained. During hospital course, patient managed with iv
antibiotics (Meropenem), PPI, analgesics & symptomatic & supportive care. Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory,
afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and motion, abdomen soft, non -tender, PCD insitu and hence being discharged in stable




                                                                                                                                Page No: 1

                                                                                      CR: 239212503329939




condition.
ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:
High protein diet.
PCD care, regular flushing & output charting as advised.
T. pantoprazole 40mg od x 10 days.
T. Paracetamol 500mg tds x 3 days then SOS.
T. Iron + Folic acid od x 2 weeks.
T. Vit C 500mg od x 2 weeks.
Chest physiotherapy & spirometry.
To collect CT scan report.
To consult in Pulmonology OPD for left pleural effusion.
To review in SGE OPD as advised with CBC report.


DISCHARGE BY : Dr Pravesh Mathur
DISCHARGE REMARKS :
FOLLOW UP ON : 08-Jan-2026
FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Pravesh Mathur
FOLLOW UP ADVICE : To consult in TEM in case of abdominal pain/distension/vomiting/fever etc.
Summary Prepared By                                             Summary Approved By

Dr S Sriram                                                     Dr Pravesh Mathur

                                             Department : Surgical Gastroenterology
                                                         Discharge Summary

CR No.: 239212503329939               Name: Subhash Kumar Vishwakarma                             Age/Gender: 35 Yr/M

Admission No.: 239212025067710        Department Unit: Surgical Gastroenterology (Surgical        Consultant/Faculty: Dr Pravesh
                                      Gastroenterology)                                           Mathur

Ward: Gastro Surgery Ward             Room/Bed: Gastro Srg Ward Room/ Bed 2                       Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat

 Discharge Type: Normal Discharge     Father/Spouse Name: Rambahor Vishwakarma/-                  Occupation:

Contact No.: 8460413474               Address: ..,,..,Bhopal                                      State/Country Madhya
                                                                                                  Pradesh/India

D.O.A. : 06-Nov-2025 12:51            D.O.D. : 28-Nov-2025                                        D.O. Print Report: 28-Nov-2025 12:30

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
���Abdominal pain since 20 days
���Vomiting since since 20 days
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient was apparently alright 20 days back when he noticed pain in abdomen since 20 days in
periumbilical region, non radiating aggravating with meals , temporarily revealed with medications.Patient noticed vomiting since 20
days (bilious) ,No h/o bowel /bladder complaints ,No h/o abdominal distension/constipation.
CASE SUMMARY: Patient conscious, oriented to time,place and person, and fairly nourished.No oedema/LN/clubbing/pallor/icterus
are present. Weight- kg,height- cm, BMI- kg/m2,PR-136/min, BP- 140/90mmHg, RR- 20, Spo2- 98%.On examination-Chest- B/L air
entry present,P/A- soft,epigastric tenderness present, no Distension/organomegaly/no ascites/no scars.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
Acute necrotizing pancreatitis;


DPDS


WON


S/P PCD (12/11/2025)


HOSPITAL COURSE:
Patient was admitted in SGE ward for above mentioned complaints, Routine blood investigations were done ( Hb-10.3 TLC-10590, Plt-
3.55L,, PT/INR ��� 16/1.36, urea/creat-29/0.5,Na/K-127/3.8, TB/DB-4.5/3.7, AST/ALT- 92/53, ALP-417-, TP/Alb-6.3/2.8 & viral markers
negative. Planned for drainage of collection. Pulmonary medicine consultation was sought for : CXR changes. USG guided diagnostic
tap was advised for pleural fluid.VIR consultation was sought for pleural effusion SOS diagnostic tapping and for drainage of
peripancreatic collection. On USG evaluation an anechoic collection ( well defined anechoic with free floating echoes noted in the
pancreatic head region.Usg guided pigtail was not feasible due to close proximity of bowel. CT guided pigtail was advised.
Consultation was sought from General Surgery for left sided ICD Placement and the patient was referred to Pulmonary Medicine i/v/o
B/L Pleural effusion. . Radiology Consultation was sought for CT s/o multiple pancreatic necrosis i/v/o CT guided pigtail drainage.
Cardiology consultation was sought i/v/o HTN (BP-150/110 mmhg) ,necessary advice followed.VIR conjsultation was sought i/v/o
residual collection, collection noted with pigtail in situ. On 19/11/25 under all aseptic precautions with LA cover USG guidance
repositioning of pigtail was done. On 20/11/25On 21/11/25 inj Meropenem, Inj vancomycin were stopped.On 24.11.25 VIR
consultation was sought for pigtail repositioning. VIR reference taken (26/11/25) for pleural tapping, diagnostic tap done, sent for




                                                                                                                                Page No: 1

                                                                                               CR: 239212503329939




pleural fluid tests. During hospital course, patient managed with IVF, iv antibiotics ,PPI, iv antipyretics, Iv antiemetics, iv diclofenac,
symptomatic & supportive care.
OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: CECT ABDOMEN 20/11/25:OBSERVATIONS Pigtail / Procedure Site:Post-procedural changes: pigtail catheter
in left lumbar region, tip abutting lower pole of spleen.Thin fluid collection (max 6 mm) in left lateral abdominal wall with few air foci.
PANCREASBulky pancreas (Head 3.4 cm, body 2.8 cm, tail 3.4 cm).Extensive peripancreatic fat stranding.Non-enhancing areas in neck
and distal body (<30% necrosis).Rest shows inhomogeneous enhancement.MPD not visualized.No calcifications. COLLECTIONS: 1.
Neck region:Heterogeneous ill-defined collection involving entire thickness of neck (~3.1 cm length).Extends into peripancreatic
region, mesenteric region near head.Size approx. 8.1 �� 5.9 �� 3.9 cm (CC �� TR �� AP). 2. Distal body and tail:Multiloculated,
heterogeneously hypodense collection with focal peripheral enhancement.Extends to peripancreatic region, lesser sac, perisplenic
region.Size approx. 8.6 �� 10.8 �� 10.3 cm (TR �� AP �� CC).Multiple air foci and air���fluid levels (? post-procedural).Tracks
inferiorly to left paracolic gutter, left perinephric region; superiorly to gastrosplenic region.These two collections intercommunicate.
VESSELS:Splenic vein, portal vein, SMV patent; portal vein mildly dilated (15 mm).Splenic and gastroduodenal arteries normal; no
aneurysm or thrombosis.No pseudoaneurysm or contrast leak. ASCITES / PERITONEUMMinimal ascites in pelvis and peritoneal cavity.
CHEST FINDINGSModerate left pleural effusion (max thickness 5.4 cm) with segmental collapse/consolidation.Right lung: multiple
GGO patches forming small consolidations.Left lung: fibro-atelectatic bands in lingula; few centrilobular nodules.GI TRACT:Mild
edematous wall thickening: proximal descending colon and splenic flexure (5���6 mm).Mural irregularities in descending colon
(advise per-rectal contrast if required).Mild wall thickening of greater curvature of stomach (reactive).Spleen:Mild splenomegaly (12.7
cm).Small wedge-shaped non-enhancing area in lower pole (11��8 mm) ��� splenic infarct.
IMPRESSION-Acute Necrotizing Pancreatitis (<30% necrosis):Two large intercommunicating infected walled-off collections involving
neck, body, tail; extending into lesser sac, perisplenic, paracolic gutter, mesentery, left perinephric region.Multiple air foci ���
likely infected / post-drainage.Post-procedural pigtail at left lumbar region.Minimal ascites; moderate left pleural
effusion.Inflammatory peritonitis with peritoneal thickening and fat stranding.Reactive mural thickening of descending colon, splenic
flexure, and stomach.Small splenic infarct (lower pole).Lung findings: patchy GGOs + small consolidations, likely
inflammatory/infective.Modified CTSI = 8/10 (Severe Acute Necrotizing Pancreatitis).
USG W/A 29/10/25,OUTSIDE): Hepatomegaly with Grade I���II fatty liver. Mild splenomegaly. Bilateral pleural effusion
(minimal).Moderate echogenic sludge in gallbladder. Features suggestive of acute pancreatitis.
USG W/A 01/11/2025,OUTSIDE:Minimal free fluid in left flank region. Small bowel loops showing increased caliber. Possibility of early
ileus.Minimal posterior collection.Impression: Minimal ascites. Features likely representing paralytic ileus..
USG W/A (04/11/2025) (OUTSIDE):Cholelithiasis with cholecystitis / sludge-filled GB. Minimal ascites.Mildly increased peristalsis.
ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:
High Protein diet
Pigtail output monitoring
T. Ofloxacin 200mg BD x 5 days
T. PANTOPRAZOLE 40mg OD x 5 days
T. PCM + Aceclofenac (325mg+100mg)BD x 5days
T. Telma 40 mg OD
Syp MVI 10ML od x 5 days
Syp lactulose 20 ml HS X 5 days
T. Ivabradine 5mg BD x 5 days
Review in SGE OPD on Monday/Thursday
DISCHARGE BY : Dr Pravesh Mathur
DISCHARGE REMARKS : Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and motion,
abdomen soft, non -tender and hence being discharged in stable condition.

FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Pravesh Mathur
FOLLOW UP ADVICE : To visit TEM/nearby hospital if abdominal pain/vomiting/fever.

       replacing the parenchyma. It measures 2.3x2x2.3cm (TRxAPxCC).Multiple
       intercommunicating collection pockets with irregular shape noted in the peripancreatic region
       at tail, extending to gastrosplenic space, lienorenal and left suprarenal space. The largest
       pocket measures 4.6x2x2.5cm (TRxAPxCC). They show thick enhancing wall and central
       non-enhancing hypodense fluid component. There are contiguous streak of extension into
       the splenic parenchyma at lower pole with surrounding heterogenous enhancement. Pigtail
       tip noted within the collection at the peripancreatic tail region, with tip abutting splenic
       parenchyma.No evidence of any aneurysm/narrowing/thrombosis involving the celiac trunk or
       its branches.No evidence of any thrombosis/narrowing involving the spleno-mesenteric axis.
   ❍   Abdominal aorta showing normal course and caliber with no evidence of luminal narrowing or
       atheromatous changes.
   ❍   Major branches of abdominal aorta including celiac axis, bilateral renal arteries, inferior
       mesenteric artery and bilateral common iliac branches showing normal course and caliber.
   ❍   Right hepatic artery noted arising as a direct branch from celiac trunk.
   ❍   Gall bladder: appears distended with no content in GB lumen. However mild GB wall
       thickening noted (max thickness 3.4mm).
   ❍   Liver: Few (atleast 4) small relatively defined lesions showing central non-enhancing
       heterogenous iso to hyperdense content (mean HU +39), and peripheral rim of enhancement
       on further contrast phase, largest measuring 19x18x15mm (TRxAPxCC) in segment VII. On
       USG correlation they appears as relatively defined heterogenous hypoechoic areas-in given
       clinical context likely represent micro-abscess.
   ❍   Spleen: rest of the spleen is otherwise normal.
   ❍   Bilateral kidneys appear normal in size and CT attenuation.No evidence of
       hydroureteronephrosis noted.
   ❍   Well defined hypodense lesion with few vertical trabeculations and intervening fatty marrow

       noted in the T9 vertebral body with intact cortex – suggestive of hemangioma.

IMPRESSION- CT Aortography reveals-
   ❍Mild atrophic pancreas at neck and proximal body with bulky tail, showing heterogenous
    hypoenhancing areas. There is diffuse peripancreatic fat stranding with intercommunicating
    collection pockets in the peripancreatic region at tail, as described. Pigtail tip in situ with tip
    abutting the splenic parenchyma.
*Features s/o severe pancreatitis (modified CTSI score 8/10) with acute necrotic collection
pockets.
   ❍Patchy areas of GGO in right upper lobe, superior and posterior basal segments of right
    lower lobe, and inferior lingular segments in bronchovascular distribution. Moderate left
    pleural effusion with associated mild parietal and visceral pleural thickening-features s/o
    infective etiology.
   ❍Few (atleast 4) small relatively defined lesions in segment VI, VII and IVA; showing central
    non-enhancing heterogenous iso to hyperdense content, and peripheral rim of enhancement
    on further contrast phase. On USG correlation they appear as relatively defined
    heterogenous hypoechoic areas-in given clinical context likely represent micro-abscess.
    Advice: follow up USG.

                                                            CECT CHEST AND ABDOMEN
CLINICAL NOTES:
   Complains of pain abdomen since 18/10/25 which was sudden in onset in the peri umbilical
   ●


   region.
   Exaggerated on food intake and relieved on medications.
   ●


   CT done outside (27/10/25) : Acute necrotizing pancreatitis with peripancreatic collection
   ●


   (Modified CT severity index - 8). Mild ascites. Reactionary wall thickening in stomach and
   1st part of duodenum.
   S/p – pigtail (12/11/25)
   ●


   Currently complains of severe pain with fever spikes.
   ●


OBSERVATIONS:
   Post procedural changes in form of pigtail insertion in left lumbar region with tip abutting the
   ●


   lower pole of spleen. There is thin strip of fluid collection in intermuscular plane in lumbar
   region (max thickness 6mm) of left lateral abdominal wall with few air attenuating foci within.
   Pancreas: Appears bulky (Head = 3.4 cm, body = 2.8 cm, tail = 3.4cm) with extensive
   ●


   peripancreatic fat stranding.Pancreas enhancement: shows non enhancing areas in the neck
   and distal body region . Rest of the pancreas shows inhomogenoius enhancement. (<30%
   necrosis)MPD: not visualized.Calcification: no evidence of any parenchymal or intraductal

MRCP

# Clinical Details:

- Complains of abdominal pain associated with vomiting since 20 days.
- Serum amylase AIIMS (26/11/25) : 69.68 U/L
- CECT Abdomen AIIMS (17/11/25) :Post-procedural status in form of pigtail catheter in left lumbar region with tip abutting lower pole of spleen. Changes of acute necrotizing pancreatitis (<30% pancreatic necrosis ) with two intercommunicating collections involving the neck, body and tail of pancreas, extending into the peripancreatic region in lesser sac, perisplenic region, left para-colic gutter, mesentery and left perinephric region. Multiple air foci seen within this collection. Minimal ascites with left moderate pleural effusion .Diffuse peritoneal thickening and fat stranding, likely inflammatory peritonitis. Mild mural thickening of descending colon/splenic flexure and greater curvature of stomach—likely reactive. Mural irregularities seen at few places in descending colon (Adv per-rectal contrast study if clinically indicated).Mild splenomegaly with small splenic infarct in lower pole.Patchy areas of GGOs with small consolidation areas in right upper and lower lobe - likely inflammatory/infective. Modified CTSI – 8/10 (Severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis). ●
- Serum Direct Bilirubin AIIMS : 0.621 mg/dL (elevated).
- Scan done to rule out other causes of biliary obstruction.

## OBSERVATIONS:

- Gall bladder: appears distended and with a no evidence ofT2 hypointense filling defect in GB lumen. However mild GB wall thickening noted (max thickness 3.5mm). No evidence of wall inflammation or pericholecystic fluid noted. ●
- The cystic duct is dilated in caliber (max diameter 5.5mm) and is seen inserting into mid CBD

## in right lateral aspect.

Vishwakarma

CBD: Distal intra-pancreatic CBD is narrowed and ill defined showing smooth tapering with upstream mild dilatation of proximal CBD, CHD and cystic duct - likely due to underlying Pancreatic inflammatory process. ●

No evidence of any T2 hypointense filling defect noted. No obvious mass/soft tissue lesion is seen in the peri ampullary region.

| Level       | Diameter (mm) |
|-------------|---------------|
| CBD         | 7.0           |
| CHD         | 8.4           |
| RHD         | 6.3           |
| LHD         | 6.5           |
| Cystic duct | 5.5           |

Pancreas: appears enlarged (head ~ 3.4cm ; body ~ 4cm ; tail ~ 2.5cm )with fuzzy irregular margins. Abnormal T2 intermediate hyperintense signal noted in the head and uncinate process (more than 30%) of pancreas which shows mild diffusion restriction on DWI/ADC likely necrotic heterogenous content. Non visualization of MPD at the level of head and body with reappearance at tail –likely due to technical factors/pancreatic edema.

A relatively defined relatively thick walled T2 hyperintensity with central isointense region of size 29x45x28mm (APxTRxCC) is noted arising from the pancreatic tail region, seen laterally extending till perisplenic space, superiorly till the greater curvature of stomach, inferiorly along left para-nephric space, and left upper para-colic gutter .

- Liver: enlarged in size ~18 cm in maximum cranio-caudal dimension. Few small T2 hyperintense /T1 hypointense lesions ( of largest size 9x7mm) noted in segment 5 and 6 of liver with DWI and ADC hyperintensity . These lesions were not seen in previous CT ?
- early forming abscesses. Spleen: enlarged in size, measures~12.8 cm in cranio-caudal dimension with abnormal T2 ●
  - hyperintense wedge shaped signals noted in the lower pole of spleen which shows diffusion restriction on DWI/ADC? infarct

- Bilateral kidneys appear normal in size and signal intensity.No evidence of hydroureteronephrosis noted. Minimal perinephric free fluid noted along the upper poles of bilateral kidneys. ●
- An oval shaped T2 hyperintense lesion noted in the T9 vertebral body suggestive of hemangioma. ●
- Visualized lower thorax shows left moderate pleural effusion (maximum pleural seperation 29 mm) with septations and collapse-consolidation of underlying lung parenchyma. ●

## IMPRESSION:MRCP reveals:

- Enlarged pancreas at head, body and tail with fuzzy irregular margin with pancreatic necrosis with peripancreatic collection as described. ●
- Non visualization of MPD at the level of head and body with reappearance at tail- likely due to technical factors/pancreatic edema. ●
- Hepatosplenomegaly.
- Few oval shaped T2 hyperintense lesions with no diffusion restriction in the segment V and VI of right lobe of liver ? early forming abscesses. ●
- Abnormal wedge shaped T2 hyperintense area in the lower pole of spleen which shows diffusion restriction on DWI/ADC ? infarct ●

Fluid Cytology ID:C-3375/25: Peripancreatic fluid.

Received 2 ml grey white slightly turbid

Clinical details: Chronic pancreatitis with pseudocyst

Microscopic findings:

Centrifuged smears show variably preserved morphology with many degenerated and occasional viable inflammatory cells in necrotic background admixed with bacterial colonies. The morphology of cells is indiscernible

Impression: Peripancreatic fluid.: Inadequate for opinion

Advise: Clinical correlation

---

**Assessment Type:** Initial assessment
**Date:** 15-January-2026
**Study ID:** `AP-NSVT-008`

---

---

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| **Revised Atlanta Severity Grade** | [x] Severe |

- [ ] Perforation
- [ ] Intestinal obstruction
- [ ] Gastric outlet obstruction
- [ ] Fistula
- [ ] Ischemia
- [ ] Bleeding

- [ ] Splenic Vein
- [ ] Portal Vein

- [ ] Combined

### B. Imaging / Endoscopy

| Imaging | Date | Key Findings |
|---------|------|--------------|
| **USG W/A (Outside)** | 29-Oct-2025 | Hepatomegaly, Grade I-II fatty liver, mild splenomegaly, bilateral pleural effusion, GB sludge, features s/o acute pancreatitis |
| **CT (Outside)** | 27-Oct-2025 | Acute necrotizing pancreatitis with peripancreatic collection, Modified CTSI 8/10 |
| **CECT Chest + Abdomen** | 17-Nov-2025 | ANP with two intercommunicating collections at neck, body, tail; extending to lesser sac, perisplenic, paracolic gutter, mesentery, perinephric region; multiple air foci; **SV, PV, SMV PATENT - NO THROMBOSIS**; splenic infarct lower pole; moderate left pleural effusion |
| **NCCT Abdomen** | 21-Nov-2025 | No significant interval change; pigtail in situ; no colonic leak on rectal contrast |
| **NCCT Abdomen** | 24-Nov-2025 | No significant interval change from previous |
| **CT Angiography** | 22-Dec-2025 | Severe pancreatitis (CTSI 8/10) with acute necrotic collection pockets; **No thrombosis/narrowing involving spleno-mesenteric axis**; liver micro-abscesses; moderate left pleural effusion |

| **Portal Hypertension** | [x] Persistent (mild splenomegaly) |
| - Splenomegaly | Yes (mild) |
| - Collaterals/Cavernoma | No |
| - Esophagogastric varices | Not evaluated |
| - Portal Gastropathy | Not evaluated |

### Other Relevant Morbidity/Complications

- Disconnected Pancreatic Duct Syndrome (DPDS) - confirmed by high DFA (41,860 U/L)
- Walled-off necrosis with residual collections
- Severe anemia requiring blood transfusions (Hb dropped to 5.2 g/dL)
- Left pleural effusion (moderate)
- Liver micro-abscesses
- Small splenic infarct (lower pole)
- Hyponatremia (Na 127.5 mmol/L at admission)
- Hyperbilirubinemia at presentation (resolved)

---

## Summary

**Study ID:** AP-NSVT-008

**Classification:** **NON-SVT CASE**

**Key Points:**
1. 35-year-old male with severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis (Modified CTSI 8/10)
2. Etiology: Possible biliary (cholelithiasis noted) / Idiopathic
3. **NO SPLANCHNIC VENOUS THROMBOSIS documented on multiple CT scans including CT Angiography**
4. Splenic vein, Portal vein, SMV all explicitly documented as PATENT
5. Complicated course with:
   - Infected WOPN with DPDS
   - Small splenic infarct (lower pole)
   - Severe anemia requiring transfusions
   - Liver micro-abscesses
   - Left pleural effusion
6. Managed with PCD insertion and conservative treatment
7. Alive at discharge, PCD in situ

---

**Data Collected By:** Dr Sarath Chandrabhatla

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
Abdominal pain for 10 months
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Pt was apparently alright 10 months back when he noticed pain in abdomen (Index pain -March 2025),
epigastric region, aggravating with meals, associated with fever, vomiting (containing food particles) managed conservatively at Local
hospital, Sagar & later continue treatment at Bansal Hospital, Bhopal with insertion of PCD (Aug 25), removed within 5 days (pus
discharge, DFA- amylase 103769). Thereafter he had H/O UGI bleed in Oct 2025 (single episode, small volume), UGIE s/o Pangastritis.
Past h/o 3 times blood transfusion for low Hb. Outside MRCP s/o acute pancreatitis with multiple peripancreatic collections with renal
parenchymal disease with moderate splenomegaly. He ha also raised TLC-31,090. Patient visited to SGE OPD in Nov 2025, evaluated,
advised for MRI abdomen & MRCP & IVR consultation for drainage of collection, was not amenable for aspiration. He had persistent
raised TLC count (25,940, CRP-121) on next OPD visit, hence he admitted on 04/12/2025 for further evaluation & management. No
H/O jaundice/abdominal distension/anorexia/ weight loss. Patient had occasional cough. Past history: Previous interventions include
PCD insertion 4 months back (8/8/25). Pt is known case of CKD (diagnosed in 2023), not on hemodialysis, on T. Sodabicarb (stopped 1
week back). He had taken empirically ATT (6 months) for suspected abdominal kochs in 2024. Family history: no similar illness; no
DM/HTN/asthma/bleeding tendencies/cancers/TB. No known allergy.
CASE SUMMARY: Patient conscious oriented to time, place and person , fairly nourished.
No Edema/LN/clubbing/pallor/icterus are present.
Weight- 61.7 kg ,height- 173 cm, BMI- 20.6 kg/m2 ,
PR-110/min BP- 139/80 mmhg RR- 20 Spo2- 98% .
P/A - soft, non tender, non distended, no lump/organomegaly, drain scar present.
CHRONIC DISEASES:
Chronic kidney disease From .
CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and
motion, abdomen soft, non tender and hence being discharged in stable condition.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
Acute pancreatitis (Index pain- March 2025)


Intra & peripancreatic collections (Infected)


Sepsis

Chronic kidney disease


HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient was admitted in SGE ward for above mentioned complaints, necessary blood investigations were done (
Hb-8.7 TLC-16240, Plt-4.48L, CRP- 225, urea/creat-69/3.4 AST/ALT-35/21 , ALP/GGT-93/33, TP/Alb-6.8/2.9, PT/INR 16/1.3, T/D bilirubin
0.4/0.3 S.Na 129, S.K 5.5 & viral markers tested negative. Patient had multiple episodes of fever present (10/12/25) started on iv
antibiotics empirically (inj. Meropenem). VIR Consultation sought for drainage of peripancreatic collection (infected), was deemed not
amenable to aspiration. MRI abdomen & MRCP was planned for persistent sepsis, to assess local complications & collections (dated
on 22/12/2025). NCCT abdomen(13/12/25)- Pancreatitis with diffusely bulky pancreas with multiple peripancreatic fluid collections
involving: Pancreatic body. Gastrohepatic /segment IVA region, Right paracolic / transverse mesocolic region with moderate
splenomegaly with perisplenic collaterals & reviewed for CT guided aspiration which could not performed (attempted & failed) due to
inaccesible site. Gastromedicine consultation was sought i/v/o pancreatitis & PHTN for further management. USG SP axis showed
splenomegaly with mild dilated PV, no collaterals. Nephrology consultation was sought for assessment of CKD (creat./K- 2.4/4.6), USG
KUB & sepsis control advised. However, patient showed clinical improvement in response to intravenous antibiotics, with a
decreasing trend in TLC (12,840) and CRP (107). Review Nephrology consultation was sought to r/o cause of CKD (S.Urea/Creat.-
69/3.4), management of dyselectrolytemia (Na/k- 129/5.5) and advise followed. Hematology consultation was sought i/v/o severe
persistent anemia (Hb. 6.9), advised iron profile. 1 PRBC transfusion was done. Post BT CBC: Hb-7.5 WBC-12840 Plt-4.12L. ENT
consultation was sought i/v/o epistaxis (single episode) and advise followed. Labs at discharge: CBC: Hb 7.6 TLC 9790, Plt 4.62L, CRP-
50, Urea/creat: 61/2.3, Na/K-135/5.0. During hospital course, patient managed with iv antibiotics (Inj. Meropenem), IV PPI, IV
analgesic, IV antiemetics, and other symptomatic & supportive care. Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory,
afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and motion, abdomen soft, non tender and hence being discharged in stable condition.
OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: UGIE (30/7/25, Outside): GE JUNCTION : Lax LES (Hills Grade 3), ESOPHAGUS : NORMAL, No varices.
STOMACH -FUNDUS, BODY and ANTRUM: Mild erythema with congested mucosa, D1:NORMAL D2: NORMAL. IMPRESSION:
Pangastritis
UGIE (6/9/25, Outside): Lax LES (Hills Grade 3), ESOPHAGUS NORMAL, STOMACH-FUNDUS: NORMAL BODY: NORMAL ANTRUM
:NORMAL D1: NORMAL D2 : NORMAL
MRCP & abdomen 1/8/25, Outside: Pancreas shows mild diffuse increased T2 hyperintensity and fuzzy margin in tail region. It shows
small T2 hyperintense 1.6 x 1.4 x 1.3 cm size cyst, not showing diffusion restriction. Mild prominence of MPD in distal body and tail
region.Few small walled-off collection in peripancreatic region, largest one measuring 2.1 x 1.6 cm. Small walled-off T2 hyperintense
collection of size 4.4 x 3.8 x 2.6 cm seen along caudate lobe of liver. Mild T2 hyperintense fluid in perigastric and right perinephric
region. Imaging features are suggestive of pancreatitis with peripancreatic collections.
USG w/a 14/10/25: Liver - Normal, Gall bladder is munimally distended, Pancreas- Body and tail of pancreas shows ill defined
heterogenous hypoechoic area of size 3.0 x 2.3 cm, likely sequelae of previous pancreatitis. Portal vein is prominent measuring 12.6
cm Outside-Splenomegaly, b/l renal parenchymal disease.
USG w/a 31/10/25,Outside-Mild hepatomegaly. Mild spleenomegaly. Both kidney shows increased cortical echotexture with relatively
maintained cortico-medullary differentiation – Needs KFT evaluation. There is well defined, thick walled, heterogensouly hypoechoic
cystic lesion measuring 22 x 23 mm noted adjacent to the pancreatic head. No evidence of any vascularity within. Pancreatic head
and proximal part of body appears to be bulky with mild adjacent of fat stranding – Features suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst
formation with possibility of changes of pancreatitis – NEEDS CECT (A+P) correlation and serum amylase and lipase correlation.
Minimal ascites.

hypoechoic areas within. A small relatively defined hypoechoic collection measuring 17 x 18 x 17 mm noted in the body region of

NCCT abdomen(13/12/25)- Pancreatitis with diffusely bulky pancreas. Extensive peripancreatic inflammatory changes, Multiple
peripancreatic fluid collections involving: Pancreatic bodyGastrohepatic /segment IVA regionRight paracolic / transverse mesocolic
region.

(Adv: Contrast study for further evaluation). Moderate splenomegaly with perisplenic collaterals. Mild hepatomegaly with Beaver’s

Low fat renal diet with added salt

MRI abdomen (non contrast) + MRCP on 22/12/2025
Follow up in Nephrolog OPD for CKD
Review in SGE OPD In Pancreas clinic on thursday.

# Patient Proforma
## Department of Surgical Gastroenterology, AIIMS Bhopal
### Thesis Title: 'Analysis of Splanchnic Venous Thrombosis in Acute Pancreatitis: A Prospective Observational Study'

---

**Assessment Type:** Initial assessment
**Date:** 15-January-2026
**Study ID:** `AP-NSVT-007`

---

## 1. Demographics

| Field | Details |
|-------|---------|
| **Name** | [REDACTED_NAME] |
| **Age / Sex** | 22 years / Male |
| **CR No.** | [REDACTED_CR] |
| **Contact No.** | Data not available |
| **Address** | [REDACTED_ADDRESS] |
| **OPD/IPD** | IPD - Gastro Surgery Ward, Bed 3 |
| **Occupation** | Data not available |
| **Date of Admission** | 04-December-2025 |
| **Date of Discharge** | 18-December-2025 |
| **Weight / Height** | 61.7 kg / 173 cm |
| **BMI** | 20.6 kg/m² |
| **ASA Classification** | Data not available |

### Addictions

| Substance | Duration |
|-----------|----------|
| Alcohol | None documented |
| Smoking | None documented |
| Tobacco chewing | None documented |
| Others | None documented |

---

## 2. Clinical Details

### A. Pain in Abdomen

| Parameter | Details |
|-----------|---------|
| **Index pain** | March 2025 |
| **Current pain** | 10 months duration (epigastric, aggravating with meals) |
| **Duration** | Chronic/recurrent |
| **Site** | Epigastric |
| **Severity (VAS 1-10)** | Data not available |

### B. Other Features

| Feature | Present | Duration/Details |
|---------|---------|------------------|
| Vomiting | [x] Yes | Contains food particles |
| Fever | [x] Yes | Present during admission |
| Abdominal distension | [ ] No | - |
| Jaundice | [ ] No | - |
| Chest Pain | [ ] No | - |
| Dyspnoea | [ ] No | - |
| Hematemesis | [x] Yes | Single episode UGI bleed (Oct 2025, small volume) |
| Melena/Haematochezia | [ ] No | - |
| Ascites | [x] Yes | Mild |
| Splenomegaly | [x] Yes | Moderate (16 cm) |
| Cough | [x] Yes | Occasional |

---

## 3. Comorbidities

| Comorbidity | Present | Duration |
|-------------|---------|----------|
| DM | [ ] No | - |
| HTN | [ ] No | - |
| CAD | [ ] No | - |
| Obesity | [ ] No | - |
| COPD | [ ] No | - |
| CLD | [ ] No | - |
| Thyroid disorder | [ ] No | - |
| Known Coagulopathy Disorder | [ ] No | - |
| CKD | [x] Yes | Diagnosed 2023, not on hemodialysis (baseline Cr 2.3-3.4) |
| Other | [x] Yes | Prior ATT for suspected abdominal Koch's (6 months in 2024) |

---

## 4. Etiology of Acute Pancreatitis

**Etiology:** Idiopathic

---

## 5. Acute Pancreatitis

### Severity Score

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| **Revised Atlanta Severity Grade** | [x] Moderately Severe (infected collections, no persistent organ failure) |
| **Modified CT Severity Score** | Not formally calculated - diffusely bulky pancreas with multiple collections |

### Acute Pancreatitis Type

- [ ] Edematous (Interstitial)
- [x] Necrotizing (Acute-on-chronic pancreatitis with WON)

### Complications

#### GIT Complications
- [ ] Perforation
- [ ] Intestinal obstruction
- [ ] Gastric outlet obstruction
- [ ] Fistula
- [ ] Ischemia
- [x] Bleeding - Single episode UGI bleed (Oct 2025)
- [x] Other: Pangastritis, Lax LES (Hills Grade 3)

#### Vascular - Splanchnic

**Arterial - Pseudoaneurysm:** [ ] No

**Venous - Thrombosis:** [ ] No

- [ ] Splenic Vein
- [ ] Portal Vein
- [ ] Superior Mesenteric Vein
- [ ] Combined

**Note:** Perisplenic collaterals present but NO thrombosis documented in any splanchnic vessel

**Septicemia / Organ Failure:** [x] Yes - Pre-existing CKD (baseline Cr 2.3-3.4)

**Pancreatic Necrosis:** [x] Yes - Infected (WON with high DFA amylase 103,769)

---

## 6. Investigations

### A. Laboratory Investigations

| Test | 04-Dec-2025 | 06-Dec-2025 | 15-Dec-2025 (Discharge) |
|------|-------------|-------------|-------------------------|
| **Haemoglobin (g/dL)** | 6.9 | - | Transfused |
| **Total Leukocyte Count (K/µL)** | 9.66 | - | - |
| **Platelet (K/µL)** | 425 | - | - |
| **C-Reactive Protein (mg/L)** | - | 225 | 50 |
| **Bilirubin Total (mg/dL)** | - | 0.47 | - |
| **AST (U/L)** | - | 35.1 | - |
| **ALT (U/L)** | - | 21.2 | - |
| **ALP (U/L)** | - | 93.6 | - |
| **PT/INR** | - | 16.7/1.38 | - |
| **Serum Amylase (U/L)** | - | 657.59 | - |
| **Serum Lipase (U/L)** | - | 308.81 | - |
| **Serum Calcium (mg/dL)** | 9.87-10.28 | - | - |
| **Serum Urea (mg/dL)** | - | 69.7 | - |
| **Serum Creatinine (mg/dL)** | - | 3.40 | - |
| **Serum Sodium (mmol/L)** | - | 129.8 (LOW) | - |
| **Serum Potassium (mmol/L)** | - | 5.51 (HIGH) | - |
| **Procalcitonin (ng/mL)** | - | 0.759 | - |

**Peak CRP:** 225 mg/L (06-Dec-2025) → 50 mg/L at discharge

**Drain Fluid Amylase (Aug-2025 PCD):** 103,769 U/L (very high - confirms DPDS)

**Severe anemia:** Hb 6.6-7.6 g/dL requiring transfusion

### B. Imaging / Endoscopy

| Imaging | Date | Key Findings |
|---------|------|--------------|
| **MRCP (Outside)** | 01-Aug-2025 | Pancreatitis with peripancreatic collections, mild MPD prominence |
| **USG (Outside)** | 14-Oct-2025 | Sequelae of pancreatitis, pseudocyst 22x23mm, splenomegaly, PV 12.6 mm (dilated) |
| **USG AIIMS** | 05-Dec-2025 | Mild hepatomegaly, moderate splenomegaly, peripancreatic collection |
| **USG SP Axis** | 13-Dec-2025 | Splenomegaly, mild dilated PV, **no collaterals** |
| **NCCT Abdomen** | 13-Dec-2025 | Pancreatitis with bulky pancreas, multiple collections, splenomegaly 16cm, **perisplenic collaterals** |
| **MRCP** | 22-Dec-2025 | Acute-on-chronic pancreatitis, WON in mid-body and gastrohepatic region, hepatosplenomegaly, **perisplenic collaterals, NO SVT** |

### C. Endoscopy

| Procedure | Date | Findings |
|-----------|------|----------|
| **UGIE** | 30-Jul-2025 | Pangastritis, Lax LES (Hills Grade 3), **No varices** |
| **UGIE** | 06-Sep-2025 | Normal, Lax LES, **No varices** |

---

## Overall Imaging Findings

| # | Parameter | Finding/Details |
|---|-----------|-----------------|
| 1 | **Pancreas** | [x] Necrosis (Acute-on-chronic pancreatitis) |
| - | Necrosis location | Diffusely bulky with collections |
| - | Necrosis (%) | Not quantified |
| 2 | **Necrosis site** | [x] Both (Pancreatic + Extra-pancreatic) |
| 3 | **Peripancreatic fluid collection** | [x] Yes |
| 4 | **Pancreatic Fluid Collection** | Location: Mid-body, gastrohepatic region; Pseudocyst 22x23mm (Oct-2025) |
| 5 | **Walled-off necrosis** | [x] Yes - Multiple (mid-body, gastrohepatic region) |
| 6 | **Modified CTSI** | Not formally calculated |
| 7 | **Splanchnic vein thrombosis** | [x] **NO** |

### Splanchnic Venous Assessment

| Vessel | Status | Details |
|--------|--------|---------|
| **Portal Vein (PV)** | [x] Patent | Mildly dilated (12.6 mm), abutted by inflammatory node but **NO thrombosis** |
| - Extent | N/A | - |
| - Location | N/A | - |
| - Cavernous transformation | [ ] No | - |
| **Superior Mesenteric Vein (SMV)** | [x] Patent | Not specifically mentioned as thrombosed |
| - Extent | N/A | - |
| - Location | N/A | - |
| - Branch involvement | [ ] No | - |
| **Splenic Vein (SV)** | [x] Patent | Not specifically mentioned as thrombosed |
| - Extent | N/A | - |
| - Location | N/A | - |
| - Isolated SV thrombosis | [ ] No | - |
| **SMV-SV Confluence** | [x] Patent | Abutted by inflammatory node but no thrombosis |

### Portal Hypertensive Changes

| Finding | Present | Details |
|---------|---------|---------|
| Splenomegaly | [x] Yes | 16 cm (moderate) |
| Ascites | [x] Yes | Mild |
| Varices | [ ] None | UGIE (30/7/25 & 6/9/25): No varices |
| Collaterals | [x] Yes | Perisplenic collaterals on NCCT & MRCP |
| Portal Gastropathy | [ ] No | UGIE: Pangastritis only, no PHG |
| Others | [x] Yes | Portal hypertensive changes likely secondary to CKD/chronic inflammation rather than SVT |

### Vascular Complications

| Complication | Present | Details |
|--------------|---------|---------|
| Arterial pseudoaneurysm | [ ] No | - |
| Intra-abdominal bleeding | [ ] No | - |
| Bowel ischemia | [ ] No | - |
| Splenic infarction | [ ] No | - |

### Other Findings

| Finding | Present | Details |
|---------|---------|---------|
| Gall stones | [ ] No | - |
| CBD | Normal | 2.9 mm on MRCP |
| GI complications | [x] Yes | UGI bleed (Oct 2025), Pangastritis |
| Hepatomegaly | [x] Yes | Mild |

---

## 7. Management

### Conservative

- [ ] ICU admission
- [ ] Parenteral nutrition
- [ ] Ionotropic support
- [ ] Ventilator support
- [ ] Hemodialysis / CRRT
- [x] Other: Ward management, IV antibiotics, blood transfusion for severe anemia, CKD management

### Intervention

- [x] Yes

### Interventions Summary

| Intervention | Date | Indication | Outcome |
|--------------|------|------------|---------|
| PCD insertion (Outside) | Aug-2025 | Peripancreatic collection | Pus drained (DFA 103,769), removed in 5 days |
| CT-guided aspiration attempted | Dec-2025 | Infected collection | Failed - inaccessible site |

**Time to first intervention:** ~5 months from disease onset

### Anticoagulation Therapy

- [x] No (No SVT documented)

---

## 8. Outcomes

### Duration of Stay

| Parameter | Days |
|-----------|------|
| **ICU stay** | 0 |
| **Total hospital stay** | 14 days |

### Morbidity

1. **Organ failure:** [x] Yes
   - CKD (pre-existing, baseline Cr 2.3-3.4)
   - No new organ failure during admission

2. **Bowel ischemia:** [ ] No

3. **Bleeding:** [x] Yes
   - Single episode epistaxis (managed conservatively)
   - H/O UGI bleed (Oct 2025)

4. **Variceal bleeding:** [ ] No (No varices on UGIE)

5. **Splenic infarction:** [ ] No

6. **Bleeding on anticoagulation:** N/A (not on anticoagulation)

7. **Readmission:** To be determined

### Mortality

- [x] No

---

## 9. Follow-up

### Splanchnic Venous Thrombosis Assessment at Follow-up

**N/A - No SVT documented at any point**

**Key Finding:** Portal hypertensive changes (splenomegaly, perisplenic collaterals) present WITHOUT SVT - likely secondary to CKD and chronic inflammatory state

### Last Follow-up Date

- **Date:** 22-December-2025 (MRCP)
- **Duration since disease onset:** ~9 months
- **Planned follow-up:** SGE OPD Pancreas clinic, Nephrology follow-up for CKD

---

## 10. Status at Last Follow-up (18-Dec-2025 discharge)

| Parameter | Status |
|-----------|--------|
| **Vascular Status** | [x] Patent (all vessels) - No SVT documented |
| **Anticoagulation** | N/A - Not indicated |
| **Portal Hypertension** | [x] Present (likely from CKD/chronic inflammation, NOT SVT) |
| - Splenomegaly | Yes (16 cm) |
| - Collaterals/Cavernoma | Perisplenic collaterals (no cavernoma) |
| - Esophagogastric varices | None on UGIE |
| - Portal Gastropathy | None |

### Other Relevant Morbidity/Complications

- Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) - baseline Creatinine 2.3-3.4
- Chronic/Recurrent pancreatitis (acute-on-chronic)
- Walled-off necrosis (not amenable to drainage)
- Severe anemia (Hb 6.6-7.6) requiring transfusion
- Hyponatremia (Na 129.8)
- Hyperkalemia (K 5.51)
- History of ATT for suspected abdominal Koch's
- Pangastritis with Lax LES (Hills Grade 3)

---

## Summary

**Study ID:** AP-NSVT-007

**Classification:** **NON-SVT CASE**

**Key Points:**
1. 22-year-old male with moderately severe acute-on-chronic pancreatitis
2. Etiology: Idiopathic
3. **NO SPLANCHNIC VENOUS THROMBOSIS documented**
4. **CRITICAL FINDING: Portal hypertensive changes (splenomegaly, perisplenic collaterals) WITHOUT SVT**
5. Portal vein mildly dilated but PATENT (no thrombosis)
6. SMV and SV not specifically thrombosed
7. Perisplenic collaterals present but NO vascular occlusion
8. Portal hypertension likely secondary to CKD and chronic inflammatory state
9. Complicated by:
   - Chronic Kidney Disease (not on dialysis)
   - Severe anemia requiring transfusion
   - Electrolyte imbalances (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia)
   - Walled-off necrosis (not amenable to PCD)
   - History of UGI bleed (Oct 2025)
10. UGIE confirmed NO varices despite portal hypertensive changes
11. Discharged in stable condition without anticoagulation

**CRITICAL RESEARCH NOTE:**
This patient demonstrates an important distinction - **PORTAL HYPERTENSIVE CHANGES WITHOUT SVT**. Despite having splenomegaly (16 cm) and perisplenic collaterals, NO splanchnic venous thrombosis was documented. This highlights that:
- Portal hypertension can occur without SVT in pancreatitis
- CKD and chronic inflammatory states can contribute to portal hypertensive changes
- Collaterals may develop from causes other than SVT
- Absence of varices on endoscopy despite collaterals on imaging
- Young age (22 years) with idiopathic pancreatitis and CKD

---

**Data Collected By:** Dr Sarath Chandrabhatla
**Last Updated:** 15-January-2026

![](_page_0_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_0_Picture_3.jpeg) # Department : Surgical Gastroenterology Discharge Summary | CR No.: 239212501755710 | Name: Rajesh Deshmukh | Age/Gender: 28 Yr/M | |--------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------| | Admission No.: 239212025039135 | Department Unit: Surgical Gastroenterology (Surgical
Gastroenterology) | Consultant/Faculty: Dr Vishal Gupta | | Ward: Gastro Surgery Ward | Room/Bed: Gastro Srg Ward Room/ Bed 5 | Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat | | Discharge Type: On request | Father/Spouse Name: Sahebrao/- | Occupation: | | Contact No.: 9993184231 | Address:,,,Bhopal | State/Country Madhya | | | | Pradesh/India | | D.O.A. : 29-Jun-2025 07:07 | D.O.D. : 14-Aug-2025 | D.O. Print Report: 14-Aug-2025 10:51 | # CHIEF COMPLAINTS: Pain abdomen x 1 day Urinary retention x 1 day Fever x 1 day HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient presented in TEM, AIIMS Bhopal with pain abdomen for 1 day (diffuse and continuous in nature partially relieved with analgesics and exaggerated following food intake). It was associated with urinary retention and low grade fever for 1 day. No h/o obstipation/vomiting. He is a known case of severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis ( date of pain May 24, 2025; alcohol induced). He was admitted for this at a private hospital in Nagpur( 25-5-2025- 7/6/2025). He was initially intubated and managed in ICU and later shifted to ward. During hospital course he developed AKI ( managed with dialysis twice) alcohol withdrawal (managed conservatively) and was discharged in stable condition. No h/o melena, jaundice, hematemesis, hematochezia. He is a known alcoholic and tobacco chewer x 15 years. He was recently diagnosed with DM (not on any medications). No other comorbidities or allergies. CASE SUMMARY: The patient is conscious and oriented. Pallor present/ abdominal wall edema, scrotal edema and B/L lower limb edema present. No icterus, cyanosis, clubbing, lymphadenopathy. Weight- 45.5kg, height- 166cm, BMI- 16.5 kg/m2. PR-110/min BP- 85/53 mmhg RR-18 Spo2- 99 % (RA) P/A: Distension (Central & Lower) ,soft, non tender. Palpable bowel loops present, no guarding or rigidity, and no evidence of ascites or palpable lump. P/R: Anal tone is normal. Fecal staining is present. CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and motion, abdomen soft, wound healthy & granulating with thick pus discharge from one point in midline wound, pigtail and FJ in situ, non tender, stoma healthy and functional. Being discharged on request in stable condition. C D grade 2 ### FINAL DIAGNOSIS: Severe Acute Necrotising Pancreatitis Walled of necrosis Ascending colon perforation ![](_page_1_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_1_Picture_3.jpeg) b/l pleural effusion Surgical site infection with wound dehiscence Hyponatremia; Anemia; HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient presented with above mentioned complaints to TEM, AIIMS Bhopal on 27th June 2025 and was admitted for further evaluation. Routine Labs were send (CBC – Hb – 8.2, TLC – 8030, Plt – 3.5L ,Urea/Creat – 10/0.79 , Na/K – 135/4.3 , Bil– 0.69/0.20 , SGOT /SGPT – 23/10 ALP/GGT – 236/191 , PT/INR – 14/1.21, Prot/alb – 6.6/3.1 Viral Markers – Non Reactive), Gastrosurgery reference was received from TEM, and advice was given. CECT abdomen (30/06/25) showed pneumoperitoneum and ANP. In view of bowel perforation, patient was shifted to SGE HDU on next day. After taking high risk consent, he underwent emergency sx on 1st July 2025. Intra op period was uneventful; was intubated and shifted to SICU with ionotropic support. He was extubated on POD 2 and he had serous discharge from main wound. He had purulent high output from all the 3 drains in immediate post-op which gradually decreased in volume from POD 6. He was started on fluconazole in view of growth of yeast in ET aspirate and urine culture. He developed b/l pleural effusion and was managed conservatively after pulmo cx. His RT output started decreasing from POD 6, stoma became functional and was started on FJ feed trial, which he tolerated. He was shifted to SGE HDU on POD 6. He started having peridrain feculent soakage over the right ADK and later feculent output from right ADK. CECT was done, and it confirmed a leak of contrast through the colon repair site. The leak was contained, was managed conservatively; He developed wound dehiscence on POD 7 with purulent discharge and was managed conservatively. Cotrimoxazole and Vancomycin were started from POD 8 based on cultures. RT was removed on POD 8 and orals was started and increased as per tolerance. Left perisplenic drain removed on POD 11. Left pelvic drain was removed on POD 20. In view of anaemia despite multiple blood transfusions, a hematology cx was taken on POD 26 and advice was followed. He had elevated counts on POD 27 ( TLC-14590), along with persistent purulent discharge from right ADK; antibiotics was upgraded to piptaz and CT was done on POD 31; showed persistent defect in colon and multiple peripancreatic collections. On POD 39, CT guided pigtail was placed into peripancreatic collection, and thick pus was drained. He started having persistent hyponatremia and was managed conservatively. During hospital course, patient managed with iv & oral antibiotics (cefaperazone sulbactum, piperacillin tazobactum, meropenem, metronidazole, Cotrimoxazole, Fluconazole, Vancomycin, levofloxacin), iv PPI, iv antipyretics, Iv antiemetics, iv diclofenac, symptomatic & supportive care. Labs at discharge (CBC-8.5/12030/3.73L). Patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and motion, abdomen soft, wound healthy & granulating with pus discharge from single point, pigtail in situ, stoma healthy, non tender. Patient is being discharged in stable condition on request. OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: USG W/A outside 22/05/25: Liver parenchymal disease. Acute pancreatitis, minimal interbowel fluid. USG W/A outside 2/6/25): Bulky & heterogenous pancreas. Ill-defined peripancreatic increased echogenicity& collection S/o acute edematous interstitial pancreatitis. Mild coarse liver echotexture & periportal cuffing. Splenomegaly. Gross ascites. USG W/A outside 21/6/25): Liver parenchymal disease, acute pancreatitis, mild splenomegaly. B/L Grade 1° Renal parenchymal disease. Mild ascites. Changes of chronic cystitis? USG W/A outside 24/6/25): Acute necrotizing pancreatitis shows with thick collections, mild ascites. Hepatosplenomegaly. Raised B/L Renal echogenicity. CT Scan NCCT (25/5/25) Outside :Pancreas enlarged, peripancreatic fat stranding, mild peripancreatic fluid. No obvious pseudocyst. MPD not dilated. Significant fat stranding in mesentery. Mild ascites. CECT - Abdomen 14/6/25) outside: Pancreas mildly bulky. Peripancreatic fat stranding. Thin walled peripancreatic collection 12 x 7 x 10 cm. PV at confluence narrowed. No obvious thrombus. Rest PV & SV normal. Mild ascites. GB no calculi seen. ![](_page_2_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_2_Picture_3.jpeg) CECT Abdomen (30/6/2025 AIIMS): Gross non – dependent intraperitoneal free air noted. Gross intraperitoneal free fluid noted extending in the perihepatic , perisplenic, peripancreatic , interbowel, bilateral paracolic gutter and pelvis.The caecum, ascending colon and proximal third of the transverse colon appear collapsed with enhancing mucosa and edematous bowel walls. Focal thinning is noted in the anterior wall of caecum with few tiny air foci adjacent to it. On positive rectal contrast administration ,no obvious extravasation of contrast is noted into the peritoneal cavity. Pancreatic shows fuzzy margins and loss of pancreatic lobulations with heterogeneity noted in the neck region. Ill-defined areas of non-enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collections noted in the peripancreatic region as described, suggestive of ANC (Acute necrotic collection): The largest collection (10.4 x 9.8 x 8.5 cm) extending from the lesser sac between the neck and body of pancreas and the body of stomach and extending inferiorly till the level of transverse colon and is surrounding the distal third of transverse colon. Another collection measuring ~ 8 x 2 x 4.4 cm is noted along the posterior body and tail of pancreas extending till the splenic hilum. Moderate inflammatory changes are noted in the form of fat stranding in the peripancreatic region, along pyloro-duodenal junction (with associated mild edematous wall thickening), 1st and 2nd part of duodenum, left anterior para-renal space and in mesenteric region. There is thickening of left anterior renal fascia and left lateral conal fascia. No evidence of parenchymal or ductal calcification noted. Splenic vein is normal in diameter~ 8.6 mm, shows normal contrast opacification with no intra-luminal filling defect. Portal vein shows normal contrast opacification. Biopsy (2/7/2025) : Excision of tissue from ascending colon perforation margins: Consistent with Perforation Peritonitis CECT Abdomen (8/7/25 AIIMS): Mild amount of free fluid in the anterior peritoneal cavity of left periumbilical region with few air foci noted. A stoma noted in the right iliac fossa with exteriorized collapsed ileal loops. Feeding jejunostomy tube noted entering through the left lumbar region with its tip in the proximal jejunum. Three post op drain tubes are noted with their tips in right subhepatic region, left perisplenic region and pelvic cavity respectively.Pancreatic parenchyma appears diffusely thinned predominantly at neck, shows fuzzy margins and loss of pancreatic lobulations with hypo enhancement of distal body and tail. Irregular shaped peripherally enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collection with internal fat debris noted in the peripancreatic region and lesser sac It measures 11.2 x 5.9 x 9.9 cm and is seen extending from the infrahepatic region (near segment IV), abutting the body of stomach and extending inferiorly till the hepatic flexure at the level of ileostomy. No evidence of aneurysmal dilatation of GDA/ Splenic artery. Normal contrast opacification of splenoportal confluence and its branches. There is a defect of size 1.3cm in the anterior wall of caecum with contrast (via distal loop) leak with extraluminal air foci in the right paracolic gutter tracking towards the pelvic cavity. CECT (1/8/25)(AIIMS) ABDOMEN : Mild amount of free fluid in the anterior peritoneal cavity of left periumbilical region with few air foci noted. A stoma noted in the right iliac fossa. Feeding jejunostomy tube noted entering through the leftlumbar region with its tip in the proximal jejunum. A post op drain tube noted with its tip in right subhepatic region Pancreas: Pancreatic parenchyma appears diffusely thinned predominantly at neck, shows fuzzy margins and loss of pancreatic lobulations with heterogeneous enhancement of distal body and tail. An irregular shaped peripherally enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collection with internal fat debris noted in the peripancreatic region and lesser sac . It measures 11.2 x 6.0 x 9.9 cm and is seen extending from the infra-hepatic region (near segment IV), abutting the body of stomach, and extending inferiorly till the hepatic flexure at the level of ileostomy. Another irregular hypodense collection approximately measuring 5.1x6.1x15.2cm in its maximum orthogonal dimensions is noted in the left anterior pararenal space which is inferiorly tracking along left paracolic gutter and extending along the left lateral conal fascia and a thin streak is noted tracking along the parietal peritoneum in the pelvic region. .No evidence of aneurysmal dilatation of GDA/ Splenic artery. Normal contrast opacification of spleno-portal confluence and its branches. On positive contrast administration in the distal loop, there is contrast extravasation noted through a defect of 10mm in the anterior wall of the ascending colon which is seen extending and reaching till the side wall of the drain. Minimal suspicious opacification of the drain at this site is noted, however no further intra-peritoneal leak noted. The findings could represent the possibility of walled off cavity. Intraop C/S (2/7/2025) K. pneumoniae- Sen - cotrimoxazole, Enterococcus fecium - Sen -linezolid; ET aspirate (2/7/205) - budding yeast; blood c/s( 2/7/2025)- S. hemolyticus Sen- Teicoplanin, clindamycin, vancomycin. Central line tip c/s- S. epidermidis, sen doxycycline, moxifloxacin, vancomycin, clindamycin. Wound fluid amylase(12/7/25)- 86.3 Wound pus swab c/s- K pneumoniae, sen cotrimoxazole, minocycline ![](_page_3_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_3_Picture_3.jpeg) ## OPERATION PERFORMED: Exploratory laprotomy with adhesiolysis with limited necrosectomy with ascending colon perforation primary repair with diversion ileostomy with feeding jejunostomy On 01-Jul-2025 SURGEONS: Dr Pravesh Mathur ASSISTANT SURGEON/SENIOR RESIDENT: Dr Gourav (SR), Dr Sarath (SR) Technicians/Nurses: Omaram, Laxman, Sohan OPERATIVE FINDINGS: 1 L pus & enteric fluid drained (sent for c/s). Interbowel adhesions present & small bowel densely adherent in right iliac fossa region & at DJ flexure region. Bowel is inflamed &edematous with pus flakes throughout the bowel.Jejunal segment adherent at extra pancreatic collections in DJ flexure region & pancreatic head in infracolic area.Large ascending colon perforation(size-2 x 2cm) found. Multiple serosal tears found over the smallbowel. Organized extra pancreatic solid necrotic collection (sent for fungal culture) present in lesser sac around pancreas bulging into infracolic compartment at head & tail part of pancreas. ### ADVICE ON DISCHARGE: Low fat high protein diet. Tab cotrimoxazole (800/160 mg) BD x 7 days T. Omeprazole 20 mg OD BBF x 7 days T. Iron + Folic acid 1 Tab OD x 7 days T. Paracetamol 650mg SOS x 7 days Syp MVI 2 tsp BD x 7 days Protein powder 2 TSF BD in 10ml of water to be continued Follow up in General medicine & hematology OPD for hyponatremia & anemia Follow up in SGE OPD in pancreas clinic on Thursday PCD catheter care as advised & strict PCD charting 24 hrly. Wound dressing and care as advised DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta DISCHARGE REMARKS : FOLLOW UP ON : 14-Aug-2025 FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Vishal Gupta FOLLOW UP ADVICE : To consult in TEM, AIIMS Bhopal/Nearby hospital in case of emergencies like persistent abdominal pain/distension/vomiting/fever/stoma complications/Drain dislodgement/ blood in PCD catheter etc. Summary Prepared By Summary Approved By Dr Basil Babu Dr Vishal Gupta

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
Pain abdomen x 1 day
Urinary retention x 1 day
Fever x 1 day
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient presented in TEM, AIIMS Bhopal with pain abdomen for 1 day (diffuse and continuous in
nature partially relieved with analgesics and exaggerated following food intake). It was associated with urinary retention and low
grade fever for 1 day. No h/o obstipation/vomiting. He is a known case of severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis ( date of pain May 24,
2025; alcohol induced). He was admitted for this at a private hospital in Nagpur( 25-5-2025- 7/6/2025). He was initially intubated and
managed in ICU and later shifted to ward. During hospital course he developed AKI ( managed with dialysis twice) alcohol withdrawal
(managed conservatively) and was discharged in stable condition. No h/o melena, jaundice, hematemesis, hematochezia. He is a
known alcoholic and tobacco chewer x 15 years. He was recently diagnosed with DM (not on any medications). No other
comorbidities or allergies.
CASE SUMMARY: The patient is conscious and oriented.
Pallor present/ abdominal wall edema, scrotal edema and B/L lower limb edema present. No icterus, cyanosis, clubbing,
lymphadenopathy.
Weight- 45.5kg, height- 166cm, BMI- 16.5 kg/m2.
PR-110/min BP- 85/53 mmhg RR-18 Spo2- 99 % (RA)
P/A: Distension (Central & Lower) ,soft, non tender. Palpable bowel loops present, no guarding or rigidity, and no evidence of ascites
or palpable lump.
P/R: Anal tone is normal. Fecal staining is present.
CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and
motion, abdomen soft, wound healthy & granulating with thick pus discharge from one point in midline wound, pigtail and FJ in situ,
non tender, stoma healthy and functional. Being discharged on request in stable condition. C D grade 2
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
Severe Acute Necrotising Pancreatitis


Walled of necrosis


Ascending colon perforation




                                                                                                                               Page No: 1

                                                                                            CR: 239212501755710




b/l pleural effusion


Surgical site infection with wound dehiscence


Hyponatremia;


Anemia;


HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient presented with above mentioned complaints to TEM, AIIMS Bhopal on 27th June 2025 and was admitted
for further evaluation. Routine Labs were send (CBC ��� Hb ��� 8.2, TLC ��� 8030, Plt ��� 3.5L ,Urea/Creat ��� 10/0.79 ,
Na/K ��� 135/4.3 , Bil��� 0.69/0.20 , SGOT /SGPT ��� 23/10 ALP/GGT ��� 236/191 , PT/INR ��� 14/1.21, Prot/alb ���
6.6/3.1 Viral Markers ��� Non Reactive), Gastrosurgery reference was received from TEM, and advice was given. CECT abdomen
(30/06/25) showed pneumoperitoneum and ANP. In view of bowel perforation, patient was shifted to SGE HDU on next day. After
taking high risk consent, he underwent emergency sx on 1st July 2025. Intra op period was uneventful; was intubated and shifted to
SICU with ionotropic support. He was extubated on POD 2 and he had serous discharge from main wound. He had purulent high
output from all the 3 drains in immediate post-op which gradually decreased in volume from POD 6. He was started on fluconazole in
view of growth of yeast in ET aspirate and urine culture. He developed b/l pleural effusion and was managed conservatively after
pulmo cx. His RT output started decreasing from POD 6, stoma became functional and was started on FJ feed trial, which he
tolerated. He was shifted to SGE HDU on POD 6. He started having peri-drain feculent soakage over the right ADK and later feculent
output from right ADK. CECT was done, and it confirmed a leak of contrast through the colon repair site. The leak was contained, was
managed conservatively; He developed wound dehiscence on POD 7 with purulent discharge and was managed conservatively.
Cotrimoxazole and Vancomycin were started from POD 8 based on cultures. RT was removed on POD 8 and orals was started and
increased as per tolerance. Left perisplenic drain removed on POD 11. Left pelvic drain was removed on POD 20. In view of anaemia
despite multiple blood transfusions, a hematology cx was taken on POD 26 and advice was followed. He had elevated counts on POD
27 ( TLC-14590), along with persistent purulent discharge from right ADK; antibiotics was upgraded to piptaz and CT was done on
POD 31; showed persistent defect in colon and multiple peripancreatic collections. On POD 39, CT guided pigtail was placed into
peripancreatic collection, and thick pus was drained. He started having persistent hyponatremia and was managed conservatively.
During hospital course, patient managed with iv & oral antibiotics (cefaperazone sulbactum, piperacillin tazobactum, meropenem,
metronidazole, Cotrimoxazole, Fluconazole, Vancomycin, levofloxacin), iv PPI, iv antipyretics, Iv antiemetics, iv diclofenac,
symptomatic & supportive care. Labs at discharge (CBC-8.5/12030/3.73L). Patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile,
tolerating orals, passing flatus and motion, abdomen soft, wound healthy & granulating with pus discharge from single point, pigtail
in situ, stoma healthy, non tender. Patient is being discharged in stable condition on request.
OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: USG W/A outside 22/05/25: Liver parenchymal disease. Acute pancreatitis, minimal interbowel fluid.
USG W/A outside 2/6/25): Bulky & heterogenous pancreas. Ill-defined peripancreatic increased echogenicity& collection S/o acute
edematous interstitial pancreatitis. Mild coarse liver echotexture & periportal cuffing. Splenomegaly. Gross ascites.
USG W/A outside 21/6/25): Liver parenchymal disease, acute pancreatitis, mild splenomegaly. B/L Grade 1�� Renal parenchymal
disease. Mild ascites. Changes of chronic cystitis?
USG W/A outside 24/6/25): Acute necrotizing pancreatitis shows with thick collections, mild ascites. Hepatosplenomegaly. Raised B/L
Renal echogenicity.
CT Scan NCCT (25/5/25) Outside :Pancreas enlarged, peripancreatic fat stranding, mild peripancreatic fluid. No obvious pseudocyst.
MPD not dilated. Significant fat stranding in mesentery. Mild ascites.
CECT - Abdomen 14/6/25) outside: Pancreas mildly bulky. Peripancreatic fat stranding. Thin walled peripancreatic collection 12 x 7 x
10 cm. PV at confluence narrowed. No obvious thrombus. Rest PV & SV normal. Mild ascites. GB ��� no calculi seen.




                                                                                                                                Page No: 2

                                                                                              CR: 239212501755710




CECT Abdomen (30/6/2025 AIIMS): Gross non ��� dependent intraperitoneal free air noted. Gross intraperitoneal free fluid noted
extending in the perihepatic , perisplenic, peripancreatic , interbowel, bilateral paracolic gutter and pelvis.The caecum, ascending
colon and proximal third of the transverse colon appear collapsed with enhancing mucosa and edematous bowel walls. Focal
thinning is noted in the anterior wall of caecum with few tiny air foci adjacent to it. On positive rectal contrast administration ,no
obvious extravasation of contrast is noted into the peritoneal cavity. Pancreatic shows fuzzy margins and loss of pancreatic
lobulations with heterogeneity noted in the neck region. Ill-defined areas of non-enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collections
noted in the peripancreatic region as described, suggestive of ANC (Acute necrotic collection): The largest collection (10.4 x 9.8 x 8.5
cm) extending from the lesser sac between the neck and body of pancreas and the body of stomach and extending inferiorly till the
level of transverse colon and is surrounding the distal third of transverse colon. Another collection measuring ~ 8 x 2 x 4.4 cm is
noted along the posterior body and tail of pancreas extending till the splenic hilum. Moderate inflammatory changes are noted in the
form of fat stranding in the peripancreatic region, along pyloro-duodenal junction (with associated mild edematous wall thickening),
1st and 2nd part of duodenum, left anterior para-renal space and in mesenteric region. There is thickening of left anterior renal fascia
and left lateral conal fascia. No evidence of parenchymal or ductal calcification noted. Splenic vein is normal in diameter~ 8.6 mm,
shows normal contrast opacification with no intra-luminal filling defect. Portal vein shows normal contrast opacification.
Biopsy (2/7/2025) : Excision of tissue from ascending colon perforation margins: Consistent with Perforation Peritonitis
CECT Abdomen (8/7/25 AIIMS): Mild amount of free fluid in the anterior peritoneal cavity of left periumbilical region with few air foci
noted. A stoma noted in the right iliac fossa with exteriorized collapsed ileal loops. Feeding jejunostomy tube noted entering through
the left lumbar region with its tip in the proximal jejunum. Three post op drain tubes are noted with their tips in right subhepatic
region, left perisplenic region and pelvic cavity respectively.Pancreatic parenchyma appears diffusely thinned predominantly at neck,
shows fuzzy margins and loss of pancreatic lobulations with hypo enhancement of distal body and tail. Irregular shaped peripherally
enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collection with internal fat debris noted in the peripancreatic region and lesser sac It
measures 11.2 x 5.9 x 9.9 cm and is seen extending from the infrahepatic region (near segment IV), abutting the body of stomach and
extending inferiorly till the hepatic flexure at the level of ileostomy. No evidence of aneurysmal dilatation of GDA/ Splenic artery.
Normal contrast opacification of splenoportal confluence and its branches. There is a defect of size 1.3cm in the anterior wall of
caecum with contrast (via distal loop) leak with extraluminal air foci in the right paracolic gutter tracking towards the pelvic cavity.
CECT (1/8/25)(AIIMS) ABDOMEN : Mild amount of free fluid in the anterior peritoneal cavity of left periumbilical region with few air
foci noted. A stoma noted in the right iliac fossa. Feeding jejunostomy tube noted entering through the leftlumbar region with its tip
in the proximal jejunum. A post op drain tube noted with its tip in right subhepatic region Pancreas: Pancreatic parenchyma appears
diffusely thinned predominantly at neck, shows fuzzy margins and loss of pancreatic lobulations with heterogeneous enhancement of
distal body and tail. An irregular shaped peripherally enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collection with internal fat debris noted
in the peripancreatic region and lesser sac . It measures 11.2 x 6.0 x 9.9 cm and is seen extending from the infra-hepatic region (near
segment IV), abutting the body of stomach, and extending inferiorly till the hepatic flexure at the level of ileostomy. Another irregular
hypodense collection approximately measuring 5.1x6.1x15.2cm in its maximum orthogonal dimensions is noted in the left anterior
pararenal space which is inferiorly tracking along left paracolic gutter and extending along the left lateral conal fascia and a thin
streak is noted tracking along the parietal peritoneum in the pelvic region. .No evidence of aneurysmal dilatation of GDA/ Splenic
artery. Normal contrast opacification of spleno-portal confluence and its branches. On positive contrast administration in the distal
loop, there is contrast extravasation noted through a defect of 10mm in the anterior wall of the ascending colon which is seen
extending and reaching till the side wall of the drain. Minimal suspicious opacification of the drain at this site is noted, however no
further intra-peritoneal leak noted. The findings could represent the possibility of walled off cavity.
Intraop C/S (2/7/2025) K. pneumoniae- Sen - cotrimoxazole, Enterococcus fecium - Sen -linezolid; ET aspirate (2/7/205) - budding
yeast; blood c/s( 2/7/2025)- S. hemolyticus Sen- Teicoplanin, clindamycin, vancomycin. Central line tip c/s- S. epidermidis, sen -
doxycycline, moxifloxacin, vancomycin, clindamycin. Wound fluid amylase(12/7/25)- 86.3 Wound pus swab c/s- K pneumoniae, sen -
cotrimoxazole, minocycline

adherent at extra pancreatic collections in DJ flexure region & pancreatic head in infracolic area.Large ascending colon
perforation(size-2 x 2cm) found. Multiple serosal tears found over the smallbowel. Organized extra pancreatic solid necrotic collection

PCD catheter care as advised & strict PCD charting 24 hrly.
Wound dressing and care as advised

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
Pus discharge from previous drain site x 1 week
Generalized weakness x 1 week
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient is f/u/c/o severe acute necrotising pancreatitis with WON with ascending colon perforation s/p
exp lap with limited necrosectomy with ascending colon perforation primary repair with diversion ileostomy with FJ (01/07/25). He
presented with c/o pus discharge from previous drain site. He had occasionally abdominal pain and c/o generalised weakness. No
fever/vomiting/Abd. Fullness. He had developed an abscess in left inguinal region , I & D was done at a local hospital on 30/8/25. He
also had dribbling of urine 1 week back and he visited to TEM, AIIMS Bhopal (Acute urinary retention) and perurethral catheterisation
was done. Now he c/o generalised weakness & purulent discharge from previous drain site & midline wound. No known medical co-
morbidities, H/O surgical intervention- Exp. Lap + ascending colon perforation primary repair + ileostomy +FJ (1/7/25). Sleep cycle ,
Bowel & bladder habit normal. No similar history & c/o of DM/HTN/Asthma/Bleeding tendencies/cancers.H/O alcohol and tobacco
chewing x 10 years. No known allergies
CASE SUMMARY: Patient conscious oriented to time, place and person. Pallor/icterus/edema, LN/clubbing is absent. Weight- 45kg,
height- 172cm, BMI- 14.5 kg/m2 PR-102/min BP- 126/88 mmhg Spo2- 98% . O/E- NVBS +, B/L A/E +. P/a-soft, non-distended, non-
tender No guarding, stoma functional & healthy. Pus discharge from left drain site, I and D site & mid line wound.
CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Currently he is hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral diet, stoma healthy and functional. FJ in situ.
Minimal pus discharge from midline wound present.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
Hyponatremia;


Iron deficiency anemia;


F/u/c/o severe scute necrotising pancreatitis with walled oof necrosis with ascending colon perforation s/p Exploratory laparotomy
with limited necrosectomy with ascending colon perforation site repair with diversion loop ileostomy with FJ(1/7/2025)


HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient presented with above mentioned complaints to SGE OPD, AIIMS Bhopal on 4th September 2025 and was
admitted for further evaluation, Routine Labs were send (CBC – Hb – 8.7 TLC – 15550, Plt – 4.8L , Blood Urea/Creat – 17/0.6 , Na/K –
117/4.2 , T.Bilirubin/D.Bilirubin – 0.4/0.1, SGOT /SGPT – 12/7 ALP/GGT – 172/90 , PT/INR – 13/1.1, Total Protein/Albumin – 5.7/3 Viral
Markers – Non Reactive). He was started on iv antibiotics and daily dressing of his abdominal wound was done. He had anemia and
hyponatremia on admission and medicine and hematology opinions were taken for the same. Blood and urine tests were done as per
their advice and reports are awaited. USG whole abdomen was done on 6/9/2025 and it did not reveal any abdominal collections.
NCCT abdomen was also done on 8/9/2025 and reported collection with air foci near pancreatic head. On 8/ 9/2025 antibiotics was




                                                                                                                                Page No: 1

                                                                                              CR: 239212501755710




changed to amikacin based on culture sensitivity from wound. On 9/9/2025, there was spontaneous pus discharge ( around 30 ml)
from just above the midline healed wound scar following which his midline soakage of wound decreased. Pus discharge from drain
site and previous I and D site also decreased. Hematology review was taken and was advised to start erythropoietin and parenteral
iron in view of iron deficiency anemia. Currently he is hemodynamically stable, tolerating oral diet, stoma healthy and functional.
Minimal pus discharge from midline wound present. During hospital course, patient managed with iv antibiotics (Tigecycline,
Amikacin), iv PPI, iv analgecis, iv antiemetics, symptomatic & supportive care. Patient improved on conservative management with
normalised TLC & improved Na. Labs at the time of discharge (11/9/2025) CBC-12.7/7003/2.77l, Na-130/ K-4.7
OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: USG W/A 6/9/25, AIIMS; No e/o free fluid in peritoneal cavity, atrophic pancreas.
NCCT 9-9-2025 (AIIMS) : Pancreatic head and body proximal body not visualized and replaced by is a relatively well defined
hypodense collection with few air attenuating densities noted in, it is measuring
approx. 5.9 x 3.6 x 6 cm , noted in the para midline location of epigastrium region , with peri collection fat stranding , laterally the
collection is seen extending into the right paracolic gutter. Superiorly, it is close proximity to the pylorus of stomach, with a liner
hypodense tract noted extending superiorly from the collection , extending to the abdominal surface in midline, suggestive of
intraabdominal collection.
A relatively defined collection is also seen in left iliac fossa region, measuring approx. 2.3 x 4.5 cm. Minimal perihepatic and peri
splenic free fluid noted. Minimal right pleural effusion noted.
7-9-2025 :Serum Iron 18.83 micro g/dL (70 - 180); UIBC 114.43 μg/dL (155 - 355);Serum Iron 18.83 μg/dL (70 - 180); TIBC 133.26 μg/dL
(250 - 400) ;Transferrin Saturation Percentage 14.13 % (10 - 50)
Pus c/s (5-9-2025): Providencia stuartii sen: Amikacin, Cefepime, Piperacillin + Tazobactum




ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:
High protein salt added diet; Tab Pantoprazole 40 mg od x 7 days; Tab paracetamol 500 mg sos x 7 days; Tab Iron+ Folic acid 1 tab od
x15 days; Cap B complex 1 capsule od x 15 days; T vit C 500 mg od x 15 days; Midline wound dressing and care and Stoma care as
advised.
To get Inj Erythropoetin 4000 units SC once weekly for 1 month as per hemotology advice.
Inj Ferric carboxymaltose 500 mg in 100 ml NS over 1 hr once weekly x 2 doses as per hemotology advice.
Follow up in hematology OPD for management of anemia.
Follow up in medicine OPD for management of hyponatremia.
DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta
DISCHARGE REMARKS :
FOLLOW UP ON : 18-Sep-2025
FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Vishal Gupta
FOLLOW UP ADVICE : To visit TEM AIIMS or local hospital in case of pain abdomen, vomiting, nil output from stoma etc.

   ●MPA, right, and left PA appear unremarkable. No evidence of any thrombo-embolism is
    noted.
IMPRESSION– In a k/c/o severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis with ascending colon perforation,
post-surgery current CECT Abdomen reveals:

   ●   Post operative changes as described.
   ●   Severe thinning of pancreas with irregular peripherally enhancing collections in retro-
       peritoneum and peritoneum and features of peritonitis as described.
   ●   On positive contrast administration in the distal loop, there is contrast extravasation through a
       defect of 10mm in the anterior wall of the ascending colon which is seen extending and
       reaching till the side wall of the drain. Minimal suspicious opacification of the drain at this site
       is, however no further intra-peritoneal leak. The findings could represent the possibility of
       walled off cavity around perforation site.
   ●   Minimal ascites as described.
