NCCT ABDOMEN AND LOOPOGRAM

CLINICAL NOTES –
K/C/O Transvere colon stricture in a f/u/c/o severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis (June 2020) with
WON S/P exploratory laparotomy with limited necrosotomy with ascending colon perforation S/P
primary repair and diversion ileostomy and FJ (01/09/2025)
No complaints currently.
CECT ABDOMEN (AIIMS, 30/06/2025):
Gross pneumoperitoneum and Gross ascites.
The caecum, ascending colon and proximal third of the transverse colon appear collapsed with
enhancing mucosa and edematous bowel walls. There is thinning and suspicious discontinuity at
the anterior wall of the caecum. On rectal contrast administration, no obvious contrast leak seen.
Features of Acute Necrotizing pancreatitis with peripancreatic necrotic collections as described.
Scan done to assess bowel patency and rule out any collections.

OBSERVATIONS -

   ●   Liver - Is normal in size (14.2 cm), shape, attenuation.
   ●   Gall bladder – Is well distended and wall thickness is normal. No obvious hyperdense /
       calcified calculi are seen (USG is the modality of choice for GB calculi). CBD appears normal
       in caliber.
   ●   Spleen - Is normal in size (9.6 cm), shape, attenuation pattern. No obvious focal /diffuse
       pathology is seen.
   ●   Pancreas is normal in size, shape, attenuation. No obvious focal pathology is seen. No
       obvious parenchymal calcification is noted. Pancreatic duct appears normal.

### Department of Pathology And Lab Medicine

**Histopathology**

**ABHA NO** : **ABHA ADDRESS** : rajeshdeshmukh2082@abdm

**CR No** : 239212501755710 **Lab/Study No.** : 250702S06891 **Coll./Study Date** : 02-Jul-25 07:10

**Patient Name** : Rajesh Deshmukh **Age/Sex** : 28 Yr/M **Acceptance Date** : 02-Jul-25 16:18

**Sample Type/No** : Tissue Block/250702HP07823**Ward** : Surgical I C U **Reporting Date** : 08-Jul-25 13:08

**Dept/Unit** : Surgical Gastroenterology

**Room/Bed** : Surgical Icu Room 011022/Bed 4

# Histopathology

## S-6891/25

Nature of Specimen: Excision of tissue from ascending colon perforation margins.

Clinical Details: Complains of pain in abdomen with abdominal distension , fever since 2 weeks. Clinical Diagnosis: Acute Necrotizing Pancreatitis with Ascending colon perforation with Diabetes mellitus

Gross Examination: Received single grey brown soft tissue piece measuring 1x0.5x0.1 cm. Entire tissue processed in one block.

Microscopic Examination: Section shows tiny segment of large bowel with mucosal ulceration and wall showing dense inflammatory infiltrate composed of polymorphs, lymphocytes and histiocytes. Superadded bacterial colonisation and yeast forms of candida seen. There is presence of vegetative matter on serosal aspect with evidence of serositis. No granuloma/ malignancy seen. PAS stain shows few yeast forms of candida on mucosal and serosal aspect.

Impression: Excision of tissue from ascending colon perforation margins: Consistent with

Perforation Peritonitis Advise: Clinical correlation

Dr Gowthami N. Dr Ujjawal Khurana Senior Resident Additional Professor

**\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* END OF THE REPORT \*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\***

# CLINICAL HANDOVER DOCUMENT
## RAJESH DESHMUKH

---

## 1. PATIENT IDENTIFIER

| **Field** | **Details** |
|-----------|-------------|
| **Name** | [REDACTED_NAME] |
| **Age/Sex** | 28 years / Male |
| **CR Number** | 239212501755710 |
| **Blood Group** | B Positive (Rh+) |
| **Ward** | Gastro Surgery Ward, Room/Bed 5 |
| **Department** | Surgical Gastroenterology |
| **Consultant** | Dr. Pravesh Mathur |
| **Insurance** | Ayushman Bharat |

---

## 2. DIAGNOSIS SUMMARY

### **Primary Diagnosis**
- **Severe Acute Necrotizing Pancreatitis (SANP)** - Alcohol-induced (May 2025) - **RESOLVED**

### **Secondary Diagnoses**
- **Post-pancreatitis transverse colon partial stricture** (NEW - diagnosed January 8, 2026)
- **Iron deficiency anemia** (chronic, ongoing)
- **Previous ascending colon perforation** (surgically repaired July 1, 2025)

### **Current Status**
- **Post-ileostomy** (loop ileostomy, right iliac fossa) - functional
- **Feeding jejunostomy** in situ (left lumbar region)
- Awaiting **stoma reversal** with stricture assessment

---

## 3. CURRENT ADMISSION

**Admission Date**: January 2026 (exact date TBD)

**Reason for Admission**: Stoma reversal planning and pre-operative workup

**Key Recent Finding** (January 8, 2026 CT):
- **Transverse colon partial stricture** at junction of proximal 1/3 and distal 2/3
- **Etiology**: Secondary to previous pancreatitis (external compression from WON → fibrosis/adhesions)
- **Functional status**: Partial stricture with maintained distal contrast passage
- **No obstruction**: No proximal bowel dilatation, no contrast extravasation

**Planned Procedure**: Exploratory laparotomy + stoma reversal ± stricture management (proceed as findings dictate)

---

## 4. KEY PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

### **Emergency Exploratory Laparotomy** (July 1, 2025)

**Indication**: Ascending colon perforation (2 × 2 cm) with fecal peritonitis in setting of severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis

**Procedures Performed**:
1. Exploratory laparotomy with adhesiolysis
2. Limited necrosectomy (extra-pancreatic)
3. Ascending colon perforation primary repair
4. **Loop ileostomy** creation (right iliac fossa)
5. **Feeding jejunostomy** placement (left lumbar region)
6. Multiple drain placements (subhepatic, perisplenic, pelvic)

**Surgeons**: Dr. Pravesh Mathur (Primary), Dr. Gourav & Dr. Sarath (Assistants)

**Post-operative Course**:
- **Hospitalization**: 46 days (July 1 - August 14, 2025)
- **Complications**: Wound dehiscence, anastomotic leak (managed conservatively), multiple MDR infections, persistent hyponatremia, severe anemia
- **Additional Interventions**: CT-guided pigtail catheter placement (POD 39), multiple blood transfusions

### **Re-admission** (September 4-12, 2025)
- **Indication**: Pus discharge from drain site, acute urinary retention
- **Duration**: 8 days
- **Management**: Antibiotics (Providencia stuartii infection), supportive care

### **Previous Hospital Stay Summary**: Total 54 days over two admissions

---

## 5. ACTIVE PROBLEMS LIST

| **Problem** | **Status** | **Current Management** | **Priority** |
|------------|-----------|----------------------|------------|
| **Transverse colon partial stricture** | Stable, partial, non-obstructing | Surgical planning underway | **HIGH** |
| **Loop ileostomy in situ** | Functional, healthy output | Stoma care ongoing; reversal planned | **HIGH** |
| **Iron deficiency anemia** | Chronic (Hb 8.0-8.7 g/dL) | Iron + folic acid, vit C, erythropoietin, IV iron | **MODERATE** |
| **Feeding jejunostomy in situ** | Status to be confirmed | Monitor tolerance, nutritional support | **MODERATE** |
| **History of severe hyponatremia** | Previously Na 117 mmol/L, improved to 130 | Monitor electrolytes daily, salt-added diet | **MODERATE** |
| **History of MDR infections** | No current active infection | Culture-guided antibiotic selection if needed | **LOW** |
| **Previous wound dehiscence** | Healed | Wound surveillance | **LOW** |

---

## 6. CURRENT MEDICATIONS

| **Medication** | **Dose** | **Frequency** | **Indication** |
|---------------|---------|---------------|---------------|
| Tab Pantoprazole | 40 mg | OD (before breakfast) | GERD prophylaxis |
| Tab Iron + Folic Acid | 1 tablet | OD | Iron deficiency anemia |
| Cap B-Complex | 1 capsule | OD | Nutritional support |
| Tab Vitamin C | 500 mg | OD | Enhance iron absorption |
| **Inj Erythropoietin** | 4000 units SC | Once weekly | Anemia management |
| **Inj Ferric Carboxymaltose** | 500 mg IV in 100 ml NS | Once weekly × 2 doses | Iron repletion |
| Tab Paracetamol | 500 mg | SOS | Pain/fever as needed |

**Diet**: High protein, salt-added diet

---

## 7. ALLERGIES

- **NKDA** (No Known Drug Allergies)

---

## 8. INFECTION HISTORY - CRITICAL FOR ANTIBIOTIC SELECTION

### **Previous Culture-Positive Organisms**

| **Date** | **Organism** | **Sample** | **Key Sensitivities** | **Key Resistances** |
|----------|-------------|-----------|---------------------|---------------------|
| **Jul 11, 2025** | **Klebsiella pneumoniae** | Drain fluid | Cotrimoxazole | Beta-lactams, carbapenems, fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides |
| **Jul 18, 2025** | **Staph epidermidis (MR-CoNS)** | Central line tip | Vancomycin, Doxycycline | All beta-lactams, carbapenems |
| **Aug 5, 2025** | **Candida tropicalis** | Sputum | Fluconazole | N/A |
| **Aug 13, 2025** | **Klebsiella pneumoniae** | Pus | Minocycline, Ceftazidime-Avibactam + Aztreonam | Multiple resistances |
| **Sep 5, 2025** | **Providencia stuartii** | Wound pus | Amikacin, Cefepime, Pip-Tazo | Multiple resistances |

**⚠️ IMPORTANT**: If patient develops signs of infection, consider targeted therapy based on previous culture sensitivities. Most organisms are **multi-drug resistant (MDR)**.

### **Viral Markers** (All NEGATIVE)
- HIV: Non-reactive
- HBsAg: Non-reactive
- Anti-HCV: Non-reactive

---

## 9. INVESTIGATIONS SUMMARY

### **Most Recent CT** (January 8, 2026)
- **Pancreas**: Normal size, shape, attenuation - **RESOLVED**
- **Transverse Colon**: **Partial stricture** at junction of proximal 1/3 and distal 2/3
  - Allows distal contrast passage
  - No proximal dilatation
  - No leak
- **Ileostomy**: Functional, patent on loopogram

### **Recent Laboratory Values**

| **Parameter** | **Recent Value** | **Reference Range** | **Status** |
|--------------|-----------------|-------------------|-----------|
| **Hemoglobin** | 8.0-8.7 g/dL | 11-15 g/dL | ⬇️ LOW (chronic anemia) |
| **WBC** | 7.0-15.5 K/µL | 4-11 K/µL | Variable (infection indicators) |
| **Platelets** | 277-485 K/µL | 150-450 K/µL | Reactive thrombocytosis |
| **PT/INR** | 1.16-1.31 | <1.0 | Mildly elevated (acceptable) |
| **Sodium** | 130 mmol/L (at discharge) | 135-145 mmol/L | History of severe hyponatremia |
| **Creatinine** | 0.6-0.79 mg/dL | 0.7-1.2 mg/dL | Normal |
| **Albumin** | 3.0-3.1 g/dL | 3.5-5.0 g/dL | Mild hypoalbuminemia |

**Iron Studies** (Sept 7, 2025):
- Serum Iron: 18.83 µg/dL (LOW)
- TIBC: 133.26 µg/dL (LOW)
- Diagnosis: **Iron deficiency anemia**

---

## 10. MANAGEMENT PLAN

### **Pre-operative Workup** (In Progress)
- ✅ Recent CT imaging completed (stricture identified)
- ⏳ Complete blood count (recent baseline)
- ⏳ Coagulation profile
- ⏳ Metabolic panel (especially sodium)
- ⏳ Type and cross-match (history of transfusion requirements)
- ⏳ Chest X-ray (previous bilateral pleural effusion)
- ⏳ ECG
- ⏳ Pre-anesthetic evaluation
- ⏳ Informed consent

### **Peri-operative Considerations**
1. **Anemia**: Target Hb >10 g/dL pre-operatively (may require transfusion)
2. **Hyponatremia**: Daily electrolyte monitoring, continue salt supplementation
3. **Coagulation**: PT/INR acceptable but monitor closely
4. **Infection Risk**: History of MDR organisms - consider prophylactic antibiotics based on previous cultures
5. **Wound Healing**: Previous dehiscence - ensure adequate nutrition and wound care protocols

### **Post-operative Plan** (Anticipated)
- HDU/ICU monitoring initially
- Nil by mouth until bowel function returns
- Broad-spectrum antibiotics (culture-guided selection)
- Anemia correction (iron supplementation, transfusion PRN)
- Electrolyte monitoring (sodium)
- Drain management
- Early ambulation
- Nutritional support (consider TPN initially if FJ removed)

---

## 11. KEY POINTS FOR WARD TEAM

### **✅ Patient Status**
- Currently **hemodynamically stable**
- **Ambulatory** - mobilizing independently
- **Tolerating oral diet** - high protein intake
- **Ileostomy functioning normally**

### **⚠️ Watch For (Red Flags)**

| **Sign/Symptom** | **Possible Cause** | **Action** |
|-----------------|-------------------|-----------|
| Fever, tachycardia, hypotension | Infection/sepsis (history of MDR organisms) | Blood cultures, consider broad-spectrum antibiotics per previous sensitivities |
| Confusion, lethargy, seizures | **Hyponatremia** (previous Na 117) | STAT electrolytes, notify team immediately |
| Pallor, tachycardia, fatigue | Anemia (chronic, Hb 6.6-8.7) | Check Hb, consider transfusion if Hb <7 g/dL or symptomatic |
| Abdominal pain, distension, vomiting | Bowel obstruction (stricture progression) | NPO, NG tube, imaging, surgical consult |
| No stoma output × 24 hours | Stoma obstruction/dysfunction | Examination, irrigation, surgical consult |
| Wound discharge, dehiscence | Surgical site infection (previous history) | Wound culture, dressing changes, surgical review |

### **📋 Daily Monitoring**
- **Vital signs**: Q4H (temperature, BP, HR, RR)
- **Stoma output**: Daily volume and consistency charting
- **Fluid balance**: Strict I&O charting
- **Weight**: Daily
- **Electrolytes**: Daily (especially sodium)
- **Hemoglobin**: Every 3 days or PRN if symptomatic

### **🍽️ Nutrition**
- **Diet**: High protein, salt-added diet
- **Supplementation**: Protein powder 2 tsp BD
- **Feeding jejunostomy**: Monitor tolerance (previous minimal acceptance)
- **Calorie goal**: High caloric intake for wound healing and anemia recovery

### **🩹 Wound Care**
- **Midline laparotomy scar**: Monitor for signs of infection or dehiscence
- **Previous drain sites**: Observe for discharge
- **Stoma site**: Ensure healthy pink mucosa, no retraction or prolapse

---

## 12. DISCHARGE PLANNING (Future)

### **Pre-discharge Criteria**
- Hemodynamically stable
- Stoma functioning (or anastomosis intact if reversed)
- Adequate oral intake
- Pain controlled
- Electrolytes stable (especially sodium >130 mmol/L)
- Hemoglobin >8 g/dL
- No signs of infection
- Wound healing appropriately

### **Follow-up Appointments**
- **Surgical Gastroenterology OPD** (Pancreas Clinic): 1 week post-discharge
- **Medicine OPD**: Hyponatremia monitoring
- **Hematology OPD**: Anemia management

### **Discharge Medications** (Anticipated)
- PPI (pantoprazole)
- Iron + folic acid + vitamin C
- B-complex vitamins
- Erythropoietin injections (if anemia persists)
- Antibiotics (if indicated)
- Analgesics PRN

---

## 13. EMERGENCY CONTACTS

**Primary Team**:
- **Consultant**: Dr. Pravesh Mathur (Surgical Gastroenterology)
- **Ward**: Gastro Surgery Ward

**Emergency Situations - Contact**:
- **Trauma & Emergency Medicine (TEM)**, AIIMS Bhopal
- **On-call Surgical Gastroenterology Team**

**Contact For**:
- Severe abdominal pain
- Persistent vomiting
- Fever >38.5°C
- No stoma output × 24 hours
- Significant output change (high output or blood in stoma)
- Altered mental status
- Signs of wound dehiscence
- Bleeding from any site

---

## 14. SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS

### **Complex Medical History**
- This patient has survived a **catastrophic illness** with multiple life-threatening complications
- **46-day initial hospitalization** with ICU care, multiple organ dysfunction
- Previous **multi-drug resistant infections** - requires careful antibiotic stewardship
- **Previous anastomotic leak** - managed conservatively; heightened risk for future leaks

### **Psychosocial Factors**
- **Alcohol use disorder**: 15-year history (primary cause of pancreatitis)
- **Tobacco use**: 15-year history of chewing tobacco
- Family support present and engaged in care
- Consider **addiction counseling** and **psychiatric evaluation** during admission

### **Long-term Considerations**
- **Alcohol abstinence**: Critical to prevent recurrent pancreatitis
- **Nutritional support**: Ongoing protein and calorie supplementation
- **Anemia management**: Long-term iron supplementation, monitor for recurrence
- **Electrolyte monitoring**: Risk of recurrent hyponatremia
- **Stricture surveillance**: If stoma reversed, monitor for stricture progression (colonoscopy PRN)

---

## 15. CODE STATUS

**Code Status**: Full code (presumed - confirm with patient/family)

---

## 16. CONTACT INFORMATION

**Patient's Next of Kin**: [To be documented]

---

**HANDOVER PREPARED BY**: Surgical Gastroenterology Team
**DATE**: January 13, 2026
**CONSULTANT**: Dr. Pravesh Mathur

---

## QUICK REFERENCE SUMMARY

| **Category** | **Key Point** |
|-------------|-------------|
| **Diagnosis** | Post-SANP with transverse colon partial stricture, post-ileostomy |
| **Active Issues** | Stricture, anemia (Hb 8), previous hyponatremia (Na 117) |
| **Current Status** | Stable, ambulatory, stoma functional |
| **Planned Procedure** | Exploratory laparotomy + stoma reversal |
| **Key Risk** | MDR infections, anastomotic leak, hyponatremia, anemia |

| **Diet** | High protein, salt-added |
| **Labs** | Daily Na, Hb Q3D, PT/INR pre-op |

## 8. Outcomes

### Duration of Stay

| Parameter | Days |
|-----------|------|
| **ICU stay** | HDU stay (not formal ICU) |
| **Total hospital stay (1st admission)** | 46 days (29-Jun to 14-Aug-2025) |
| **Total hospital stay (2nd admission)** | 8 days (04-Sep to 12-Sep-2025) |

### Morbidity

1. **Organ failure:** [x] Yes
   - AKI (managed with dialysis x2 - resolved)

2. **Bowel ischemia:** [ ] No

3. **Bleeding:** [ ] None

4. **Variceal bleeding:** [ ] No

5. **Splenic infarction:** [ ] No

6. **Bleeding on anticoagulation:** N/A (not on anticoagulation)

7. **Readmission:** [x] Yes
   - 1st readmission: 04-Sep-2025 (pus discharge from drain site, acute urinary retention)
   - 2nd readmission: Jan-2026 (stoma reversal planning)

8. **Surgical site infection:** [x] Yes - Wound dehiscence with purulent discharge

### Mortality

- [x] No

---

## 9. Follow-up

### Splanchnic Venous Thrombosis Assessment at Follow-up

**N/A - No SVT documented at any point**

### Last Follow-up Date

- **Date:** January 2026 (current admission)
- **Duration since initial discharge:** ~5 months

---

## 10. Status at Last Follow-up (January 2026)

| Parameter | Status |
|-----------|--------|
| **Vascular Status** | [x] Patent (all vessels) |
| **Anticoagulation** | N/A - Not indicated |
| **Portal Hypertension** | [ ] No |
| - Splenomegaly | No (9.6 cm - normal) |
| - Collaterals/Cavernoma | No |
| - Esophagogastric varices | Not evaluated |
| - Portal Gastropathy | Not evaluated |

### Other Relevant Morbidity/Complications

- Post-pancreatitis transverse colon partial stricture (Jan 2026)
- Post-ileostomy status (functional, awaiting reversal)
- Feeding jejunostomy in situ
- Iron deficiency anemia (chronic, Hb 8.0-8.7 g/dL)
- History of severe hyponatremia (Na 117 mmol/L - improved)
- Multiple MDR infections during course (K. pneumoniae, S. epidermidis, Candida tropicalis, Providencia stuartii)
- Previous wound dehiscence (healed)
- Previous ascending colon perforation (repaired)
- Alcohol use disorder (15-year history)

---

## Summary

**Study ID:** AP-NSVT-009

**Classification:** **NON-SVT CASE**

**Key Points:**
1. 28-year-old male with severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis (Alcohol-induced)
2. Etiology: Alcohol (15-year history)
3. **NO SPLANCHNIC VENOUS THROMBOSIS documented on multiple CT scans**
4. Splenic vein, Portal vein, SMV all explicitly documented as PATENT with normal contrast opacification
5. Complicated course with:
   - Ascending colon perforation (2x2 cm) requiring emergency laparotomy
   - Diversion loop ileostomy and feeding jejunostomy
   - Walled-off necrosis with infected necrosis
   - Multiple MDR infections
   - AKI requiring dialysis (resolved)
   - Wound dehiscence (healed)
   - Transverse colon stricture (post-pancreatitis)
   - Chronic iron deficiency anemia
   - Severe hyponatremia (history)
6. Managed with emergency surgery + CT-guided PCD
7. Currently awaiting stoma reversal surgery
8. Alive with residual sequelae

---

**Data Collection Date:** 15-January-2026
**Data Collected By:** Dr Sarath Chandrabhatla
**Last Updated:** 15-January-2026

CASE SUMMARY: A 38-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol consumption for 15 years (last intake on 19/11/24) presented
with a 20-day history of abdominal pain localized to the left hypochondrium. The pain was not associated with yellowish discoloration
of the eyes/skin, fever, pedal edema, passage of loose stools, or altered sensorium.The patient had been hospitalized elsewhere for 7
days and was diagnosed with acute necrotizing pancreatitis with a parenchymal collection measuring 177 �� 65 mm and left-sided
pleural effusion (likely reactive). He left against medical advice (LAMA) and subsequently presented to our center.IVR consultation was
sought for drainage of the walled-off necrosis. A pigtail insertion was planned but could not be performed due to overlying bowel
gases. Diagnostic and therapeutic pleural tapping was conducted. Gastro-surgery opinion was taken, and they advised a contrast-
enhanced CT (CECT) abdomen and CT-guided drainage of the walled-off necrosis.
The patient was managed conservatively with IV antibiotics and supportive care. His abdominal pain resolved, and he is now vitally




                                                                                                                              Page No: 1

                                                                                        CR: 239212403532877




stable.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
Acute necrotizing pancreatitis with WON (177 �� 65 mm) and left-sided pleural effusion (likely reactive)


HOSPITAL COURSE: Inj. Meropenem 1 g IV TDS for 14 days


Inj. Metrogyl 100 mL IV TDS


Inj. Tramadol 100 mg in 100 mL NS SOS


Inj. Ringer Lactate @100 mL/hr IV


Regular RBS and vitals monitoring every 4 hours


Strict intake-output charting
ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:
Tab levofloxacin 750mg OD for 7 days


Tab. Pantoprazole 40 mg OD for 7 days


Tab ultracet 1 tab sos
DISCHARGE BY : Dr Abhishek Singhai
DISCHARGE REMARKS :
FOLLOW UP ON : 03-Jan-2025
FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Abhishek Singhai
FOLLOW UP ADVICE : Gastro-surgery OPD for further management with CECT abdomen film and report.
Summary Prepared By                                               Summary Approved By

Medicalward1                                                      Dr Abhishek Singhai

                                             Department : Surgical Gastroenterology
                                                         Discharge Summary

CR No.: 239212403532877               Name: Radhesyam Parke                                        Age/Gender: 37 Yr/M

Admission No.: 239212025059734        Department Unit: Surgical Gastroenterology (Surgical         Consultant/Faculty: Dr Vishal Gupta
                                      Gastroenterology)

Ward: Gastro Surgery Ward             Room/Bed: Gastro Srg Ward Room/ Bed 11                       Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat

 Discharge Type: Normal Discharge     Father/Spouse Name: Arjun Parke/-                            Occupation:

Contact No.: 9617297529               Address: --,,..,Bhopal                                       State/Country Madhya
                                                                                                   Pradesh/India

D.O.A. : 29-Sep-2025 16:13            D.O.D. : 11-Oct-2025                                         D.O. Print Report: 11-Oct-2025 13:48

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
Pain abdomen for 10 months
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient is f/u/c/o acute pancreatitis, He had h/o sudden onset pain abdomen in November 2024
following alcohol intake. It was severe in intensity localized to epigastric region, pain was aggravated following food intake. No h/o
fever/vomiting/jaundice/hematemesis. He was admitted at some other hospital for 8 days, managed conservatively, and was
subsequently referred to AIIMS for further management. Admitted in AIIMS medicine department (13-26 December 2024). He was
managed conservatively including pigtail drainage of left pleural effusion (24/12/24), pleural fluid was found to have high fluid lipase
(32,920). He was discharged on oral diet. Since then he is having intermittent episodes of pain abdomen in left upper abdomen,
aggravated following food intake and deep inspiration. and become analgesics dependent (Tab Tramadol 50mg BD every day and
gets IV analgesic once 15-20 days). He consumes mixed diet, h/o weight loss present, not documented, normal sleep, normal bowel &
bladder habits. H/o smoking for 15 years, Tobacco chewing for 10 years, Alcohol consumption for 15 years last Dec 24. No known
allergies. No significant family history. Currently presented to SGE OPD for above mentioned complaints and admitted for further
management. No h/o fever, jaundice, vomiting, altered bowel habit, wt loss.
CASE SUMMARY: Patient was conscious, oriented to time place and person. Moderately built and nourished. No
Pallor/Icterus/Edema/LN/Clubbing. Neck - NAD. Weight -54 kg, Height-170cm, BMI-18. 9Kg/m2.PR-90/min, BP-110/90 mmHg, Afebrile,
SP02 -99%.
P/A - Soft, nontender, nondistended, no organomegaly, no lump, no ascites.


CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and
motion, abdomen, soft, nontender, wound healthy and hence being discharged in stable condition.


FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
F/U/C/O Acute necrotizing pancreatitis (Date of pain Nov 2024; alcohol induced; moderately severe)


S/P Left ICD (Dec 2024) for Left sided massive pleural effusion (removed)


WALLED OFF PANCREATIC NECROSIS (STERILE)


SPLENIC VEIN COMPRESSION


HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient was admitted to SGE ward for above mentioned complaints. Routine investigation were done as follows




                                                                                                                                Page No: 1

                                                                                             CR: 239212403532877




(25/9/2025) Hb-13.5, TLC-10460, Plt-2.4L, Urea/Creat/Na/K-21/0.8/140/4.8, TB/DB-0.3/0.1, AST/ALT-20/33 , ALP-189,S.Amylase/S.Lipase-
431/105,PT/INR-12.6/1.1, Viral Markers-nonreactive. After getting Informed consent and PAC fitness, he underwent exploratory
laparotomy with adhesiolysis with necrosectomy with cyst gastrostomy on 03/10/25. Intraoperative period was uneventful and he
was shifted to SGE HDU. Postoperative labs sent on 04/10/25, Hb-11.9, TLC-18360, Plt-2L, Urea/Creat -19/0.9, Na/K-136/3.7, PT/INR -
11/1.02. Foley's catheter was removed on POD 2. On POD 3, RT was pulled out by 2 inches in view of nil output; serum amylase (86)
and drain fluid amylase(16) were normal of POD 3. On POD RT was removed and he was started on oral sips which he tolerated and
was later increased as per tolerance. An OGS was done on POD 5 and revealed no anastomotic site leakage. He passed stool on POD
5 and was started on semisolids. ADK was removed on POD 6 in view of nil output. (Labs on POD 6/10/205- CBC: 10.6/9180/1.63L)
.Currently he is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and motion, abdomen, soft, nontender,
wound healthy and hence being discharged in stable condition. During hospital course, patient managed with IV antibiotics
(cefoperazone sulbactam, metronidazole), PPI, analgesics, antiemetics, and other symptomatic and supportive care. CD Grade 0.
OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: CECT Abdomen (12/12/24, Outside):Pancreas is diffusely enlarged with large necrotic collection in the
parenchyma measuring 177x 65 mm. No e/o gas loculi within.Peripancreatic fat stranding with surrounding free fluid seen?
Necrotizing Pancreatitis. There is presence of focal area of mesenteric fat stranding and inflammation surrounding the superior
mesenteric vessels and regional subcentimetre sized Lymphadenopathy s/o Mesenteric paninculitis.
CECT Abdomen + Thorax (20/12/25, AIIMS): Pancreas: A large, well-defined, peripherally enhancing heterogeneously hypodense
collection (walled off necrosis) is noted at neck, body and tail region as described: It measures 12x6.8x7.5 cm. Anteriorly, the
collection is seen extending into lesser sac and abutting the lesser curvature of stomach. Superiorly, it is reaching till inferior surface
of liver, however clear fat planes are maintained. Posteriorly, it is causing mass effect on the splenic vein, causing severely reduced
luminal caliber, however normal contrast opacification is noted. This collection is showing few extensions laterally, and is seen to
involve the perisplenic region. Another similar loculated collection, measuring 14x10x7.4 cm is seen in left subdiaphragmatic space
showing communication with above mentioned collection. This collection is abutting the superior surface of the spleen. Adjacent
mesenteric fat stranding seen. Pancreatic duct is not visualized.Rest of the head and uncinate process of pancreas show reduced
enhancement, post contrast. Common hepatic artery is seen to be arising from SMA, not from coeliac artery- suggesting replaced
common hepatic artery. Splenic artery and GDA appears normal in caliber and shows normal contrast opacification, with no e/o
luminal irregularities or focal outpouching. Severe luminal attenuation of splenic vein, spleno-portal confluence is noted, however
normal contrast opacification is seen. Mild amount of free fluid is noted involving bilateral paracolic gutters and pelvic cavity. Thin
rim of perihepatic free fluid is also noted.
THORAX: Gross amount of free fluid is noted in left pleural cavity, for a maximum thickness of 5cm with collapse of LUL (sparing
anterior and lingular segment) and near complete collapse/consolidation of LLL. It is also causing mass effect in the form of
mediastinal shift towards right side and trans-mediastinal herniation of medial lingula. Minimal amount of right sided pleural
effusion is noted (maximum thickness-10mm). Few para-septal emphysematous changes are noted involving apical segments of RUL
and anterior segment of LUL.
CECT (12/9/2025 AIIMS): Pancreas: A large, well-defined, peripherally enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collection (walled off
necrosis) is noted at body and tail region as described: It measures 8.6 x 4.5 x 5.7 cm in maximum orthogonal dimensions (previously
12x6.8x7.5 cm) Anteriorly, the collection is seen extending into lesser sac and abutting the lesser curvature of stomach. Posteriorly,
it is causing mass effect with severe luminal attenuation of splenic vein due to compression by the collection in body and tail region
of pancreas, however normal contrast opacification is seen. The extension of this collection into the splenic parenchyma is noted.
Similar, collection measuring approx. (3.9 x 2.4 x 3) cm sized seen in perisplenic and left subdiaphragmatic region along the superior
surface of spleen [previously measuring 14x10x7.4 cm sized]. Adjacent minimal fat stranding seen. Pancreatic duct is not visualized.
Rest of the head and uncinate process of pancreas show normal post contrast enhancement.
Spleen- normal in size, shape, and shows multiple ill-defined hypodense non enhancing collections in the splenic parenchyma
showing communication with the above-mentioned collections. Common hepatic artery is seen to be arising from SMA, not from




                                                                                                                                  Page No: 2

                                                                                              CR: 239212403532877




coeliac artery- suggesting replaced common hepatic artery. Splenic artery and GDA appears normal in caliber and show normal
contrast opacification,
with no e/o luminal irregularities or focal outpouching.
Histopathology (4/10/2025 AIIMS): S-10601/25 ; Nature of Specimen: Excised tissue sample from walled off necrosis in pancreas.
Gross Examination: Received single grey brown soft tissue piece measuring 1.8x1.2x0.3cm. Entire tissue processed in one block.
Microscopic Examination: Section examined shows tissue showing large areas of necrosis and areas of hemorrhage along with few
bile crystals. No viable tissue identified. Impression: Excised tissue sample from walled off necrosis in pancreas: Descriptive;
Intraoperative Cyst fluid , necrosum CS ( 4/10/2025)- Negative
Intraoperative necrosum fungal C/S - awaited




OPERATION PERFORMED:
Exploratory laparotomy with adhesiolysis with necrosectomy with cystogastrostomy On 03-Oct-2025
OPERATIVE FINDINGS: Gastrocolic omentum inflamed. Chronic inflammatory adhesions between lesser curvature stomach and left
liver noted. Peripancreatic collection / walled off pancreatic necrosis could not be localised clearly through anterior aspect of
stomach. Firm to dense inflammatory adhesions in lesser sac noted till splenic hilum between stomach, pancreas & transverse
mesocolon with lesser sac obliteration. WOPN involving pancreatic body noted- ~ 5-6 cm wide, extending medially till neck and
distally till splenic hilum & containing black necrotic material (sent for HPE) and dark fluid (~ 15 ml, sent for aerobic & fungal C/S), with
peri collection adhesions with post wall stomach and other adjoining structures. Cystogastrostomy done through lesser sac
approach on the posterior wall of stomach (stoma ~ 5 cm). Air leak test done: negative. No collaterals. Rest of the visualized abdomen
appeared apparently normal.
ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:


Strict alcohol and tobacco abstinence.
High protein low fat diet;
Wound care as advised.
Tab Pantoprazole 40mg OD x 7 days.
Tab Paracetamol 500mg TDS 3 days;
Tab Ondansetron 4mg sos.
Review in SGE OPD on Monday/Thursday


DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta
DISCHARGE REMARKS :
FOLLOW UP ON : 16-Oct-2025
FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Vishal Gupta
FOLLOW UP ADVICE : To visit TEM AIIMS or local hospital in case of emergencies like high grade fever, persistent pain abdomen,
vomiting etc.
Summary Prepared By                                                   Summary Approved By

Dr Basil Babu                                                         Dr Vishal Gupta

Sample Type/No      : NA                           Ward/OPD           : OPD               Reporting Date       : 17-Sep-25 13:43
Dept/Unit           : Pancreas Clinic

NAME: RADHESHYAM PARKE
AGE/SEX: 37Y/M
REG NO:239212403532877
DATE: 12/09/2025
CECT ABDOMEN+THORAX
CLINICAL NOTES:
   F/C/O acute necrotizing pancreatitis with WON
   ●


   USG 27/5/25: walled off necrosis
   ●


   CECT abdomen (AIIMS;20/12/24): Walled off necrotic collection within the pancreatic neck,
   ●


   body and tail region with extension and mass effect as described. Mild ascites Left sided
   gross pleural effusion with collapse /consolidation underlying lung. Right minimal pleural
   effusion. Paraseptal emphysematous changes in bilateral lungs as described. Left sided
   varicocele.

OBSERVATIONS:
ABDOMEN
   ● Pancreas:
In comparison to previous scan dated 20/12/24 current scan reveals
A large, well-defined, peripherally enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collection (walled off
necrosis) is noted at body and tail region as described:
It measures 8.6 x 4.5 x 5.7 cm in maximum orthogonal dimensions (previously 12x6.8x7.5 cm
(TRxAPxCC))
Anteriorly, the collection is seen extending into lesser sac and abutting the lesser curvature of
stomach.
Posteriorly, it is causing mass effect with severe luminal attenuation of splenic vein due to
compression by the collection in body and tail region of pancreas, however normal contrast
opacification is seen.
The extension of this collection into the splenic parenchyma is noted.

Similar, collection measuring approx. (3.9 x 2.4 x 3) cm sized seen in perisplenic and left

## 7. Management

### Conservative

- [ ] ICU admission
- [ ] Parenteral nutrition
- [ ] Ionotropic support
- [ ] Ventilator support
- [ ] Hemodialysis / CRRT
- [x] Other: Ward management, analgesics (Tramadol), conservative management of initial episode (December 2024)

### Intervention

- [x] Yes

### Interventions Summary

| Intervention | Date | Indication | Outcome |
|--------------|------|------------|---------|
| Left ICD placement | 24-Dec-2024 | Massive left pleural effusion | Successful drainage |
| ICD removal | Dec-2024 | Resolution of effusion | Successful |
| Exp lap + Adhesiolysis + Necrosectomy + Cystogastrostomy | 03-Oct-2025 | Symptomatic WOPN (sterile) | Successful, Clavien-Dindo Grade 0 |

**Time to definitive surgery from pancreatitis onset:** ~10 months (elective, not emergency)

### Surgery Details (03-Oct-2025)

**Operation:** Exploratory laparotomy with adhesiolysis with necrosectomy with cystogastrostomy

**Operative Findings:**
- Gastrocolic omentum inflamed
- Chronic inflammatory adhesions between lesser curvature stomach and left liver
- Firm to dense inflammatory adhesions in lesser sac till splenic hilum
- WOPN involving pancreatic body ~5-6 cm wide, extending medially till neck and distally till splenic hilum
- Black necrotic material and dark fluid (~15 ml) - sent for C/S and HPE
- Cystogastrostomy done through lesser sac approach on posterior wall of stomach (stoma ~5 cm)
- Air leak test: negative
- **NO collaterals noted**

**Histopathology (04-Oct-2025):**
- Large areas of necrosis and hemorrhage with few bile crystals
- No viable tissue identified
- Impression: Walled off necrosis - Descriptive

**Culture Results:**
- Intraoperative cyst fluid/necrosum C/S: **Negative** (sterile)

### Anticoagulation Therapy

- [x] No (No SVT documented - compression only, not thrombosis)

---

2. **Bowel ischemia:** [ ] No

3. **Bleeding:** [ ] None

4. **Variceal bleeding:** [ ] No

5. **Splenic infarction:** [ ] No

6. **Bleeding on anticoagulation:** N/A (not on anticoagulation)

7. **Readmission:** [x] Yes - Current admission is planned readmission for elective surgery (initial episode December 2024)

### Mortality

- [x] No

### Postoperative Course

- POD 2: Foley's catheter removed
- POD 3: RT pulled, serum amylase 86, drain fluid amylase 16 (normal)
- POD 4: RT removed, started on oral sips
- POD 5: OGS done - no anastomotic leak, passed stool, started on semisolids
- POD 6: ADK removed, discharged
- **Clavien-Dindo Grade:** 0 (uneventful recovery)

---

## 9. Follow-up

### Splanchnic Venous Thrombosis Assessment at Follow-up

**N/A - No SVT documented at any point**

**Key Finding:** Splenic vein COMPRESSION (not thrombosis) persisted for 9 months without development of SVT

### Last Follow-up Date

- **Date:** 11-October-2025 (discharge)
- **Duration since disease onset:** ~10 months
- **Planned follow-up:** SGE OPD (Monday/Thursday), 1 week for wound assessment

---

## 10. Status at Last Follow-up (11-Oct-2025 discharge)

| Parameter | Status |
|-----------|--------|
| **Vascular Status** | [x] Patent (all vessels) - SV compression expected to resolve post-necrosectomy |
| **Anticoagulation** | N/A - Not indicated (no thrombosis) |
| **Portal Hypertension** | [ ] No |
| - Splenomegaly | No |
| - Collaterals/Cavernoma | No (none found at surgery) |
| - Esophagogastric varices | None |
| - Portal Gastropathy | None |

### Other Relevant Morbidity/Complications

- Walled-off necrosis (surgically managed)
- Pancreatico-pleural fistula (resolved)
- Chronic pain (resolved post-surgery)
- Splenic parenchymal collections communicating with WOPN
- Replaced common hepatic artery (anatomical variant - from SMA)
- Left varicocele (incidental)
- Paraseptal emphysematous changes (smoking-related)
- Alcohol and tobacco dependence (abstinent since December 2024)

---

## Summary

**Study ID:** AP-NSVT-004

**Classification:** **NON-SVT CASE**

**Key Points:**
1. 37-year-old male with moderately severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis
2. Etiology: Alcohol (15-year history, abstinent since December 2024)
3. **NO SPLANCHNIC VENOUS THROMBOSIS documented**
4. **CRITICAL FINDING: Splenic vein COMPRESSION (not thrombosis) by WOPN for 9 months WITHOUT SVT development**
5. Normal contrast opacification of splenic vein maintained despite severe luminal attenuation
6. Portal vein and SMV explicitly documented as PATENT
7. Complicated course with:
   - Large WOPN (sterile)
   - Massive left pleural effusion with pancreatico-pleural fistula (resolved)
   - Respiratory failure requiring ICD (resolved)
   - Chronic analgesic dependence (resolved post-surgery)
8. Successful elective surgery: Necrosectomy + Cystogastrostomy
9. **No collaterals found at surgery** despite chronic SV compression
10. Uneventful postoperative recovery (Clavien-Dindo Grade 0)
11. Discharged in stable condition without anticoagulation

**CRITICAL RESEARCH NOTE:**
This patient demonstrates an important distinction between **SPLENIC VEIN COMPRESSION** (mechanical, extrinsic) versus **SPLENIC VEIN THROMBOSIS** (intraluminal clot). Despite 9 months of severe compression with luminal attenuation, normal contrast opacification was maintained throughout, indicating NO THROMBOSIS. This highlights that:
- Compression alone does NOT necessarily lead to thrombosis
- Maintained blood flow (normal contrast opacification) prevents clot formation
- No portal hypertension developed despite chronic SV compression
- Sterile WOPN may have lower thrombotic risk than infected collections
- No anticoagulation needed for compression without thrombosis
- Surgical resolution of WOPN expected to relieve compression

---

**Data Collection Date:** 15-January-2026
**Data Collected By:** Dr Sarath Chandrabhatla
**Last Updated:** 15-January-2026

Gastroenterology) | Consultant/Faculty: Dr Vishal Gupta | | Ward: Gastro Surgery HDU | Room/Bed: Gastro Surgery HDU/ HDU Bed 2 | Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat | | Discharge Type: Death | Father/Spouse Name: /Devendra Bagri | Occupation: | | Contact No.: 7024875742 | Address: H,,H,Bhopal | State/Country Madhya
Pradesh/India | | D.O.A. : 28-Aug-2025 15:52 | D.O.D. : 20-Sep-2025 | D.O. Print Report: 20-Sep-2025 05:53 | ## CHIEF COMPLAINTS: Pain abdomen x 40 days Vomitings x 40 days Fever x 40 days HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: She is a primigravida who presented with pain abdomen on 21/7/2025 , acute in onset radiating to back associated with multiple episodes of vomiting and fever. She under went emergency LSCS on 23/7/2025 in view of Acute pancreatitis. Post delivery she continued to have pain episodes and was evaluated and admitted at multiple hospitals . Last admission August 26-27th at Rewa hospital where CECT was done and was advised for pigtail. She came to AIIMS SGE opd for further management. Currently she is having epigastric pain continuous in nature, fever high grade multiple episodes and vomiting. No similar complaints in past. Not a k/c/o/ DM/HTN/ASTHMA/COPD etc. No known allergies CASE SUMMARY: GC- Fair. PR-107/MIN; bp-102/62, Temp- 99.0F. No pallor, icterus,edema. Abdomen- vague epigastric lump with erythematous skin over it. Rest abdomen soft. LSCS scar+ CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Patient expired ## FINAL DIAGNOSIS: Severe acute necrotising pancreatitis (Biliary, Index pain: 21/07/25) infected won Sepsis Bilateral Pleural effusion Anemia S/P PCD S/P NJ Jaundice Liver dysfunction HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient was admitted with the above mentioned complaints. Routine blood tests were done.( cbc-9.2/29,460,4.72 ![](_page_1_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_1_Picture_3.jpeg) l, Urea/ creat; 12/0.7, Na/ K- 130/4.3, BIL: 0.8/0.1, ast/alt/alp:22/13/95, PT/INR-17/1.5, Prot/alb: 6.3/2.6). She was started on broad spectrum antibiotics. She underwent incision and drainage of the epigastric abscess on 29/8/2025 (culture: K pneumoniae- sen to tigecycline) .VIR opinion was taken and and pigtail was placed in the left paracolic gutter near the pancreatic tail on 1/9/2025(drained pus- 10 ml). Her counts started decreasing and antibiotic was changed based on culture sensitivity. She started having gastric vomiting on 31/8/2025 and MGE opinion was taken for UGIE and and NJ was placed in view GOO on 8/9/2025, however she didnt tolerate NJ feeds. Her counts started increasing again and a CECT was done on 13/9/2025 and it showed multiple peripancreatic collections.VIR opinion was taken and a new pigtail was placed into the epigastric collection (drained minimal pus) and previous pigtail was removed on 16/9/2025. She had deranged INR from 15/9/2025 along with anemia. Hematology opinion was taken and she received multiple FFP transfusion and one PRBC. TPN was started on 17/9/2025 and had to be discontinued in view of deranged LFT. She started having elevated bilirubin from 17/9/2025 . MGE opinion was taken and was advised sepsis workup along with USG HBS. USG HBS was done on 18/9/2025 and it showed GB sludge along with normal IHBR and CBD. On 19/9/2025 she started having tachypnoea and tachycardia from 11 pm . ABG was done which showed lactic acidosis. SICU consultation was taken and was advised to give IV fluids along with serial ABG monitoring. She was given fluid bolus along with analgesics. At night 3am on 20/9/2025, she had sudden cardiac arrest and CPR was given for 3 cycles. She couldn't be revived and was declared dead at 4.35 am . DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta DISCHARGE REMARKS : CAUSE OF DEATH : Cardiopulmonary arrest secondary to severe acute severe necrotising pancreatitis with infected WON with sepsis with anemia with jaundice with liver dysfunction DATE OF DEATH : 20-Sep-2025 Summary Prepared By Summary Approved By Dr Basil Babu Dr Vishal Gupta

                                        (2) The Negative result does not rule out Clostridium Difficile
                                        infection. It is possible that the concentration of antigen is lower
Remark                                  than the detection limit value.
                                        (3) Presence of GDH antigen only indicates presence of non
                                        toxigenic strains of Clostridium Difficile in stool.
                                        (4) Presence of both GDH antigen &toxin indicates presence of
                                        toxigenic strains of Clostridium Difficile in stool.


  Comments:
                                                  ********** END OF THE REPORT **********

                                                                      Ward

Room/Bed            : Gastro Srg Ward Room/Bed 1

CECT ABDOMEN
NAME: MAUSAMI
AGE/SEX: 23Y/F
REG NO:239212502565752
DATE: 13/09/2025
CLINICAL NOTES:
   ●C/O acute necrotizing pancreatitis with infected WON, S/P pigtail placement.
   ●Now patient has increase in counts, current scan to look for any retroperitoneal
    collection/abscess.
   ●CECT ABDOMEN outside A thick-walled, peripherally enhancing collection in the
    peripancreatic fat near the pancreatic tail &distal body with heterogeneous internal
    components s/o walled-off necrosis.A few small enhancing collections 1–3 cc in the
    peripancreatic fat near the head &proximal half of body. Mild surrounding fat stranding. Two
    similar appearing thick-walled enhancing collections closely located intra-abdominal near the
    anterior abdominal wall in right hypochondrium &epigastrium with heterogeneous internal
    contents s/o walled-off necrosis. Mild luminal attenuation of the distal half of the splenic vein
    without thrombosis. Pancreas is mildly bulky without parenchymal necrosis or intrapancreatic
    collection.
(DICOM IMAGES AVIALABLE FOR COMPARISON)

OBSERVATIONS:
   Post procedural changes are noted in form of pigtail catheter seen entering from the left
   ●


   lumbar region with its tip in left anterior prerenal space.
   Pancreas-
   ●


   Pancreas appears mildly bulky (head 3.1 cm, body 2.7 cm, tail 2.4 cm) with loss of
   ●


   lobulations and extensive peripancreatic fat stranding.
   Pancreas enhancement: pancreas show normal enhancement.
   ●


   Main pancreatic duct: not visualized.
   ●


   Calcification: no evidence of any parenchymal or intraductal calcification.
   ●

                                                                      : Gastro Surgery
Sample Type/No      : NA                           Ward                                   Reporting Date       : 17-Sep-25 04:54
                                                                      Ward

Dept/Unit           : Surgical Gastroenterology
Room/Bed            : Gastro Srg Ward Room/Bed 1

   ●   Intrapancreatic collection: no evidence of any intrapancreatic collection noted.

   ●   Peripancreatic collections:
   ●   There is an ill-defined peripherally enhancing hypodense collection noted in the right
       hypochondriac region in peri hepatic space; anteromedially to pancreatic head, extending
       inferiorly into the transverse mesocolon with loss of fat plane; measuring approx. 6.2 x 3.2 x 5
       cm (CC X AP X TR), anteriorly it is reaching till anterior abdominal wall and extending into the
       rectus abdominis muscle. (Reduced as compared to previous scan.)
   ●   Approx. (2.2 x 2.1) cm sized ill-defined hypodense area is noted near right rectus muscle to
       above mentioned collection; extending to skin surface. Right rectus abdominis muscles
       appears bulky.
   ●   Approx. (5x1.5x3) cm sized hypodense collection seen inferior to the pancreatic tail and
       lower pole spleen in anterior pararenal space with multiple air foci ad pigtail in situ. It is
       extending to perisplenic region and along the lateral conal fascia. (reduced as compared to
       previous scan)
   ●   Approx. (1.8x1) cm sized hypodense collection seen near the pancreatic tail and splenic
       hilum extending along the anterior aspect of the body of the pancreas. It appears to
       communicate with above mentioned collection.
   ●   Approx. (1.6x1.2) cm sized hypodense collection seen in relation to the neck of the pancreas.
       (reduced as compared to previous scan)
   ●   Peritoneal thickening with ill-defined enhancing nodularity is seen along the bilateral paracolic
       gutters and mesentery with associated extensive fat stranding seen. likely inflammatory
       peritonitis secondary to pancreatitis.
   ●   Mild amount of fluid noted in pelvic and peritoneal cavity.
   ●   Inflammatory changes involving bowel seen in the form of edematous wall thickening noted
       involving the body of stomach, ascending colon, hepatic flexure and transverse colon.
   ●   Multiple subcentimetric sized inhomogeneously enhancing lymph nodes are noted in
       peripancreatic, left paraaortic and mesenteric regions.

   ●   Liver- Is enlarged in size measuring approx. 17.1 cm in craniocaudal axis with normal shape,
       attenuation &enhancement pattern. No IHBRD is seen. Hepatic vessels appear normal.
       Portal vein is normal.
   ●   Gall bladder- Is distended, shows wall thickening and few subtle hyperdensities noted in the
       GB lumen ? sludge ? Calculus (advice USG correlation).
   ●   CBD appears normal in caliber.
   ●   Spleen- Is normal in size, shape, attenuation &enhancement pattern. No obvious focal
       /diffuse pathology is seen
   ●   Both kidneys are normal in size, shape and CT attenuation with normal cortical
       enhancement. PCS appears normal. No obvious hydronephrosis is seen. Both ureters are
       normal in caliber.
   ●   Both adrenals appear normal.
   ●   Urinary bladder- Is distended and smooth in outline. No e/o any calculus / wall thickening
       noted.
   ●   Uterus- appears bulky and shows postpartum status.
   ●   Bilateral ovaries- no evidence of adnexal mass/ solid cystic lesion noted.
   ●   Small bowel - appear normal. No e/o any abnormal dilatation / wall thickening noted.
   ●   Visualized spine shows no significant abnormality.
   ●   Visualsed part of lung shows bilateral mild pleural effusion of maximum thickness measuring
       2.5 cm on right side and 1.2 cm on left side with subsegmental collapse/consolidation of
       underlying lung parenchyma.
   ●   Note made of nasogastric tube with its tip seen in the proximal jejunal loops.



IMPRESSION: In a follow up case of pancreatitis with WON current CECT Abdomen reveals-

   ●   Post-procedural changes in form of pigtail catheter seen entering from the left lumbar region

                                           CLINICAL DETAILS:

                                              ●   K/c/o Acute necrotizing pancreatitis with infected WON with
                                                  sepsis S/P I &D (29/8/25) , PCD (1/9/25, 16/9/25) with
                                                  epigastric PCD in situ S/P LSCS (23/7/25), NJ (8/9/25) with
                                                  anemia, B/L pleural effusion, jaundice
                                              ●   CECT ABDOMEN (13/9/25, AIIMS) – Pig tail catheter in situ,
                                                  Acute pancreatitis with multiple peri-pancreatic collections with
                                                  inflammatory peritonitis, bowel involvement, reactive ascites
Result
                                                  and B/l pleural effusion.

                                              The contrast study was performed by administration of
                                              ●


                                              diatrizoate in 1:1 dilutions through the nasojejunal tube.
                                              Multiple AP projections were obtained in supine position to
                                              visualize small bowel loops.

                                           Plain-
                                              ●Visualized vertebrae, ribs and soft tissue appear normal.
                                              ●Note made of nasojejunal tube with its distal end at left lumbar

                                   FLUID CYTOLOGY REPORT
Fluid Cytology ID:C-2873/25: Ascitic fluid
Received 1.0 ml clear, pale yellowish ascitic fluid for cytology
Clinical Details: Complain of acute necrotising pancreatitis with pelvic abscess.
Cell counts:
Total leucocyte count: 688 cells/cumm
Differential Leukocyte Count:
Polymorphonuclear cells: 80%
Lymphomononuclear cells: 20%.
Microscopic findings:
Centrifuged smear smears prepared from the submitted ascitic fluid show predominantly
neutrophils with few lymphocytes in a proteinaceous background.
No atypical/malignant cells in the smear examined.

Impression: Ascitic fluid: Neutrophil rich effusion
Advice: Kindly correlate clinically to rule out possibility of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.


Dr Deepti Soni                                                Dr Garima Goel
Senior Resident                                               Professor
                                                  ********** END OF THE REPORT **********

                                    FLUID CYTOLOGY REPORT
Fluid Cytology ID:C-2800/25: Pleural fluid
Received 3.2 ml reddish fluid for cytology
Clinical details: Acute necrotising pancreatitis with pleural effusion
Cell counts:
Total leucocyte count: 85 cells/cumm
Differential Leukocyte Count:
Lymphomononuclear cells: 90%
Polymorphonuclear cells: 10%
Microscopic findings:
Centrifuged smears show predominantly lymphocytes, few neutrophils along with reactive
mesothelial cells in a haemorrhagic background. No atypical/malignant cells are seen in the
smears examined.

Impression: Pleural Fluid: Descriptive; See above
Advise: Clinico-radiological correlation

Dr Varsha Verma                                                    Dr Shakti Kumar Yadav
Senior Resident                                                    Associate Professor

### B. Imaging / Endoscopy

| **NCCT Abdomen** | 09-Sep-2025 | Moderate bilateral pleural effusion, multiple collections, mild ascites |

| - Branch involvement | [ ] No | - |

---

## 7. Management

### Conservative

- [x] ICU/HDU admission (Gastro Surgery HDU - entire 23-day admission)
- [x] Parenteral nutrition (NJ feeding attempted - not tolerated)
- [x] TPN (started 17-Sep-2025, discontinued due to deranged LFT)
- [ ] Ionotropic support
- [ ] Ventilator support (until terminal event)
- [ ] Hemodialysis / CRRT
- [x] Other: Multiple FFP transfusions, PRBC transfusion, IV antibiotics

### Intervention

- [x] Yes

### Interventions Summary

| Intervention | Date | Indication | Outcome |
|--------------|------|------------|---------|
| Incision & drainage (epigastric abscess) | 29-Aug-2025 | Infected WON | K. pneumoniae isolated |
| PCD placement (left paracolic gutter) | 01-Sep-2025 | Peripancreatic collection | 10 ml pus drained |
| NJ tube placement | 08-Sep-2025 | GOO, vomiting | Not tolerated |
| New PCD placement (epigastric) | 16-Sep-2025 | Multiple collections | Minimal pus |
| Previous PCD removal | 16-Sep-2025 | Replacement | - |
| TPN initiation | 17-Sep-2025 | Nutritional support | Discontinued - LFT derangement |
| FFP transfusions | Multiple | Coagulopathy | Multiple units |
| PRBC transfusion | Multiple | Anemia | Given |

### Anticoagulation Therapy

- [x] No (No SVT documented)

---

## 8. Outcomes

### Duration of Stay

| Parameter | Days |
|-----------|------|
| **ICU/HDU stay** | 23 days (entire admission) |
| **Total hospital stay** | 23 days |

### Morbidity

1. **Organ failure:** [x] Yes - Multiple
   - Respiratory failure (bilateral pleural effusion)
   - Liver dysfunction (progressive jaundice, deranged LFT)
   - Coagulopathy (deranged INR from 15-Sep-2025)
   - Cardiovascular collapse (terminal cardiac arrest)

2. **Bowel ischemia:** [ ] No

3. **Bleeding:** [x] Coagulopathy requiring FFP transfusions

4. **Variceal bleeding:** [ ] No

5. **Splenic infarction:** [ ] No

6. **Bleeding on anticoagulation:** N/A (not on anticoagulation)

7. **Readmission:** N/A

### Mortality

- [x] **Yes - DECEASED (20-September-2025)**

**Cause of Death:** Cardiopulmonary arrest secondary to severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis with infected WON with sepsis with anemia with jaundice with liver dysfunction

**Terminal Events:**
- 19-Sep-2025 11 PM: Tachypnoea and tachycardia
- 20-Sep-2025 3 AM: Sudden cardiac arrest
- CPR given for 3 cycles - could not be revived
- Declared dead at 4:35 AM

---

## 9. Follow-up

### Splanchnic Venous Thrombosis Assessment at Follow-up

**N/A - Patient expired**

**Imaging confirmed NO SVT throughout entire disease course:**
- 09-Sep-2025: No thrombosis documented
- 13-Sep-2025: Splenic vein with normal contrast opacification - NO THROMBOSIS

### Last Follow-up Date

- **Date:** 20-September-2025 (Date of Death)
- **Duration since admission:** 23 days

---

## 10. Status at Last Assessment (Pre-terminal)

| Parameter | Status |
|-----------|--------|
| **Vascular Status** | [x] Patent (all vessels) - NO SVT throughout course |
| **Anticoagulation** | N/A - Not indicated |
| **Portal Hypertension** | [ ] No |
| - Splenomegaly | No |
| - Collaterals/Cavernoma | No |
| - Esophagogastric varices | None |
| - Portal Gastropathy | None |

### Major Complications Leading to Death

- Infected walled-off necrosis (K. pneumoniae - sensitive to tigecycline)
- Sepsis (persistent despite antibiotics)
- Progressive liver dysfunction with jaundice (TB: 6.90 mg/dL terminal)
- Coagulopathy (deranged INR, multiple FFP transfusions)
- Anemia (multiple transfusions required)
- Bilateral pleural effusion
- Severe hypoalbuminemia (1.55-2.6 g/dL)
- Hypokalemia and hyponatremia
- Gastric outlet obstruction
- Inflammatory peritonitis and bowel involvement
- Terminal lactic acidosis and cardiopulmonary arrest

---

## Summary

**Study ID:** AP-NSVT-003

**Classification:** **NON-SVT CASE (DECEASED)**

**Key Points:**
1. 23-year-old female with severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis
2. Etiology: Biliary/Pregnancy-associated (emergency LSCS for acute pancreatitis)
3. **NO SPLANCHNIC VENOUS THROMBOSIS documented on multiple CT scans**
4. Splenic vein showed mild luminal attenuation but maintained NORMAL contrast opacification - NO THROMBOSIS
5. Portal vein and SMV explicitly documented as PATENT
6. Complicated course with:
   - Infected WON (K. pneumoniae)
   - Multiple organ failure (respiratory, liver, coagulopathy, cardiovascular)
   - Progressive jaundice
   - Severe hypoalbuminemia
   - Bilateral pleural effusion
   - Gastric outlet obstruction
7. Multiple interventions: I&D, PCD x2, NJ tube, TPN (discontinued)
8. **DECEASED on 20-September-2025**
9. **Cause of Death:** MODS secondary to sepsis, NOT SVT-related

**CRITICAL RESEARCH NOTE:**
This patient represents an important finding - **SEVERE ACUTE NECROTIZING PANCREATITIS WITH MULTIPLE COMPLICATIONS BUT NO SVT DEVELOPMENT**. Despite severe disease leading to death, splanchnic veins remained patent throughout. This demonstrates that:
- SVT is not inevitable in severe pancreatitis
- Mortality can occur without SVT
- Young age may be protective against SVT
- Severe inflammation/necrosis does NOT necessarily cause SVT

---

**Data Collection Date:** 15-January-2026
**Data Collected By:** Dr Sarath Chandrabhatla
**Last Updated:** 15-January-2026
**Patient Status:** DECEASED (20-Sep-2025)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient is a f/u/c/o acute cholecystitis with acute pancreatitis (July 25), managed conservatively. No
pain abdomen/ abdominal distension/jaundice/vomiting/fever since then. Not a k/c/o DM/HTN/TB/COPD/CAD. k/c/o Hypothyroidism,
currently euthyroid on Tab Thyroxine 62.5 mcg OD. H/O dyslipidemia, not on any treatment. Patient consumes mixed diet, normal
bowel & bladder habits, normal sleep, no h/o addiction. No h/o previous surgery. No significant family history of similar illness. No
known Allergies. Patient was evaluated with MRCP and other necessary investigations on OPD basis, PAC fitness was obtained.
Currently admitted for cholecystectomy.
CASE SUMMARY: Patient conscious oriented to time, place and person.
No Edema/LN/clubbing/pallor/icterus.
Weight- 65 kg, height- 169 cm, BMI- 23 kg/m2, PR-80/min BP- 112/72mmHg, Spo2- 98%, Afebrile.
P/a- soft, non tender, no organomegaly, no ascites.
CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus,
abdomen soft, non tender, port sites healthy with stapler insitu and hence being discharged in stable condition.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
Gallbladder cholesterolosis with cholesterol polyposis


 F/U/C/O acute cholecystitis with acute pancreatitis


Dyslipidemia;


Hypothyroidism;


HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient was admitted in Pvt ward for cholecystectomy after getting necessary blood investigations (Hb-13, TLC-
5260, Plt-1. 5L, Na/K-140/3.38, TB/DB-0.7/0.1, AST/ALT-30/27, ALP/GGT-69/99, TP/Alb-7/4.3, CRP-1. 3 & viral markers negative). USG
abdomen revealed mild borderline GB wall thickening with maintained mural stratification -may likely represent residual
inflammation of Gallbladder. After getting informed consent and PAC fitness, patient underwent Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on
16/09/25, Intraoperative and postoperative periods was uneventful. RT removed and patient was started oral sips on POD-0 and
gradually increased as per tolerance. During hospital course, patient was managed with IVF, IV antibiotics (cefoperazone+sulbactum),
PPI, antiemetics, and symptomatic & supportive care. Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating
orals, passing flatus, abdomen soft, non tender and hence being discharged in stable condition.




                                                                                                                               Page No: 1

                                                                                            CR: 239212200390481




OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: USG W/A on 25/7/25: Gr 1 fatty liver. Rest normal.
USG HPB on 28/7/25: GB distended, wih mild diffuse wall thickening with maintained stratification. Sludge + CBD could not be
assessed.
MRCP done on 28/7/25: GB wall edema (upto 9 mm) with sludge. Mildly dilated CBD/CHD (upto 9.5mm) throughout its course with
abrupt tapering at ampulla with mild soft tissue edema at periampullary region. No filling defects. Mild diffusely bulky pancreas with
mild peripancreatic fluid.
CECT chest & abdomen was done on 30/7/25 which showed moderate diffuse GB wall thickening with edematous wall (max 8mm)
with minimal pericholecystic fluid. Prominent CBD. Bulky pancreas with fuzzy margins with minimal surrounding free fluid. Minimal
ascites & left pleural effusion.
USG W/A(09/09/25, AIIMS): LIVER-Normal, shape & size, diffusely raised hepatic echogenicity, not obscuring peri-portal region,
echogenicity s/o Grade 1 fatty liver. No IHBRD. PV-normal, hepatopetal flow, hepatic veins & intra hepatic IVC-Normal. GB-mildly
thickened GB wall with maintained mural stratification of max. thickness ~2.6mm, echo free. SPLEEN- Normal shape, size &
echotexture. CBD Prox- non dilated. PANCREAS: Normal shape, size & echotexture. Both KIDNEY-normal. Aortic & paraaortic region-
obscured. UB-Distended, normal shape size & echo free, Prostate-normal, Seminal vesicles-normal. Others:No e/o free fluid in
peritoneal cavity. Visualized bowel loops appear unremarkable. IMPRESSION:Mild borderline GB wall thickening with maintained
mural stratification -may likely represent residual inflammation of Gallbladder.
MRCP (9/9/25): Gall bladder: is distended. It shows mild symmetrical smooth circumferential wall thickening (maximum 4mm) with
maintained mural stratification. No evidence of any T2 hypointense filling defect within. No e/o any pericholecystic fluid noted.
Interface with the adjacent liver parenchyma is maintained. The cystic duct is non-dilated and opening into posterior aspect of supra-
pancreatic CBD, approximately 3cm distal to primary confluence. Biliary drainage: Conventional biliary anatomy is seen with primary
confluence formed by right and left hepatic ducts. IHBR are not dilated. CBD / CHD 4.5 mm, lumen free. Pancreas appears normal in
size and signal intensity. No evidence of any altered parenchymal signals noted. No evidence of any peripancreatic fat stranding or
collection. MPD is not dilated. Liver: is normal in size and shows normal signal intensity. No evidence of any focal lesion seen. Spleen
is normal in size and shows no focal lesion. Note is made of splenunculus measuring
8x9mm at the hilum. MPRESSION: MRCP reveals: Mild symmetrical smooth circumferential gall bladder wall thickening with
maintained mural stratification ��� represent mild residual inflammation. Non-dilated biliary system.
OPERATION PERFORMED:
Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy On 16-Sep-2025
OPERATIVE FINDINGS: GB normally distended, thin wall. Rouvier sulcus absent. HDL fatty with obscured extrahepatic biliary anatomy
due of excessive HDL fat but part of CBD & CHD visualised with ICG-NIRF cholangiography. Calots triangle,-fatty; mildly inflamed.
Cystic duct normal, lumen free; main cystic artery normal with a small soft cystic node; small accessory cystic artery arising from right
hepatic artery & entering into body of GB; confirmed with ICG- NIRF. noted. Critical view of safety with doublet view achieved. Liver &
rest of the visualized abdomen apparently normal. On cut section: GB thin walled, mucosa strawberry appearance, studded with
cholesterol polyps; thick bile with one free cholesterol polyp & ? sludge noted; No stone. Nassar grade 2
ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:
Soft diet (Low fat)
Rest for 1 week
Tab Pantoprazole 40 mg OD x 7 days
Tab Paracetamol 500 mg TDS x 2 days then SOS
Tab Domperidone 10 mg 1 TDS x 5 days
Syrup Lactitol 15 ml HS
Tab Antacid (Gelusil MPS) 1 SOS
Tab Ondansetron 4mg (Mouth dissolving, Sublingual) 1 SOS




                                                                                                                                Page No: 2

                                                                                     CR: 239212200390481




Tab Thyroxine 62.5 mcg OD continue
Tab B complex 1 OD x 15 days
Tab Vitamin C 500 mg 1 OD x 15 days
Surgical wound care as explained.
Avoid abdominal straining 1 month
Review in Endocrinology OPD for hypothyroidism / dyslipidemia.
Review in SGE OPD after 1 week for stapler removal & with Biopsy report
DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta
DISCHARGE REMARKS :
FOLLOW UP ON : 25-Sep-2025
FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Vishal Gupta
FOLLOW UP ADVICE : Review in emergency (TEM) AIIMS Bhopal/ Nearby hospital in case of persistent fever, pain abdomen, jaundice,
vomiting, abdominal distension etc.

                                      Kalan,.,Bhopal                                               Pradesh/India

D.O.A. : 28-Jul-2025 09:40            D.O.D. : 04-Aug-2025                                         D.O. Print Report: 04-Aug-2025 10:56

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
Abdominal pain x 4 days
Vomiting x 1 day
Yellowish discolouration of urine x 1 days
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Pt was apparently alright 4 days back, when he experienced discomfort & pain in epigastrium
following heavy meal, initially milder in intensity, progressed to severe abdominal pain x 1 day associated with 2-3episodes of
vomiting. For these complaints pt consulted in AIIMS emergency (TEM) where he was admitted & evaluated with labs & imaging &
was found to have acute cholecystitis. Pt was then assessed by SGE team & was admitted for further management. H/O yellowish
discolouration of urine x 1 day. No fever/GI bleed/abdominal distension. H/O similar illness in 2023, evaluated with USG & MRCP
which revealed circumferential smooth GB wall thickening & was managed conservatively. Pt is a K/C/O hypothyroidism on treatment
with T. Thyroxine. No addictions/allergy.
CASE SUMMARY: Pt is conscious, well oriented to time, place & person, afebrile. Icterus +
PR- 84/min, BP- 132/84mm Hg, SpO2- 97%
P/A - soft, tenderness + over right hypochondrium & epigastrium, not distended.
CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Pt is hemodynamically stable, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing stools, P/A soft, non tender & hence
being discharged in stable condition. Advised to collect CRP, RFT, LFT, Amylase, lipase, TPOAb reports.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
Acute cholecystitis


Acute biliary pancreatitis (mild)


GB sludge


Obstructive jaundice;
Remarks: no CBD stone


Hypothyroidism;


HOSPITAL COURSE: Pt was admitted for above mentioned complaints. Necessary blood investigations were done (TLC- 6520, Hb- 13.3,
Plt- 1.27L, CRP- 4.08, TB/DB- 5.34/2.89, AST/ALT- 513/544, ALP/GGT- 344/953, Amylase/Lipase- 3110/8086). USG W/A was done
(28/7/25) which showed distended GB showing mild diffuse wall thickness with GB sludge; MRCP was advised for CBD evaluation.




                                                                                                                              Page No: 1

                                                                                            CR: 239212200390481




MRCP (28/7/25) showed GB wall edema (upto 9 mm) with sludge. mildly dilated CBD/CHD (upto 9.5mm) throughout its course with
abrupt tapering at ampulla with mild soft tissue edema at periampullary region, no filling defects. Mild diffusely bulky pancreas with
mild peripancreatic fluid. Gastromedicine consultation was done & advise followed (Hep A & E IgM done-both negative). Repeat labs
showed improving LFT and pancreatic enzymes (TB/DB- 2.28/0.97, AST/ALT- 242/431, ALP/GGT- 334/888, Amy/lip- 895/1827). Oral sips
were started on 29/7/25, following which pt developed severe abdominal pain & discomfort for (1 day) which required multiple
analgesics. CECT chest & abdomen was done on 30/7/25 which showed moderate diffuse GB wall thickening with edematous wall
(max 8mm) with minimal pericholecystic fluid, prominent CBD, bulky pancreas with fuzzy margins with minimal surrounding free
fluid, minimal ascites & left pleural effusion. Repeat labs showed TLC- 6140, Hb- 11.9, Plt- 1.2L, TB/DB- 1.74/0.75, AST/ALT- 313/446,
ALP/GGT- 402/982, U/Cr- 24/0.97, Na/K- 136/3.41, CRP- 20.39, TG- 65, HDL/LDL- 43/111, VLDL- 13, calcium- 8.29). Oral feed gradually
resumed and gradually increased as per tolerance. Endocrinology consultation was done for hypothyroidism & advise followed
(Thyroxine dose increased). PMR consultation was done & advise followed. Labs were repeated which showed normal CBC (TLC- 4920,
Hb- 12.8, Plt- 1.58L), improving LFTs (TB/DB- 1.59/0.55, AST/ALT- 161/304, ALP/GGT- 317/804) and increased CRP (69). Pt was managed
conservatively with IVF, iv antibiotics (cefoperazone-sulbactum), PPI, analgesics, antiemetics and other symptomatic and supportive
treatment. Patient responded to conservative management with improving jaundice and resolved abdominal pain. During stay
patient remained hemodyanimically stable with no fever, adequate urine output, & no O2 requirement. Currently pt is
hemodynamically stable, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing stools, P/A soft, non-tender & hence being discharged in stable condition.
Advised to collect LFT, amylase, lipase, RFT & CRP reports & to review in OPD. Plan: USG abdomen after 2 weeks. Interval
cholecystectomy.
OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: USG W/A on 25/7/25: Gr 1 fatty liver. Rest normal.
USG HPB on 28/7/25: GB distended, wih mild diffuse wall thickening with maintained stratification. Sludge + CBD could not be
assessed.
MRCP done on 28/7/25: GB wall edema (upto 9mm) with sludge. Mildly dilated CBD/CHD (upto 9.5mm) throughout its course with
abrupt tapering at ampulla with mild soft tissue edema at periampullary region. No filling defects. Mild diffusely bulky pancreas with
mild peripancreatic fluid.
CECT chest & abdomen was done on 30/7/25 which showed moderate diffuse GB wall thickening with edematous wall (max 8mm)
with minimal pericholecystic fluid. Prominent CBD. Bulky pancreas with fuzzy margins with minimal surrounding free fluid. Minimal
ascites & left pleural effusion.
CXR : NAD (provisional)
ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:
Rest for 1 week.
Avoid fatty meal
Tab Pantoprazole + Domperidone (40/30) mg 1 OD x 7 days.
Tab Paracetamol 650 mg TDS x 3 days then SOS.
Tab Aceclofenac + Drotaverine (100/80) 1 SOS.
Tab Ondansetron 4 mg (Mouth dissolving) sublingual SOS
Syrup Antacid 2 tsf tds/ sos
Tab Thyroxine 62.5 microgram 1 OD x 10 days
Syp. Multivitamin 10ml OD
Tab UDCA 300 mg BD x 10 days.
To follow up in Endocrinology OPD for hypothyroidism.
To review in SGE OPD after 1 week with labs reports.
DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta
DISCHARGE REMARKS :




                                                                                                                                Page No: 2

                                                                                    CR: 239212200390481




FOLLOW UP ON : 11-Aug-2025
FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Vishal Gupta

pain/distension/vomiting/fever/jaundice etc

CBD                                                          9.5
CHD                                                          8.5
RHD                                                          6.8
LHD                                                          6.0
Cystic duct                                                  2.5

   ●   Pancreas - appears mildly diffusely bulky with strands of abnormal T2 hyperintense signal
       within. There is also minimal fluid in peripancreatic region, retro peritoneum, bilateral
       perinephric spaces and perisplenic regions.
   ●   Liver: is normal in size and shows normal signal intensity. No evidence of any focal lesion
       seen.
   ●   Spleen is normal in size (9 cm) and shows no focal lesion. Note is made of splenunculus
       measuring 8x9mm at the hilum.
   ●   No significant abnormal lymph nodes are noted in visualized abdomen.
   ●   Bilateral kidneys appear normal in size and shape.
   ●   Bilateral adrenals appear normal.

IMPRESSION: MRCP reveals:
   Mild diffuse edema of pancreas with minimal fluid in peripancreatic region and adjacent fluid
   ●


   compartments suggestive of acute interstitial pancreatitis (modified CTSI score 2).
   Moderate diffuse gall bladder wall thickening/edema likely inflammatory.
   ●


   Mildly dilated CHD/CBD showing abrupt tapering at ampulla with edema in peri ampullary
   ●


   region - likely represents inflammatory changes.

## Department of Pathology And Lab Medicine

**Histopathology Status :**1 Amendment/Addendum Report

**ABHA NO** : - **ABHA ADDRESS** : kawal9419781592@abdm

**CR No** : 239212200390481 **Lab/Study No.** : 250916S09835 **Coll./Study Date** : 16-Sep-25 12:25 **Patient Name** : Kawal Krishan **Age/Sex** : 55 Yr/M **Acceptance Date** : 16-Sep-25 14:54 **Sample Type/No** : Tissue Block/250916HP11227**Ward** : Private Ward **Reporting Date** : 09-Oct-25 11:09 **Dept/Unit** : Surgical Gastroenterology **Addendum Date** : 03-Oct-25 15:22

**Room/Bed** : Private Ward Room/Bed 13

# Histopathology Report

## S-9835/25

Nature of Specimen: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy specimen.

Clinical Details: Follow up case of acute cholecystitis with acute pancreatitis.

Gross Examination: Received already cut open cholecystectomy specimen measuring 4x2x0.6 cm. External surface is smooth and grey brown. Cut surface is bile stained with velvety mucosa. No stone, perforation, polyp, cystic lymph node identified. Wall thickness varies from 0.2 to 0.3 cm. Representative section in one block A.

Regross bits embedded in blocks B and C

### Microscopic examination:

Sections show wall of gall bladder with mucosal villous hyperplasia and hypertrophy with expansion of the lamina propria by sheets of foamy lipid laden macrophages. There is Rokitansky Aschoff sinus formation. The muscular layer appears mildly hypertrophied with perimuscular fibrosis and mild chronic inflammatory infiltrate. There is no dysplasia or malignancy.

Impression: Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy specimen: Chronic cholecystitis with cholesterolosis.

| Dr Sarat Manohar                                                                   Dr Sramana Mukhopadhyay |
