jay-karoria-85b758ef26::495a539ef58b.text:
CR: 239212502434968




                                              Department : Surgical Gastroenterology
                                                          Discharge Summary

CR No.: 239212502434968                 Name: Jay Karoria                                            Age/Gender: 43 Yr/M

Admission No.: 239212025075918          Department Unit: Surgical Gastroenterology (Surgical         Consultant/Faculty: Dr Vishal Gupta
                                        Gastroenterology)

Ward: Gastro Surgery Ward               Room/Bed: Gastro Srg Ward Room/ Bed 6                        Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat

 Discharge Type: Normal Discharge       Father/Spouse Name: Ramsvroop Karoria/-                      Occupation:

Contact No.: 7000151350                 Address: Galla Kothar Thatipur , Gwalior,,.,Gwalior          State/Country Madhya
                                                                                                     Pradesh/India

D.O.A. : 15-Dec-2025 10:38              D.O.D. : 11-Jan-2026                                         D.O. Print Report: 11-Jan-2026 12:45

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
Abdominal pain for 2 weeks
Vomiting for 2 weeks
Loose stools for 3 days
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient is a follow up case of acute necrotizing pancreatitis who was admitted, evaluated and
managed in the department of SGE AIIMS Bhopal from 1-8-2025 to 4-9-2025. He had gastric outlet obstruction secondary to
peripancreatic collection/pseudocyst compression in the previous admission, for which he underwent UGIE which showed mucosal
edema at antrum and NJ placement for the same. Aspiration was also done from the pancreatic head collection (around 6ml purulent
content), following which he had symptomatic relief and NJ was removed at discharge. Patient was apparently alright 2 weeks back
when he developed pain in abdomen over the epigastric region, radiating to back, following alcohol intake. He was admitted in
private hospital between 27/11/25 and 3/12/25; 3/12/25 and 14/12/25 (had one episode of UGI bleed) and took LAMA. During
evaluation, USG (27/11/25) showed acute on chronic pancreatitis and CT abdomen (3/12/25) showed coarse enlarged liver with
hepatitis, atrophic pancreas). He presented to AIIMS currently with complaints of abdominal pain for 20 days associated with
vomiting (watery)- last episode 2 days back, non bilious, aggravated with meals, associated with hiccups, temporarily relieved with
medications. History of loss of appetite present. History of loose stools around 2 to 3 times per day for 3 days. No history of
abdominal distension. No history of fever, jaundice ,oliguria, cough/breathlessness. He consumes alcohol occasionally. No known
medical comorbidities or known allergies.
CASE SUMMARY: Patient conscious, oriented to time, place and person.
Fairly nourished. No Edema/LN/clubbing/pallor/icterus are present.
Weight- 74 kg ,height- 148 cm, BMI- 33.8 kg/m2,
PR-72/min, BP- 120/80 mmhg, RR- 20, Spo2- 98%.
P/A- tenderness present at epigastric region, vague lump present in the epigastric region, no guarding/ rigidity, no scar present, no
ascites or organomegaly.
PR - no malena, normal stool staining
CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and
motion, abdomen soft, non -tender and hence being discharged in stable condition.


FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
Recurent acute on chronic pancreatitis (alchohol induced)




                                                                                                                                  Page No: 1

                                                                                             CR: 239212502434968




Gall bladder sludge


perisplenic WON


Sepsis


Acute hepatitis (resolved)


HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient was admitted in SGE ward for further management. Necessary blood investigations were done (Hb-13.5
TLC-16990, Plt-1.47L, CRP-194, Urea/Creat-19/0.58, T/D bilirubin-0.28/0.24, AST/ALT-16/11, ALP/GGT-89/34, TP/Alb-6.7/2.9, PT/INR-
15.8/1.31, S.Na-130 S.K-4.38. Started empirically on injection Meropenem at admission and completed a 14-day course. Had a
transient episode of watery vomiting for one day; following which started on clear liquids and gradually increased as per tolerance.
Gastromedicine opinion was taken for UGIE in v/o h/o UGI bleed which showed small hiatus hernia and stomach, duodenum normal.
Urgent VIR opinion was taken on 19/12/25 for drainage of peripancreatic infected collection in view of sepsis. USG abdomen
(17/12/25) showed collection in pancreatic tail region (45cc) and USG guided aspiration of 60ml purulent fluid was done and was sent
for c/s (sterile), DFA (12.5). Patient symptomatically improved partially following intervention. Fibroscan done on 20/12/25 showed F0
fibrosis. CECT abdomen done on 24/12/25 showed large collection in pancreatic tail region (4.4 x 3.4 x 10 cm) with extension into
perisplenic area (7.8 x 3.2 x 6.5cm). VIR opinion was taken for PCD insertion into the perisplenic collection due to persistent
symptoms, USG guided pigtail catheter (12fr) was inserted into the perisplenic collection. Pigtail output was purulent in nature
around 20 to 40ml daily (around 100 to 200ml for 2 days in between). DFA-7. Fungal culture showed no growth. Patient had
persistent increased TLC count (17,260). He was started on Inj Pip-taz and Inj Metronidazole, given for 5 days showed decreased TLC
(11120). VIR review was sought for residual collection. USG (29/12/25) showed collection in perisplenic region measuring 7.5x1.9cm
with pigtail insitu. On 4/1/26 his abdominal pain increased with fresh bleeding (around 100ml) in the PCD; PCD was clamped, pt
remained hemodynamically stable. Urgent CT angiogram done showed no evidence of bleed or pseudoaneurysm. Hb 11.8 -> 10.5,
INR 1.19. No fall in Hb noted and he was hemodynamically stable throughout. PCD output turned purulent with blood tinge around
10 to 20ml. VIR review for residual collection reassessment with previous CECT abdomen showed significant decrease in perisplenic
collection and advised pigtail removal. His symptoms improved significantly. Pigtail was removed on 10/1/26 (nil output). Psychiatry
opinion was taken i/v/o alcohol deaddiction and advised Tab Baclofen 20mg. During hospital course, patient managed with IV
antibiotics (Meropenem, Piptaz, Metronidazole, IVF, PPI, analgesics, antiemetics, prokinetics, and other symptomatic & supportive
care. Labs on discharge: Hb- 10.5, TLC- 9260, PLT-1,94,000. CRP- 49, LFT- WNL, RFT- WNL. Currently patient is hemodynamically stable,
ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals, passing flatus and motion, abdomen soft, non tender and hence being discharged in stable
condition.
OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: MRCP 25/09/25 AIIMS: Non-dilated biliary system. Mild enlargement and altered signal of the pancreatic
head- likely represents focal pancreatitis. There is non visualization of pancreatic duct in this region with upstream dilatation of
pancreatic duct in the body and tail of pancreas. The pancreatic duct in the uncinate process is visualized and normal in caliber. Small
lobulated soft tissue is seen in the right transverse mesocolon measuring ~27×21mm suggestive of residual necrotic collection. It is
showing significant reduction in size in comparison to previous CT abdomen dated 24.08.2025, no obvious ductal communication.
USG WA 27/11/25 OUTSIDE: Acute on chronic pancreatitis. Mild hepatomegaly with Grade 1 fatty liver.
USG WA 10/12/25 OUTSIDE: Changes of subacute pancreatitis with peri pancreatic ill defined collection, mild hepatomegaly Mild GB
sludge.
CT WA 3/12/25 OUTSIDE: Coarse enlarged liver without nodular surface or distorted architecture with caudate lobe hyperplasia –
hepatomegaly / hepatitis. Distended gall bladder filled with sludge showing edematous wall thickening and pericholecystic collection.
Right renal tiny calcific concretions are seen.Atrophic pancreas showing fuzzy border, peripancreatic fat stranding – sequelae of




                                                                                                                                  Page No: 2

                                                                                              CR: 239212502434968




previous insult. Mild free fluid seen in peritoneal cavity – ascites. Few portal, peripancreatic, pre-paraaortic, aortocaval, retrocaval and
mesenteric Lymphnodes are seen, largest measuring approx. 9 mm size. Circumscribed edematous bowel loops wall thickening seen
at bowel loops with adjacent fat stranding without significant luminal narrowing or proximal dilatation – congestion.
UGIE (14/12/2025, Aiims): Normal, Small hiatus hernia
Fibroscan (20/12/25, AIIMS): F0 fibrosis, Garde 0 fatty liver.
CECT Abdomen (24/12/2025, AIIMS): Pancreas and peripancreatic region: Pancreatic size appears bulky and edematous in the head
region with fuzzy margins. Rest of the pancreas appears mild atrophic. Pancreatic enhancement: Head of the pancreas shows ill
defined hypo enhancing area (measuring 29x12 mm) with rest of the parenchyma showing inhomogenous enhancement pattern.
Main pancreatic duct: The MPD in the distal body of pancreas is dilated (maximum diameter – 5.2 mm in proximal body region).
Calcifications: No evidence of intraductal or intraparenchymal calcifications noted. Fat stranding and extent: Significant mesenteric fat
stranding and haziness in peripancreatic region (along the head and tail) and lesser sac. Ill defined mildly enhancing inflammatory
tissue seen adjacent to the pancreatic head.Pancreatic and peripancreatic collections: Number of collections: 1. Location: extra
pancreatic. Extent: there is an ill defined irregular shaped, multiloculated thick walled peripherally enhancing heterogeneously
hypodense collection noted in peripancreatic region along the body in the lesser sac and mesenteric region, measuring approx. 4.4 x
3.4 x 10.0 cm (AP x TR x CC). It is seen extending posterosuperiorly into perisplenic region indenting on the splenic parenchyma
(along upper mid pole) and reaching till the subdiaphragmatic region, measuring approx. 7.8 x 3.2 x 6.5 cm (AP x TR x CC).
Anteroinferiorly, the collection is extending to the left transverse mesocolon with adjacent edematous thickening of the bowel. Few
small pockets of collections are seen in the perisplenic region along the upper and midpole with largest measuring ~ 2.7 x 1.1 cm is
noted at upper pole of spleen along its medial and posterior aspect in subcapsular location. Ascites: not present. Pleural effusion:
Mild amount of free fluid is noted in left pleural cavity of maximum thickness ~ 2.1 cm with underlying subsegmental
consolidated/collapsed lung parenchyma. Vessels: Portal vein appears patent with no evidence of thrombosis. SMV appears patent
with no evidence of thrombosis. Splenic artery and vein appear patent. Splenic artery shows tortuous in its entire course. Segmental
focal narrowing seen involving mid part of splenic vein with normal contrast opacification. Gastroduodenal artery: No evidence of
focal outpouching noted. Few tortuous collaterals seen in the peripancreatic and lienorenal space. Edematous wall thickening seen
involving along the transverse colon, splenic flexure and greater curvature of stomach. Multiple subcentimeteric to enlarged lymph
nodes are seen in peripancreatic, aortocaval and left paraaortic regions, largest measuring ~ 16 x 10 mm – likely reactive. Liver is
normal in size, shape, attenuation and enhancement pattern. No IHBRD is seen. Hepatic vessels appear normal. Portal vein is normal.
Gall bladder is distended and wall thickness is normal. No obvious hyperdense / calcified calculi are seen (USG is the modality of
choice for GB calculi). CBD appears normal in caliber. Spleen is normal in size, shape, attenuation and enhancement pattern. Both
kidneys are normal in size, shape and CT attenuation with normal cortical enhancement. PCS appears normal. No obvious
hydronephrosis is seen. Both ureters are normal in caliber. A well-defined non enhancing hypodense cystic lesion measuring approx.
5 x 5 mm noted in the cortex of lower pole of left kidney with no e/o internal septations or solid components suggestive of simple cyst
– Bosniak 1 cyst. Thickening of left anterior renal fascia. Thin strip of perinephric fluid is seen along left side. Impression:Pancreatic
head appears bulky and edematous with ill-defined hypoenhancing areas, while the rest of the pancreas shows heterogeneous post-
contrast enhancement. The body and tail are mildly atrophic with dilatation of the main pancreatic duct. There is significant
peripancreatic inflammation with fat stranding and inflammatory soft tissue seen adjacent to the pancreatic head. A large,
multiloculated, peripherally enhancing peripancreatic collection is noted in the lesser sac and mesentery, extending into the
perisplenic and subdiaphragmatic regions, along with small subcapsular perisplenic collections. Reactive inflammatory changes are
seen involving the transverse colon, splenic flexure of the colon, and the greater curvature of the stomach. Mild left pleural effusion is
also present.
USG WA 16/12/25 AIIMS: A well defined hypoechoic collection with no internal vascularity on CD T2 measuring 64x31x39mm (45
cc)noted at pancreatic tail region abutting the splenic surface. Mild left pleural effusion. GB normal & echofree, Liver - normal, No
IHBRD




                                                                                                                                   Page No: 3

                                                                                       CR: 239212502434968




OPERATION PERFORMED:
Pigtail innsertion in perisplenic collection On 26-Dec-2025
OPERATIVE FINDINGS: Under all aseptic precautions with LA cover USG guidance 12 Fr pigtail catheder was inserted into the
perisplenic collection
SINGLE TIME ASPIRATION On 17-Dec-2025
OPERATIVE FINDINGS: Under aseptic condition and USG guidance 60ml of purulent free fluid aspiration was done from the left sub
diaphragmatic area.
ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:
Normal diet, Low fat diet
Rest for 1 week.
Strict abstinence of alcohol.
T. PANTOPRAZOLE 40 mg OD x 7 days
T. PCM 500 mg TDS X 3 DAYS THEN SOS
T. METOCLOPRAMIDE 10mg TDS X 5 DAYS
SYP LACTULOSE 20 ml HS
T. BACLOFEN 20MG 1 OD
Collect CT Angiography report.
Review in SGE OPD in Pancreas clinic on Thursday
DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta
DISCHARGE REMARKS :
FOLLOW UP ON : 19-Jan-2026
FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Vishal Gupta
FOLLOW UP ADVICE : Review in TEM, AIIMS Bhopal/Nearby Hospital for persistent abd pain/ vomiting/fever/ abd distension/blood in
vomiting or stools etc.

Dr Basil Babu                                                    Dr Vishal Gupta

CR: 239212502434968




                                             Department : Surgical Gastroenterology
                                                         Discharge Summary

CR No.: 239212502434968               Name: Jay Karoria                                            Age/Gender: 43 Yr/M

Admission No.: 239212025050209        Department Unit: Surgical Gastroenterology (Surgical         Consultant/Faculty: Dr Vishal Gupta
                                      Gastroenterology)

Ward: Gastro Surgery Ward             Room/Bed: Gastro Srg Ward Room/ Bed 12                       Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat

 Discharge Type: Normal Discharge     Father/Spouse Name: Ramsvroop Karoria/-                      Occupation:

Contact No.: 7000151350               Address: Galla Kothar Thatipur , Gwalior,,.,Gwalior          State/Country Madhya
                                                                                                   Pradesh/India

D.O.A. : 18-Aug-2025 13:21            D.O.D. : 04-Sep-2025                                         D.O. Print Report: 04-Sep-2025 10:51

CHIEF COMPLAINTS:
Pain Abdomen since 5 months
Vomiting since 5 months
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient was apparently asymptomatic till March 2025 when he developed acute pain abdomen (upper
abdomen; not radiating; severe in intensity; not associated with food intake), associated with multiple vomiting (gastric in nature); not
associated with fever, jaundice, melena, or hematemesis. He was managed conservatively elsewhere at a private hospital (NPO, iv
analgesics); discharged after 1 week. Patient had similar 5-6 episodes requiring hospital admission, the last (9���17 August 25 at
Arogyadham Hospital, Gwalior). Hx of alcohol & smoking present since 2008 & stopped 2 months back. No known medical
comorbidities (DM, HTN, COPD). Drug history: Nil. No known allergies.


CASE SUMMARY: O/E: Conscious oriented to time,place and person, fairly nourished.
No Edema/LN/clubbing/pallor/icterus
Weight- 50 kg ,height- 162 cm, BMI- 19.1 kg/m2.
PR-78/min BP- 110/70 mmhg RR- 20 Spo2- 98%.
P/A-Mild epigastric & right upper quadrant tenderness, soft, no organomegaly.
CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Currently patient is hemodynamically stable, ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating orals full liquids and soft
diet, passing flatus and motion, abdomen soft, non tender. Patient is being discharged in a stable condition.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
AP - Acute pancreatitis;
Remarks: ETHANOL RELATED


Gastric outlet obstruction
Remarks: secondary to peripancreatic collection/pseudo cyst compression


GB sludge


peripancreatic & intrabdominal collection, infected


HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient was admitted in SGE ward for above mentioned complaints. Necessary routine investigation done.
CBC/RFT/LFT -WNL, PT/INR ��� 16.1/1.4, S.Prot /Alb ��� 5.4/2.9 , Amylase / Lipase ��� 95/109, CRP ��� 22 ). He had
multiple episodes of vomiting. RT was placed (bilious output). Medical gastroenterology opinion was sought, UGIE was done, revealed




                                                                                                                                Page No: 1

                                                                                            CR: 239212502434968




extrinsic compression with mucosal edema seen at antropylorus, adult UGI Scope negotiated with mild resistance into D1; s/o Acute
Pancreatitis, GOO, Mucosal edema at Antrum. USG revealed (20/8/25) collection 23x15mm anterior to antrum with thickening of
antrum. Cardiology consultation was sought for management of hypertension, advised Telma AM and BP monitoring. He had febrile
episodes for 2 days. TLC- 10,160, CRP- 168; hence, IV antibiotic (meropenem) started. NJ placement done i/v/o GOO. NJ feed started &
gradually increased as per diet chart. Patient tolerated full NJ feed. CECT W/A (24/08/25, AIIMS) revealed an irregular heterogeneously
hypodense collection in the transverse mesocolon (4.8 �� 3.2 �� 4.0 cm) extending to the anterior wall of the pylorus, where a
defined collection (3.4 �� 2.5 �� 3.0 cm) caused luminal compression and narrowing of gastric lumen with GOO. VIR Consultation
sought for aspiration of intraabdominal collections. Single time aspiration of pus done (6ml). Pus C/S reported Klebsiella Pneumoniae
sensitive to Amikacin, Amoxiclav, Ampicillin Sulbactum, Cefixime, Cefoperazone Sulbactum, Ceftazidime, Ceftriaxone,, Levofloxacin.
Pus Fungal c/s awaited. CRP-62. Patient responded well to treatment; oral intake was gradually initiated alongside NJ feeds, which
were tapered as he progressed to a full oral diet (full liquids and soft) that he tolerated. During hospital course, patient managed with
IV antibiotics (Levofloxacin, Meropenem, IVF, iv PPI, iv analgesics, Iv antiemetics, single time aspiration of infected pancreatic
collection, and other symptomatic & supportive care with symptomatic response. Labs on discharge: CBC/RFT/LFT -WNL, PT/INR
��� 16.1/1.4, S. Prot /Alb ��� 5.4/2.9 , Amylase - awaited , CRP ��� 62 Currently patient is hemodynamically stable,
ambulatory, afebrile, tolerating oral full liquid and soft diet, passing flatus and motion, abdomen soft, non tender. NJ removed at
discharge.


OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: USG 10/3/25 (outside): Mild hepatomegaly with Grade II fatty liver. GB well distended. No calculous.
Minimal peripancreatic fat inflammation near head of pancreas. Early pancreatitis. Small Lt. renal calculus. Gaseous bowel loops.
USG 10/4/25 (outside): Liver normal. GB- partially contracted. Echofree lumen. A cystic lesion (7 �� 8 mm size) seen around head and
body of pancreas. H/o pancreatic pseudocyst.
USG 14/7/25 (outside): Mild hepatomegaly, GB- partially contracted. Echofree lumen. Bulky pancreas with heterogeneous
echotexture. S/o pancreatitis.
USG 11/8/25 (outside): Mildly edematous peripancreatic fat with edema of pyloric antrum and 1st part of duodenum. Mild ascites. GB-
Partially contracted, echofree lumen.
CT Scan CECT W/A 12/7/25 (outside): Subacute pancreatitis with pseudopancreatic cyst. Nonspecific mesenteric and retroperitoneal
lymphadenopathy.
CECT W/A 10/3/25 (outside): f/s/o Severe acute necrotising pancreatitis with modified CTSI 6/10. Minimal ascites. Hepatomegaly and
diffuse steatosis.
CECT W/A 30/7/25 (outside): Short segment heterogeneously and moderately enhancing transverse colonic wall thickening with
surrounding desmoplastic reaction and lymphadenopathy, along with a thick-walled loculated collection in the greater sac.
UGIE (20/08/25, AIIMS): Extrinsic compression with mucosal edema seen at antropylorus, adult UGI Scope negotiated with mild
resistance into D1. Impression:f/u/c/o Acute Pancreatitis, GOO, Mucosal edema at Antrum
USG W/A (20/08/25, AIIMS): Hyperechoic pancreas with irregular dilatation of MPD with few hyperechoic focii within the pancreatic
parenchyma s/o sequalae to previous pancreatitis. Small loculated collection anterior to gastric antrum. GB Sludge.
CECT W/A 24/08/25 (AIIMS): An irregular shaped, ill defined walled heterogeneously hypoechoic collection measuringapprox. 4.8 x 3.2
x 4.0 cm (TR x AP x CC) noted in the transverse mesocolon, extending till the anterior wall of the stomach near the pylorus, forming a
defined collection, measuring approx. 3.4 x 2.5 x 3.0 cm (TR x AP x CC) in the anterior wall of the pylorus, causing compression and
narrowing of the gastric lumen with significant surrounding fat stranding in greater omentum and lessor sac. The fat stranding is
seen extending till the GB fossa region with no obvious GB wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. There is an ill defined hypodensity
with surrounding fat stranding is noted in the region of neck of pancreas and the posterior wall of the pylorus with suspicious
communication of the MPD with the collection. The MPD in the distal body and tail of pancreas region is dilated (maximum diameter
��� 5.6 mm in mid body region) Head of the pancreas appears hypo enhancing with rest of the parenchyma showing normal




                                                                                                                                 Page No: 2

                                                                                            CR: 239212502434968




enhancement pattern. Multiple, sub centimetric and borderline enlarged sized, homogenously enhancing lymph nodes are noted in
the peripancreatic region, peri-portal and periGB region, largest measuring approx. 10 x 9 mm in peripancreatic region with
surrounding fat stranding. NG tube is noted in situ with its tip is noted near the D1-D2 junction. Liver- mildly enlarged ��� 17 cm,
however normal. A well defined non enhancing hypodense cystic lesion measuring approx. 5 x 5 mm noted in the cortex of lower
pole of left kidney with no e/o internal septations or solid components suggestive of simple cyst ��� Bosniak 1 cyst. IMPRESSION:
Irregular, ill-defined walled collections in the transverse mesocolon and anterior wall of pylorus, with associated fat stranding
extending into greater omentum and lesser sac. The anterior pyloric collection causes compression and luminal narrowing of gastric
outlet - gastric outlet obstruction (GOO). Ill-defined hypodensity with surrounding fat stranding at pancreatic neck and posterior wall
of pylorus, with suspicious communication of MPD with the collection with dilated distal MPD.Head of pancreas shows
hypoenhancement; rest of parenchyma enhances normally. Multiple subcentimetric and borderline enlarged homogenously
enhancing nodes in peripancreatic, periportal and peri-GB regions - likely reactive.Mild hepatomegaly.
ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:
High Protein High Calorie Soft Diet
Strict alcohol abstinence.
T. Levofloxacin 750 mg OD x 2 days
T. Omeprazole 20mg OD x 7 days
T. TELMA AM (40/5) mg OD continue
T. Vit C 500mg OD x 14 days
T. Paracetamol 500mg SOS
Syp B complex 1 tsp BD
Protein Powder 1 scoop in 100ml Milk TDS
Sup Lactulose 10ml HS
MRI+ MRCP scheduled on 25/09/2025.
Review in Cardiology OPD for hypertension.
Review in SGE OPD (Pancreas clinic) on Thursday
DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta
DISCHARGE REMARKS :
FOLLOW UP ON : 11-Sep-2025
FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Vishal Gupta
FOLLOW UP ADVICE : Review in TEM, AIIMS Bhopal/nearby hospital in case of fever/pain/vomiting etc.
Summary Prepared By                                                 Summary Approved By

Dr Gourav Singh Rajput                                              Dr Vishal Gupta




                                                                                                                                Page No: 3

239212502434968 DATE: 25/09/2025 CLINICAL DETAILS:

- K/c/o acute necrotizing pancreatitis-alcohol induced.
- CECT Abdomen AIIMS- August 2025- Irregular, ill-defined walled collections in the transverse mesocolon and anterior wall of pylorus, with associated fat stranding extending into greater omentum and lesser sac. The anterior pyloric collection causes compression and luminal narrowing of gastric outlet - gastric outlet obstruction (GOO), with suspicious communication of MPD with the collection with dilated distal MPD. ll-defined hypodensity with surrounding fat stranding at pancreatic neck and posterior wall of pylorus. ●
- Currently to assess the status of the collection and the pancreatic duct.

# OBSERVATIONS:

- Pancreas: Mild enlargement and altered T2 FS hyperintense signal of the pancreatic head, with mild peri-pancreatic fat stranding noted. There is non visualization of pancreatic duct in this region with upstream dilatation of pancreatic duct in the body and tail of pancreas. The pancreatic duct in the uncinate process is visualized and normal in caliber. No evidence of anomalous pancreatico-biliary junction/long common channel.No obvious mass/soft tissue lesion is seen in the peri ampullary region. ●
- Small, ill defined, lobulated T2/T2 FS intermediate to hypointense soft tissue is seen in the right transverse mesocolon measuring 27x21mm, anterior to the pylorus-suggestive of residual necrotic collection. No obvious ductal communication. ●
- Gall bladder: is distended. No evidence of any T2 hypointense filling defects within the lumen. The cystic duct shows low medial insertion into the common hepatic duct. ●
- CBD: is of normal caliber, showing smooth distal tapering towards ampulla with no evidence of T2 hypointense filling defect noted. ●

## Summary

**Study ID:** AP-NSVT-001

**Classification:** **NON-SVT CASE**

**Key Points:**
1. 43-year-old male with recurrent acute on chronic necrotizing pancreatitis (alcohol-induced)
2. Etiology: Alcohol (occasional use since 2008)
3. **NO SPLANCHNIC VENOUS THROMBOSIS documented on multiple CT scans including CT Angiography**
4. Splenic vein shows focal segmental narrowing but PATENT with normal contrast opacification
5. Portal vein and SMV explicitly documented as PATENT
6. Complicated course over 3 admissions with:
   - Gastric outlet obstruction (1st admission - resolved)
   - Infected peripancreatic collection (Klebsiella)
   - Perisplenic WON requiring aspiration and PCD
   - Sepsis (resolved)
   - Acute hepatitis (resolved)
   - UGI bleed (1 episode)
   - PCD bleeding (resolved spontaneously)
   - GB sludge
7. Managed with IV antibiotics, USG-guided aspiration and PCD insertion
8. Alive at discharge in stable condition
9. Follow-up scheduled: 19-Jan-2026

**Discharge Advice:**
- Normal diet, low fat
- Rest for 1 week
- **Strict abstinence from alcohol**
- Tab Pantoprazole 40mg OD x 7 days
- Tab PCM 500mg TDS x 3 days then SOS
- Tab Metoclopramide 10mg TDS x 5 days
- Syp Lactulose 20ml HS
- Tab Baclofen 20mg OD (alcohol deaddiction)
- Collect CT Angiography report
- Review in SGE OPD Pancreas clinic (Thursday)

---

**Data Collected By:** Dr Sarath Chandrabhatla
**Last Updated:** 15-January-2026

yasin-khan-9d2126b2c0::0c83bc9cdb14.text:
![](_page_0_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_0_Picture_3.jpeg) # Department : Surgical Gastroenterology Death Summary | CR No.: 239212503623306 | Name: Yasin Khan | Age/Gender: 57 Yr/M | |--------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------| | Admission No.: 239212025074620 | Department Unit: Surgical Gastroenterology (Surgical
Gastroenterology) | Consultant/Faculty: Dr Vishal Gupta | | Ward: Surgical I C U | Room/Bed: Surgical ICU Room 011022/ Bed 1 | Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat | | Discharge Type: Death | Father/Spouse Name: Bashir Khan/- | Occupation: | | Contact No.: 9340417375 | Address: .,,.,Damoh | State/Country Madhya
Pradesh/India | | D.O.A. : 08-Dec-2025 23:14 | D.O.D. : 23-Dec-2025 | D.O. Print Report: 23-Dec-2025 17:31 | ## CHIEF COMPLAINTS: Abdominal Pain (on/off) –3.5 months back Vomiting – 2 months On and off fever – 2 months HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Pt presented initially in September 2025 with Acute Biliary Necrotising Pancreatitis (Md CTSI - 8/10) secondary to Gall stone pancreatitis. After initial conservative management he developed WOPN which required step-up endoscopic intervention, he was assessed on 30/10/25 with UGIE and was planned for EUS CG on 19/11/25. EUS CG and LAMS placement was performed on 19/11/25 and drained 500ml dirty brown fluid f/b 2 sessions of DEN (28/11 and 3/12) . During the same admission from 3/12/25 - 8/12/25, patient developed AKI and severe sepsis which recovered over time under ICU management. Post recovery he developed abdominal distension with septated ascites (purulent on aspiration).Ncct imaging with oral contrast done on 7/12/25: Pneumoperitoneum? Suspected duodenal perforation. No known comorbidities, addictions or allergies. No past surgical history. CASE SUMMARY: GC: poor. Edema present No LN/clubbing/pallor/icterus are present. Weight- 61.7 kg ,height- 173 cm, BMI- 20.6 kg/m2 ,PR-66/min BP- 129/69 mmhg RR- 20 Spo2- 98% .On examination-Chest- B/L air entry present ,P/A– soft, gaseous distention present, tenderness present, no guarding/rigidity . No ascites/scars. CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Patient expired on 23-12-2025 at 4.30 pm HOSPITAL COURSE: He was admitted in TEM with the above mentioned complaints and routine blood investigations were done.( Hb-8.7 TLC-14700, Plt-2.2L, urea/creat-77/1.13 AST/ALT-49/22 , ALP/GGT-,TP/Alb-5.36/2.43PT/INR 13/1.09 T/D bilirubin 0.79/0.61 S.Na 142 S.K 4.99& viral markers tested negative). Gastrosurgery opinion was taken and advice was given. He was later transferred to SGE ward on 13-12-205. He was started on iv antibiotics, RT was kept on continuous drainage and was planned for CECT Abdomen. CECT was done on 17-12-2025 and was suggestive of sealed off perforation. USG doppler was done in view of b/l pedal edema and revealed right LL SFT and was started on heparin as per CTVS advice. He was planned for emergency laparotomy in view persistent undrained collections, however was deferred in view of absence of A negative blood component in blood bank. VIR opinion was taken and USG guided pigtail was placed into peritoneal cavity and it drained around 4l of purulent ascites along with hemorrhagic fluid. After informed consent and high risk consent he underwent emergency Exploratory laparotomy with drainage of intra abdominal collections and hemoperitoneum with evacuation of clots adhesiolysis with peritoneal lavage on 19-12-2025. Intraop he was started on ionotrope and required high dose nor adr for maintain BP, along with blood transfusion. Plan for necrosectomy and FJ was abandoned in view of hypotension and patient was shifted intubated with ionotropic support to SICU. Postoperative labs Hb-9.5 TLC-11870, Plt-46000, urea/creat-77/1.13 AST/ALT-49/22 , ALP/GGT-,TP/Alb-5.36/2.43PT/INR 13/1.09 T/D bilirubin 0.79/0.61 S.Na 142 S.K 4.99. Hematology opinion was taken for thrombocytopenia. One unit RDAP was transfused on POD 2. He was extubated on POD 2 and was shifted to SGE HDU on POD3. RT output decreased and he was started on RT feeds from POD 3 which he tolerated. Platelets ![](_page_1_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_1_Picture_3.jpeg) continued to fall in the post operative day 3 and 4 (25,000). On POD4, patient started having tachypnoea and required oxygen support. Despite high flow oxygen support, he was not maintaining saturation and SICU opinion was taken for intubation. He was later shifted to SICU on 23-12-2025 and was intubated and kept on ventilator with FiO2 requirement of 100%. He was also started on Nadr. At 4 pm, he arrested and CPR was given according to ATLS protocol. However couldn't be revived and was later declared dead at 4.30 pm. During hospital course, patient managed with, iv antibiotics( meropenem, metronidazole, fluconazole) iv PPI, iv antipyretics, Iv antiemetics, iv diclofenac, symptomatic & supportive care. OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: CT Abdomen (9/9/25, outside):Liver is mild enlarged in size measuring approximately 16.9 cm with decreased parenchymal density suggestive of mild hepatomegaly with fatty infiltration ofliver. Pancreas is mild bulky in size with heterogeneous and mild oedematous attenuation. Pancreatic parenchyma shows heterogenous enhancement with areas of body and tailnecrosis and ill-defined peripancreatic, epigastric and perigastric collection. Pancreatic duct is normal. Fat planes and mesentery surrounding pancreas and epigastric region show significant thickeningand soft tissue stranding with lateral conal fascial fat stranding also involving lesser sac, perigastric, hepatogastric and perisplenic region, omental and mesenteric fat stranding. Multiple sub-centimetric lymph nodes – suggest possibility of acute necrotizing pancreatitis (Advise serum Lipase Amylase correlation). (Modified CTseverityindex 8/10). Minimal right sided pleural effusion is also seen with adjacent lung atelectasis. Mild left pleural effusion with underlying collapse/consolidation of lung parenchyma noted. Minimal ascites noted.Defect of size 4 mm seen at umbilicus with herniation of omental fat – s/o tiny umbilical hernia.Left inguinal hernia with defect of size 21 mm through abdominal fat and bowel loop herniating without obstruction.Right inguinalhernia with defect of size 9 mm through abdominal fat herniating without obstruction. USG WA (22/10/25 OUTSIDE) Relatively well defined collection with the internal echoes and echogenic content seen in epigastric region (peripancreatic) s/o walled off necrosis. Hepatomegaly. EUS (30/10/25 OUTSIDE)- Acute necrotising pancreatitis with WOPN USG WA (15/11/25 OUTSIDE)- Relatively well defined collection with the internal echoes and echogenic content seen in epigastric region (peripancreatic) s/o walled off necrosis ,as compared to previous report, (8x10.7x14.4cm) there is increase in size of lesion. Hepatomegaly. USG Abdomen (19/11/25 OUTSIDE)- GB shows fine sludge within lumen. Pancreas- Inhomogeneous echotexture. Mild adjacent fat stranding or collection seen. Approx 65x26mm sized hypoechoic collection seen adjacent to body. No free fluid inside the peritoneal cavity. No significant mesenteric lymph nodes seen. Bowel loops not dilated shows normal peristalsis. EUS (19/11/25 OUTSIDE)- WOPN, EUS guided cytogastrostomy done. USG WA (28/11/25 OUTSIDE)- Hepatomegaly. Gallbladder sludge. Minimal ascites. Endoscopy (28/11/25 OUTSIDE)- Direct endoscopic necrosectomy done. USG Abdomen (3/12/25 OUTSIDE)- Hepatomegaly. Visualised part of pancreas appears atrophic. B/L raised renal echotexture. Endoscopy (3/12/25 OUTSIDE)- DEN done. USG WA (6/12/25 OUTSIDE)- Hepatomegaly. Moderate ascites with coarse echoes and sepation.Visualised part of pancreas appears atrophic. B/L raised renal echotexture. CT Abdomen (7/12/25)Pancreas is partly replaced by oblong shaped mixed density collection showing multiple air pockets abutting duodenal jejunal junction — pancreatitis with suspicious pancreaticoduodenal fistula.Mild to moderate ascites with pneumoperitoneum. Left inguinal hernia(27mm defect).Bilateral pleural effusion. USG (10/12/25 OUTSIDE): Moderate to gross amount of fluid noted in peritoneal cavity with multiple septations, free floating echoes within. Mild hepatomegaly. GB sludge. Pancreas obscured by GB sludge. CECT ABDOMEN (15/12/25 AIIMS): Acute necrotizing pancreatitis with few WON in anterior pararenal space as described above. Modified CTSI- 10/10 s/o severe pancreatitis. Gross hydropneumoperitoneum. On positive oral and rectal contrast, no demonstrable leak I seen from the bowel loops into the loculated fluid/ WON. Splenic vein not visualized- possibly compressed by mass effect by ![](_page_2_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_2_Picture_3.jpeg) collection/ thrombosed. Few serpiginous collaterals are in perigastric, peripancreatic region. Left indirect inguinal hernia. Post procedural changes with metallic cystogastrostomy tube position USG color doppler (15/12/25 AIIMS): No obvious DVT in bilateral CFV, popliteal vein and left SFV. An eccentric focal partial thrombus noted in right distal SFV causing complete luminal obstruction ### OPERATION PERFORMED: Exploratory laparotomy with drainage of intra-abdominal collections & hemoperitoneum with evacuations of clots, adhesiolysis with peritoneal lavage. On 19-Dec-2025 OPERATIVE FINDINGS: Approx ~2.8L hemorrhagic purulent ascitic fluid drained. Multiple old blood clots (~500 CC) evacuated, mainly from right lower quadrant around PCD entry point (? PCD insertion trauma) & some blood clots from left lower quadrant. No other obvious source of bleeding identified. Thick purulent collection with clots in right iliac fossa and pelvis. Rt subphrenic collection present ~ 500 ml- purulent, hemorrhagic, with a lot of pus flakes over entire liver surface. No obvious bile/ enteric leak/staining seen Thickened & edematous stomach, LAMS could not be localised. Extensive intraabdominal adhesions between stomach, liver, omentum, intestine and parietal wall. Greater omentum thickened, densely adhered to underlying small bowel & transverse colon up to pelvis & forming a cocoon & obscuring inframesocolic compartment & entire small bowel. Thick pus seen coming out from one point in the interbowel space in the left lower abdomen, possibly communicating with the peripancreatic WON collection- cavity drained and irrigated. Small bowel could not be delineated completely due to dense interbowel adhesions. Peritoneal lavage done in all quadrants. PCD removed. PCD entry site was closed inside with prolene 2-0. Small serosal small bowel repaired with silk 3-0. Planned feeding jejunostomy deferred as small bowel was inaccessible due to adhesions and cocoon-like abdomen. Necrosectomy and stent removal also deferred due to intraoperative hemodynamic instability with increasing inotropic support. DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta DISCHARGE REMARKS : CAUSE OF DEATH : Multiorgan dysfunction syndrome DATE OF DEATH : 23-Dec-2025 Summary Prepared By Summary Approved By Dr Maidh Pavneet Singh Dr Vishal Gupta

# CECT ABDOMEN CLINICAL NOTES:

- Case of acute biliary necrotizing pancreatitis s/p EUS (outside) with gross pneumoperitoneum and pancreatic ascites and bilateral pleural effusion and hypoalbuminemia. ●
- USG W/A (15/11/25, outside): increase in size of WON

# OBSERVATIONS:

Pancreas and peripancreatic region:

- Pancreas thickness: 1.6 cm at proximal body
- Pancreatic enhancement: heterogenous with complete replacement of head, distal body and tail by necrotic collection. Only thin residual parenchyma seen at head and uncinate process.
- Main pancreatic duct: not visualized
- Calcifications: no evidence of intraparenchymal/intraductal calcifications noted
- Fat stranding and Extent: Diffuse mesenteric fat stranding and haziness in peripancreatic region and lesser sac with thickening of left anterior renal fascia.

### Pancreatic and peripancreatic collections:

- Post procedural changes are noted in the form of mettalic cystogastrostomy tube in situ with its one end in the cardia- proximal body of stomach and other end entering into a thick walled peripherally enhancing hypodense collection of size 4.8x9.5x7.2 cm (APXTRXCC) containing multiple air foci within. This collection is noted communicating with another morphologically similar collection in its antero-inferior aspect of size~ 4.3x3.9 cm, it is noted displacing and compressing the adjacent jejunal loops. ●
- Few other peripherally enhancing intercommunicating hypodense collections are noted in peripancreatic space at the pancreatic head region containing air foci within, largest of size~2.8x3.2 cm. ●

Ascites: Gross amount of loculated peritoneal fluid seen, extending to bilateral subdiaphragmatic region and causing indentation over surface of liver with compression of parenchyma. Mass effect is also seen over the greater curvature of stomach. Large air- fluid level is seen within the loculated collection s/o hydro-pneumoperitoneum. This collection is also extending into the bilateral iliac fossa region.

Pleural effusion: Mild amount of free fluid is noted in bilateral pleural cavity (left> right) of maximum thickness~ 3.4 cm on left side and ~1.9 cm on right side with collapsed/consolidated lung parenchyma.

## Vessels:

- Portal vein: appears patent with no evidence of thrombosis.
- SMV: appears patent with no evidence of thrombosis.
- Splenic artery and vein: splenic vein not visualized- possibly compressed by mass effect by collection/ thrombosed. Few serpiginous collaterals are in perigastric, peripancreatic region.
- Gastroduodenal artery: No evidence of focal outpouching noted.
  - Marked diffuse fat stranding is noted in abdominal and pelvic subcutaneous tissue- diffuse anasarca ●
  - Prominent azygous and hemiazygous vein is noted.
  - Left indirect inguinal hernia is seen upto superficial inguinal ring with collapsed descending colon loops seen herniating. ●
  - On positive oral and rectal contrast, no demonstrable leak is seen from the bowel loops into the loculated fluid/ WON. ●
  - Liver- normal in size, shape, attenuation and enhancement pattern. No IHBRD is seen. Hepatic vessels appear normal. Portal vein is normal. ●
  - Gall bladder- Is distended and wall thickness is normal. No obvious hyperdense / calcified calculi are seen (USG is the modality of choice for GB calculi) ●
  - CBD appears normal in caliber.
  - Spleen- Is normal in size, shape, attenuation and enhancement pattern. No obvious focal

### /diffuse pathology is seen

- Both kidneys are normal in size, shape and CT attenuation with normal cortical enhancement.PCS appears normal. No obvious hydronephrosis is seen. Both ureters are normal in caliber. A tiny Bosniak 1 cyst is noted at upper pole cortex of left kidney. ●
- Both adrenals appear normal.
- Urinary bladder- Is empty with foley's in situ. Prostate appears normal.
- Stomach, small bowel appear normal. No e/o any abnormal dilatation / wall thickening noted. ●
- Visualized spine shows degenerative changes in the form of periarticular erosions and sclerosis at L5-S1 vertebral level with narrowing of disc space and vacuum phenomenon. ●
- Eccentric athero-calcific plaque is noted in abdominal aorta and right common iliac artery, not causing significant luminal narrowing. ●
- Ryle's tube in situ.

### IMPRESSION: CECT Abdomen reveals-

- Acute necrotizing pancreatitis with few WON in anterior pararenal space as described above. Modified CTSI- 10/10 s/o severe pancreatitis. ●
- Gross hydropneumoperitoneum. On positive oral and rectal contrast, no demonstrable leak is seen from the bowel loops into the loculated fluid/ WON. ●
- splenic vein not visualized- possibly compressed by mass effect by collection/ thrombosed. Few serpiginous collaterals are in perigastric, peripancreatic region. ●
- Left indirect inguinal hernia
- Post procedural changes with metallic cystogastrostomy tube position as described.

CLINICAL DETAILS:

K/co Acute biliary necrotizing pancreatitis with WOPN S/P EUS ●

– Cystogastrostomy

( 19/11/25), S/P Direct endoscopic necrosectomy ( 28/11/25,

3/12/25) with gross pneumoperitoneum

● C/o Abdominal pain, vomiting

suspicious pancreaticodudoenal fistula

TECHNIQUE:

Contrast study was performed by instillation of iohexol in 1:1 ●

dilution via oral route.

Plain Film-NG tube and cystogastrostomy stent is noted in situ.

- No obvious leak could be identified.
- No evidence of stricture, obstruction, diverticulum or ulceration is seen. ●
- No evidence of any growth is noted.

Impression: in a K/c/o Acute biliary necrotizing pancreatitis with WOPN S/P EUS – Cystogastrostomy and Direct endoscopic necrosectomy, current study reveals:

- Pneumoperitoneum .
- No obvious leak could be identified.

---

**Study ID:** `AP-SVT-006`

- [ ] Edematous (Interstitial)
- [x] Necrotizing (>50% necrosis - head, distal body, tail replaced)

### Complications

#### GIT Complications
- [ ] Perforation (Suspected duodenal perforation - sealed off)
- [ ] Intestinal obstruction
- [ ] Gastric outlet obstruction
- [ ] Fistula (Suspicious pancreaticoduodenal fistula)
- [ ] Ischemia
- [ ] Bleeding
- [x] Other: Gross hydropneumoperitoneum, purulent ascites, adhesions (cocoon abdomen)

**Arterial - Pseudoaneurysm:** [ ] No (GDA specifically evaluated - no outpouching)

- [ ] Portal Vein (Patent)
- [ ] Superior Mesenteric Vein (Patent)

## Summary

**Study ID:** AP-SVT-006

**Classification:** **SVT CASE - PROBABLE SPLENIC VEIN INVOLVEMENT (DECEASED)**

**Key Points:**
1. 57-year-old male with severe acute biliary necrotizing pancreatitis (Modified CTSI 10/10)
2. Etiology: Biliary (GB sludge documented)
3. **SPLANCHNIC VENOUS STATUS:**
   - Portal Vein: PATENT
   - SMV: PATENT
   - **Splenic Vein: NOT VISUALIZED - possibly compressed by mass effect or thrombosed**
   - Collaterals present in perigastric, peripancreatic region
4. Complex clinical course with:
   - WOPN requiring EUS-CG with LAMS + 2 sessions of DEN (outside hospital)
   - Severe sepsis with AKI (recovered)
   - Gross hydropneumoperitoneum, purulent septated ascites
   - Suspected sealed-off duodenal perforation
   - Emergency laparotomy for hemoperitoneum (POD0 at AIIMS)
   - Severe thrombocytopenia (25 K/µL)
   - DVT (right distal SFV) - started on heparin
5. Underwent emergency exploratory laparotomy on 19-Dec-2025
   - 2.8L hemorrhagic purulent ascitic fluid drained
   - 500cc blood clots evacuated
   - Necrosectomy deferred due to hemodynamic instability
6. Post-operative course complicated by:
   - Persistent thrombocytopenia
   - Respiratory failure (POD4)
   - Required intubation with 100% FiO2
   - High-dose noradrenaline support
7. **Expired on 23-December-2025 at 4:30 PM**
8. **Cause of Death: Multiorgan Dysfunction Syndrome (MODS)**

---

**Data Collection Date:** 15-January-2026
**Data Collected By:** Dr Sarath Chandrabhatla
**Last Updated:** 15-January-2026

---

## Operative Findings (19-December-2025)

- ~2.8L hemorrhagic purulent ascitic fluid drained
- Multiple old blood clots (~500cc) evacuated - mainly from right lower quadrant around PCD entry point
- Thick purulent collection with clots in right iliac fossa and pelvis
- Right subphrenic collection (~500ml) - purulent, hemorrhagic, with pus flakes over liver surface
- No obvious bile/enteric leak identified
- Thickened, edematous stomach; LAMS could not be localized
- Extensive intra-abdominal adhesions forming cocoon abdomen
- Greater omentum thickened, densely adhered to small bowel and transverse colon
- Thick pus from interbowel space in left lower abdomen (communicating with peripancreatic WON)
- Small bowel could not be completely delineated due to dense adhesions
- Small serosal bowel injury repaired
- Feeding jejunostomy deferred (small bowel inaccessible)
- Necrosectomy and stent removal deferred due to hemodynamic instability

![](_page_0_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_0_Picture_3.jpeg) # Department : Surgical Gastroenterology Discharge Summary | CR No.: 239212501771952 | Name: Vishnu | Age/Gender: 34 Yr/M | |----------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------| | Admission No.: 239212025046744 | Department Unit: Surgical Gastroenterology (Surgical
Gastroenterology) | Consultant/Faculty: Dr Vishal Gupta | | Ward: Gastro Surgery Ward | Room/Bed: Gastro Srg Ward Room/ Bed 6 | Patient Category: Ayushman Bharat | | Discharge Type: Normal Discharge | Father/Spouse Name: Devkaran/- | Occupation: | | Contact No.: 9575345171 | Address: FD.,,Sehore,Sehore | State/Country Madhya
Pradesh/India | | D.O.A. : 01-Aug-2025 14:57 | D.O.D. : 19-Sep-2025 | D.O. Print Report: 19-Sep-2025 15:40 | ## CHIEF COMPLAINTS: Pain abdomen x 3 Months Nausea and Vomiting x 3 Months HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient was apparently healthy 2 months ago when he had severe pain abdomen on April 18th 2025 in epigastrium. It was severe, continuous, radiating to back and also associated with nausea and multiple episodes of vomiting, both gastric and bilious. For this, he consulted at Rudra Hospital for 15 days (April 18th - April 30th 2025) where he was managed conservatively. Later in view of persistent symptoms he got admitted at another private hospital where he was investigated with CECT and also underwent pleural tapping for effusion. He had mild symptom relief and was referred to AIIMS Bhopal. He was admitted in AIIMS Bhopal (General surgery) from 19th June to July 1st. He was managed conservatively, was started on ATT after pulmonary medicine opinion in view of cytology findings in pleural fluid aspirate. He was later discharged and attached to SGE and VIR OPD. He underwent 2 PCD placement into epigastric collection on which was later removed on OPD basis. He continued to have pain abdomen and hence was admitted in SGE ward. No H/o jaundice / fever spikes. H/o passage of dark coloured stool (+) constipation (+). No H/o DM / HTN. Dry cough (+) SOB (+). On ATT since 2 months for suspected pulmonary TB. Personal History: Mixed diet, sleep adequate, addiction - alcohol, tobacco chewing since 20 years. No known allergies. CASE SUMMARY: Patient conscious oriented to time, place and person ,fairly nourished .No Edema/LN/clubbing/pallor/icterus are present. Weight- 41.3 kg ,height- 158 cm, BMI- 16.5 kg/m2 ,PR-92/min BP- 120/84 mmhg RR- 20 Spo2- 98% .On examination-Chest-B/L air entry present ,P/A- mild epigastric tenderness +. CONDITION AT DISCHARGE: Patient is currently being hemodynamically stable, tolerating soft diet, passing stool and flatus and is being discharged in stable condition. PCD in situ draining - 100-150 ml/day; Right ICD in situ draining 10 ml/day, column movement+ Acute severe necrotising pancreatitis Multiple walled off necrosis FINAL DIAGNOSIS: S/P multiple PCD placements into WON(30/6/25, 8/8/2025, 20/8/2025) B/L Pancreaticopleural fistula Right sided pyothorax ![](_page_1_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_1_Picture_3.jpeg) S/P right pleural cavity pigtail( 10/9/2025) Disconnected pancreatic duct syndrome External pancreatic fistula Cholelithiasis; Splenic vein thrombosis; HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient was admitted to the SGE ward with the above-mentioned complaints. Routine tests were done (Hb: 8.8, TLC: 9490, TB/DB: 0.49/0.19, AST/ALT: 236/54, ALP: 92, CRP: 30 amylase-). He was kept NPO, started on levofloxacin and VIR opinion was taken for drainage of intraabdominal collection which was drained under CT guidance on 8/8/2025, 14 Fr pigtail placed into the collection in left paracolic gutter. Fluid had very high amylase- 3957, & was sterile. He had symptomatic improvement and was started on oral diet. He had b/l pleural effusion and underwent diagnostic pleural tapping on 11/8/2025 and its showed elevated amylase levels in both sides (Right- 3090; left- 556). On 12/8/205 he had recurrent pain abdomen and multiple episodes of vomiting. He was kept NPO, started on octreotide, and MGE opinion was taken for NJ placement. NCCT abdomen was done on 16/8/2025 and showed collection near pancreatic head. On 20/8/2025 NJ placement was done. He was shifted to HDU in view of respiratory distress. C xray revealed gross b/l pleural effusion; pulmonary opinion was taken and therapeutic pleural tapping was done on 22/8/2025 following which he had symptomatic relief. Under CT guidance,14 Fr pigtail was placed into the peripancreatic collection and old pcd was removed on 21/8/2025. The pigtail drained around 100-200 ml necrotic fluid daily and later clear fluid (amylase- 10,7401, culture -sterile). NJ trial feed was started on 21/8/2025 which he tolerated and was increased as per tolerance. A CECT was done on 25/8/2025 and MRCP on 2/9/2025 which showed disconnected pancreatic duct. MGE opinion was taken for ERCP and PD stenting and is planned for the same on OPD basis . Pulmonary medicine opinion was taken on 8/9/2025 in view of mild tachypnoea and aspiration was done from right pleural cavity; it showed pus, and on 10/9 2025, 10 fr pigtail was placed under VIR into right pleural cavity which drain around 100 ml pus. ( Culture- K pneumoniae). PCD fluid was refed via NJ. Patient was given oral feed trial which he tolerated without any increase in PCD output. Hence NJ was removed on 13/9/2205 and he was started fully on oral diet. Pulmonary review was taken on 15/8/2025 and was advised to keep the PCD in situ in view of infected pleural fluid and discharge patient with ICD. He had high grade fever episodes on 17 and 18th September. He was started on oral antibiotics and usg was done (18/9/2025) which revealed no intra abdominal collection or pleural effusion. Fever settled after 2 days. Patient is currently being hemodynamically stable, tolerating soft diet, passing stool and flatus and is being discharged in stable condition. During hospital course he was managed with iv and oral antibiotics (meropenem, levofloxacin, cefuroxime) analgesics, antiemetics, antispasmodics, octreotide symptomatic and supportive care. Labs at the time of discharge; CBC- 9.5,8280,3.86l, crp-33, lipase- 26. Plan : ERCP PD stenting. OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: USG W/A (14/05/25 Outside):GB shows multiple calculi of average size 5 mm, GB wall thickness normal, no pericholecystic collection. Pancreas shows edema & mild to moderate peripancreatic, perisplenic & pelvic free fluid. Rt kidney shows calculi of size 4-5mm at all Poles. Lt kidney shows calculi of size 3-4mm at mid pole & lower pole. There is mod. Rt pleural effusion. CECT ABDOMEN & PELVIS (10/6/2025 Outside): Liver is normal in size. Hypoperfusion is seen involving Right lobe of Liver. PV is cord like at liver hilum likely chronic thrombosis. No obvious focal lesion; CBD not dilated.GB - partially distended. Multiple calculi are seen largest of size 6mm Walls - Normal. Pancreas appears Atrophic. A well-defined cystic lesion ~10 x 6 x 4 cm is seen posterior to pancreas + hypodense areas likely hemorrhage. The pancreatic duct is mildly dilated; Spleen - Normal in size & density. B/L moderate basal pleural effusion CECT thorax & abdomen 20/6/25,AIIMS: Replacement of pancreatic parenchyma involving, body region ( greater than 30% involvement of pancreatic parenchyma). Two large well-defined irregular shaped peripherally enhancing collections replacing body of ![](_page_2_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_2_Picture_3.jpeg) pancreas extending to anterior peri-pancreatic region and to subhepatic and subdiaphragmatic regions suggestive of pseudocyst. No obvious communication noted between these collections. Left branch of MPV appears attuenuated however,normal contrast opacification seen , likely secondary to mass effect. Non-visualization of extra-hepatic portal vein and splenic vein -thrombosis/ significant luminal compression by the pseudocyst . mild pelvic ascites and lt. Pleural effusion. Few isolated peripherally enhancing collections in the subdiaphragmatic and umbilical regions. Tubular and cystic bronchiectatic changes involving bilateral lobar, segmental and subsegmental bronchi. CECT THORAX AND ABDOMEN 25/8/25 ,AIIMS: Peripherally enhancing collection in the head of the pancreas region, measuring approx. 1.8 x 1.7 cm, seen abutting the intra-pancreatic segment of CBD, which appears to be non dilated. A pig tail is seen traversing through the left 8th intercostal space with its tip is noted anterior to the body of the pancreas in anterior para-renal space with no obvious surrounding large peripherally enhancing collection, however significant fat stranding is noted. Another small peripherally enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collection of size 4.3 x 1.7 cm noted in the left paraumbilical region in anterior abdomen. Few small peripherally enhancing, variable sized heterogeneously hypodense collections are noted in the gastro-splenic space, largest of them measuring approx. 1.2 x 1.2 cm, abutting the traversing pigtail posteriorly. There is another, ill defined, irregular shaped, peripherally enhancing heterogeneously hypodense collection, measuring approx. 2.5 x 1.7 x 2.3 cm noted in the gastro-hepatic region. The body region is pancreas is mildly atrophied and shows hypo enhancement. THORAX- Tubular and cystic bronchiectatic changes are noted involving the bilateral lobar, segmental and sub segmental bronchi. Gross amount of free fluid noted in the right pleural cavity for maximum thickness of 6 cm with overlying collapsed / consolidated lung field. Moderate amount of free fluid noted in the left pleural cavity for maximum thickness of 4.1 cm with overlying collapsed / consolidated lung. MRCP 2/9/25 ,AIIMS; Gall bladder: is distended, with multiple variable sized, round to oval, intraluminal T2 hypointense filling defects, with admixed T2 intermediate sludge in entire GB lumen and the neck-cystic duct junction, largest measuring 6.1x6.8x5mm in the fundal regions suggestive of GB calculi. No evidence of GB wall thickening/pericholecystic fluid noted. The cystic duct is dilated (maximum diameter 5.5mm), with short course curving inferomedially and draining in the right posterolateral aspect of upper 1/3rd CBD (7 o��� clock).Biliary drainage: The RASD is joining with the LHD to form CHD, with the RPSD seen draining separately into the CHD just below the primary confluence (Type IIIB) CBD: is dilated however shows smooth distal tapering towards ampulla with no evidence of T2 hypointense filling defect noted. Mild prominence of the central IHBR, however no obvious dilatation. Pancreas : There is focal area of non visualized pancreatic parenchyma in the neck region, and replaced by two relatively defined collections showing central heterogenous intermediate to mildly hyperintense, T1 hypointense fluid signal and peripheral irregular rim of T2/FS iso to slightly hyperintense, T1 isointense soft tissue (w.r.t adjacent pancreatic parenchyma). They collectively measure 2.4x2.3x3.5cm. The central fluid content shows diffusion restriction on DWI/ADC. There is another similar collection seen in the left anterior pararenal space (near lower pole of left kidney) showing central T1 hypointense, T2/FS hyperintense signal and peripheral T2/FS hypointense rim with central mild diffusion restriction measuring 2x1.6x1.9cm. There is focal non visualization of the pancreatic duct at this above mentioned region in neck for a total segment length of 2.2cm. Distally and proximally, the pancreatic duct shows normal caliber (~2.6mm at tail and ~2mm at head). Pigtail catheter tip noted entering the abdominal cavity through the left hypochondrium with its tip in peripancreatic region abutting the parenchyma at the proximal body. No evidence of any surrounding collection noted. There is mild diffuse T2/FS hyperintense signal in the peripancreatic region and mesenteric fat. No evidence of anomalous pancreatico-biliary junction/long common channel. There is gross multi-septated pleural effusion on right side (maximum thickness~4.3cm) with few areas of T2/FS intermediate loculated fluid pockets and debris with mild pleural thickening. There is collapsed/consolidated lower lobe anteromedial to the effusion. Thin sliver of pleural effusion seen on left side. UGIE (20/8/2025 AIIMS): Normal. USG W/A 17/9/25 AIIMS: Cholelithiasis without reactive etiology, Proximal CBD dilatation with abrupt cut off distally , Rt. renal calculi ,Rt. pleural effusion. Pigtail noted in situ on Rt. pleural cavity & another one in splenorenal pouch. No intra abdominal collection. DFA :(Date/Source/Value):- 22-9-25/Rt. Pleural cavity/1262, 09-08-25/1st PCD fluid/3957, 11-8-25/ Lt. Pleural cavity /5567, 11-8-25/ Rt. Pleural cavity/3090, 22-08-25/Rt. pleural cavity/484, 27-08-25/2nd PCD fluid/10740. Right pleural pus C/S - K pneumoniae - ![](_page_3_Picture_0.jpeg) ![](_page_3_Picture_3.jpeg) intermediate sensitivity- colistin. ### OPERATION PERFORMED: Pigtail Placement into Pleural Cavity On 10-Sep-2025 OPERATIVE FINDINGS: On 10/9/25, Under all aspetic precautions with LA cover USG guidance 10 Fr pigtail catheter was inserted into right pleural cavity with guide wire ,15 cc purulent collection was aspirated. Pigtail Placement On 20-Aug-2025 OPERATIVE FINDINGS: On 20/8/25 Under CT guidance and aseptic precautions, a 14F pigtail catheter was inserted into the peripancreatic collection. The previous collection was also drained. Pigtail Placement On 08-Aug-2025 OPERATIVE FINDINGS: On 08/08/25, under CT guidance and aseptic precautions, a 14F pigtail catheter was inserted into the collection in the left paracolic gutter. ## ADVICE ON DISCHARGE: Soft high protein low fat diet; ICD and Pigtail care as advised. Tab Cefuroxime 500 mg BD x 7 days; T Pantoprazole 40 mg x 7 days; T Paracetamol 500 mg TDS X 3 days followed by sos x 7 days; Tab Tramadol 50 mg sos x 7 days. T. Vitamin C 1 tab od x 7 days; Syp B complex 2 tsp OD x 7 days; Protein powder 2 tsp Bd x 7 days; Syp Cremaffin 15 ml hs x 7 days; Follow up in Pulmonary medicine department for further management of right sided pyothorax and ICD removal. Follow up in MGE OPD for ERCP and Pancreatic duct stenting. Follow up in PAC for clearance for ERCP. DISCHARGE BY : Dr Vishal Gupta DISCHARGE REMARKS : FOLLOW UP ON : 25-Sep-2025 FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Vishal Gupta FOLLOW UP ADVICE : To visit TEM AIIMS or local hospital in case of high grade fever, pain abdomen, drain/icd pull out, chest pain, dyspneoa etc. Summary Prepared By Summary Approved By Dr Basil Babu Dr Vishal Gupta

# CHIEF COMPLAINTS:

Pain in upper abdomen since 3 months

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient was apparently well 3 months back, when he had sudden onset pain abdomen, severe in intensity colicky in nature in umblical region radiating to epigastrium, more on bending forward, present throughout the day. Patient was admitted for the same in a private hospital where he was managed conservatively.

A/w abdominal distension, gradually increased in size. A/w vomitting 5-7 episodes per day with food content, yellowish in color, not blood tinged.

A/w fever spikes (documented 102 F) with chills, mostly at night.There is a h/o yellowish discoloration, malena, hard stools, weight loss, dry cough and shortness of breath ( not requiring oxygen support).

# Past history

Received treatment for above mentioned complaints in rudra hospital for 10 days.

Again readmitted after one month.

(Kept NPO and history of three times therapeutic pleural fluid drainage)

History of treatment in aman hospital for above complaints.

No known comorbidities

No surgical history

Personal history

Chronic alcoholic since 20 years (last 3 months back)

Tobacco chewer since 13 years (last 1 day back)

Vegetarian by diet

Normal bladder habbits

History of tb contact with mother

General Examination

Vitals: BP: 118/70 PR: 72 bpm Temp: Afebrile

SpO2: 99%

Pallor:- , Icterus: -, cynosis -, Edema: -, Lymphadenopathy: -

CNS: Conscious & oriented to time, place and person

![](_page_1_Picture_0.jpeg)

![](_page_1_Picture_3.jpeg)

No sensory and motor deficit CVS: S1, S2 heard, no murmur Respiratory: B/L air entry present

R>L ,

B/l basal crepts present

Abdomen

Distended abdomen

Umblicus central and inverted

Visible dilated veins in epigastrium

Swelling in epigastrium

Swelling in epigastrium, 12\*12cm , tense cystic ,non tender,no local rise of temperature

On percussion: dullness Bowel sounds : present

### FINAL DIAGNOSIS:

chronic pancreatitis with walled of necrosis with cholelithiasis with portal vein thrombosis with ALD on att since 26/6/25.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient presented to AIIMS OPD with above mentioned complaints and admitted in general surgery ward on 19/6/25. All routine investigations were sent.USG w/a was done s/o likely pseudocyst and moderate left pleural effusion. Pulmonary medicine call was done in view of outside cytology s/o tubercular etiology and repeat pleural fluid diagnostic tests were advised. Cect w/a and HRCT Thorax was done s/o walled of necrosis and pleural effusion .IVR call was sought in view of USG and CECT findings, and diagnostic pleural fluid tapping was done, which was sent for analysis. Gastromedicine call was sought in view of cect findings s/o pseudocyst with portal vein thrombosis and conservative management was advised. Both pleural fluid and sputum CBNAAT were negative but pleural fluid was s/o exudative etiology. A review pulmo call was sought, and the patient was started on ATT(26/06/25). Gastromedicine review call was done in view of raised amylase, lipase ?alcoholic pancreatitis. Conservative management on the OPD basis was advised. IVR call was done again for pseudocyst fluid aspiration, and fluid was sent for analysis. Currently the patient is vitally stable, accepting oral feeds ,tolerating ATT passing flatus and motion, hence being discharged with advice to follow up in general surgery OPD.

### OTHER INVESTIGATIONS: USG w/a 12/6/25

Chronic pancreatitis with perpancreatic walled off necrosis/likely pseudocyst

B/l minimal to mild pleural effusion

Minimal to mild ascitis

# Cect abdomen

A well defined cystic lesion anterior to pancreas compressing the left lobe of the liver. Another cystic lesion posterior to pancreas with hyperdense areas likely haemorrhage . The pancreatic duct is mildly dilated. S/o chronic pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation. Likely portal vein thrombosis

Cholelithiasis

Right renal non obstructive calculi

Bilateral pleural effusion

## USG w/a 19/6/25

Bulky heterogenous head of pancreas with large hypoechoic collection with internal septations in perpancreatic and liver sac likely

![](_page_2_Picture_0.jpeg)

![](_page_2_Picture_3.jpeg)

pseudocyst.

Mild ascitis

Minimal left pleural effusion.

Review USG 20/6/25

Moderate amount of free fluid in left pleural cavity of maximum thickness 8.1cm(1620 ml)

Cect abdomen 19/6/25(AIIMS)

Necrosis of pancreatic parenchyma involving the body region (>30% involvement of pancreatic parenchyma).

Two large well defined irregular shaped peripherally enhancing collections replacing the body of the pancreas extending to the anterior peri pancreatic region and to the subhepatic and subdiaphragmatic region with further extent and surrounding inflammatory changes s/o walled of necrosis.

Non visualisation of extra hepatic portal vein and splenic vein ?thrombosis/significant luminal compression by the WON.

Mild pelvic ascitis and left sided pleural effusion.

Few isolated peripherally enhancing collections in subdiaphragmatic and umblical regions.

Tubular and cystic bronchiectatic changes involving bilateral lobar segmental and subsegmental bronchi

### ADVICE ON DISCHARGE:

High Protein diet ,low fat

Protein powder 2 tsp TDS

Plenty of oral fluids

Tab ATT (4FDC 3 tab ) OD to continue

Tab BENADONE 40 mg 1/2 tab OD to continue

Tab PANTOP 40 mg OD

Tab PCM 650 mg SOS

Tab CREON 10K BD

Tab mvbc 1 tab od

L/A BUPRENORPHINE PATCH for 1 week

Syp CREMAFFIN 30 ml HS SOS

DISCHARGE BY : Dr Manish Swarnkar

DISCHARGE REMARKS :

FOLLOW UP ON : 03-Jul-2025

FOLLOW UP CONSULTANT / FACULTY : Dr Manish Swarnkar

FOLLOW UP ADVICE : Follow up in general surgery OPD on Thursday and second and fourth Saturday

Follow up in pulmonology OPD.

Follow up in DOTS

Summary Prepared By Summary Approved By

Gensurgward1 Dr Manish Swarnkar

Left branch of MPV appears attuenuated however,normal contrast opacification seen , likely secondary to mass effect.Non-visualization of extra-hepatic portal vein and splenic vein as described- ?thrombosis with significant reduction in the peripancreatic collection with increased bilateral pleural effusion. ●
- MRCP done to check for DPDS.

- CBD: is dilated however shows smooth distal tapering towards ampulla with no evidence of T2 hypointense filling defect noted. Mild prominence of the central IHBR, however no obvious dilatation. No obvious mass/soft tissue lesion is seen in the peri ampullary region. ●

| Level       | Diameter (mm) |
|-------------|---------------|
| CBD         | 9.5           |
| CHD         | 9.7           |
| RASD        | 5.3           |
| RPD         | 3.1           |
| LHD         | 3.8           |
| Cystic duct | 5.5           |

● Pancreas : (correlated with CECT abdomen scan done on 25.08.2025)

There is focal area of non visualized pancreatic parenchyma in the neck region, and replaced by two relatively defined collections showing central heterogenous T2/T2 FS intermediate to mildly hyperintense, T1 hypointense fluid signal and peripheral irregular rim of T2/FS iso to slightly hyperintense, T1 isointense soft

- tissue (w.r.t adjacent pancreatic parenchyma). They collectively measure 2.4x2.3x3.5cm (TRxAPxCC). There is adjacent. The central fluid content shows diffusion restriction on DWI/ADC. There is another similar collection seen in the left anterior pararenal space (near lower pole of left kidney) showing central T1 hypointense, T2/FS hyperintense signal and peripheral T2/FS hypointense rim with central mild diffusion restriction measuring 2x1.6x1.9cm (TRxAPxCC). ●
- There is focal non visualization of the pancreatic duct at this above mentioned region in neck

for a total segment length of 2.2cm. Distally and proximally, the pancreatic duct shows normal caliber (~2.6mm at tail and ~2mm at head).

- There is gross multi-septated pleural effusion on right side (maximum thickness~4.3cm) with few areas of T2/FS intermediate loculated fluid pockets and debris with mild pleural thickening. There is collapsed/consolidated lower lobe anteromedial to the effusion. Thin sliver of pleural effusion seen on left side. ●
- Liver: is mildly enlarged, measures ~15.2 cm in maximum cranio-caudal dimension. There is a well defined tiny oval T2/FS hyperintense, T1 hypointense cystic lesion in the segment IVA of liver measuring ~5x4mm-suggestive of simple hepatic cyst. Rest of the liver shows normal parenchymal signal. ●
- Spleen: measures~9.1cm in cranio-caudal dimension.No focal lesion noted.
- There is mild dilatation of the left renal pelvis and proximal ureter, however no calyceal dilatation seen. Bilateral kidneys otherwise appear normal in size, shaped and signal intensity. ●
- NG tube noted in situ.

# IMPRESSION: MRCP reveals:

- Focal area of full thickness necrotic parenchyma in pancreatic neck replaced by two WON collection, with focal non visualization of pancreatic duct in this segment as described. ●
- Another small WON in the left anterior pararenal space (near lower pole of left kidney).
- Gross multi-septated pleural effusion on right side as described.
- Pigtail catheter tip abutting the pancreatic parenchyma at the proximal body as described.

ZN stain for AFB is Negative.

---

## Summary

**Study ID:** AP-SVT-004

**Classification:** **SVT CASE - COMBINED PORTAL VEIN + SPLENIC VEIN THROMBOSIS (CHRONIC)**

**Key Points:**
1. 34-year-old severely malnourished male (BMI 16.5) with severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis
2. Etiology: Mixed - Alcohol (20-year history) + Gallstones
3. **COMBINED PV + SV THROMBOSIS - CHRONIC**
   - Portal vein: Cord-like appearance (chronic thrombosis)
   - Splenic vein: Not visualized (complete occlusion)
   - First documented: 10-Jun-2025
4. SMV: PATENT
5. Portal hypertensive features:
   - Right liver lobe hypoperfusion
   - CBD dilatation (9.5 mm)
   - Left MPV branch attenuated
   - Varices status UNKNOWN (UGIE pending)
6. Complicated by:
   - **DPDS (2.2 cm gap)** - rare complication
   - **External pancreatic fistula (100-150 ml/day)**
   - **Bilateral pancreaticopleural fistula**
   - **Right pyothorax with XDR Klebsiella**
   - **XDR E. coli UTI**
   - Severe malnutrition
   - Suspected pulmonary TB
   - Multiple comorbidities
7. **ANTICOAGULATION NOT STARTED**
8. Multiple drains in situ at discharge (PCD, ICD)
9. Requires ERCP with PD stenting

**CRITICAL RESEARCH NOTES:**
1. **Most severe SVT** in cohort - Combined PV + SV thrombosis (chronic)
2. **DPDS** - rare complication requiring ERCP intervention
3. **XDR infections** - extremely limited antibiotic options
4. **Multiple fistulae** - pancreatic and pancreaticopleural
5. **NO anticoagulation** despite extensive thrombosis
6. **Severely malnourished** - BMI 16.5
7. **Complex multi-system disease** requiring coordinated care
8. **UGIE urgently needed** to assess for varices

---

**Data Collection Date:** 15-January-2026
**Data Collected By:** Dr Sarath Chandrabhatla
**Last Updated:** 15-January-2026
